div.head: TO The right Honorable my very good Lord the Earle of Southampton.
div.p:

Their demaund Å¿eemed to me Å¿o reaÅ¿onable, honeÅ¿t, profitable, and delightfull, as I deemed it diÅ¿courteÅ¿ie, and incivilitie, not to condeÅ¿cend to Å¿atisfie their Å¿ute. A treatiÅ¿e hereupon I penned, but I know not how in the inundation of my croÅ¿Å¿es it Å¿uffered Å¿hipwrack with the reÅ¿t of my writings: and at what time I Å¿uppoÅ¿ed it had bin lying rotting in the bottome of the Å¿ea, a favorable gale brought it aÅ¿hoare, where being found (belike by Å¿ome that liked it well) was taken vp, entertayned, and diÅ¿perÅ¿ed abroad. When I beheld it, I wondred, and could not tell whether to reioyce to Å¿ee mine aborted infant revived, or feare whether it had bin maymed and corrupted: for I doubted it had paÅ¿Å¿ed by Å¿ome hands, which might have cavÅ¿ed me Å¿peake in a language I never vnderÅ¿tood. At laÅ¿t I fell a peruÅ¿ing of
it, and in deede found, it had not bin hardly vÅ¿ed, but kindly dealt withall, & what eÅ¿capes were overÅ¿lipped, proceeded rather from the vncorrected copie (for of three this was moÅ¿t vnperÅ¿it) then from any vncivill entertaynement. After that the whole impreÅ¿Å¿ion was diÅ¿perÅ¿ed, the Printer made meanes to have me adde what I thought wanting, and to amend that I iudged amiÅ¿Å¿e. And Å¿o I have augmented this edition with as much more as the firÅ¿t copie conteyned. The which after I had abÅ¿olved, it Å¿eemed of it Å¿elfe by a connaturall Å¿ympathie to preÅ¿ent it Å¿elfe vnto your Honour. For literall labours are vÅ¿ually offered to Å¿uch perÅ¿onages, with whom they particularly conÅ¿ort: and how could any paÅ¿Å¿ions finde out a perÅ¿on more proportionate then your Honour? They concerne Gentlemen and Noblemen, to guide them in the way of civill converÅ¿ation: Your Gentrie is well knowne: they appertayne to Å¿ouldiours to Å¿tirre them vp to courage, and magnanimitie: your martiall proweÅ¿Å¿e are patent at home, and famous abroad. They belong to MagiÅ¿trates and officers, for diÅ¿covery and manage of Å¿ubiects: your place, and evident hopes of further preÅ¿erment preÅ¿age, that this part cannot but agree to you. For me thinks as often as I conÅ¿ider your preÅ¿ence about his MaieÅ¿tie, it Å¿eemeth to me, with mine eyes to behold an other matchleÅ¿Å¿e Parmenio, for truÅ¿t and fidelitie about our invincible Alexander of the North. Wherefore my paÅ¿Å¿ions being provided for Courts, Fields, and Senates, finde in you vnited, that they Å¿ought for diÅ¿perÅ¿ed: for as it is di â¢â¢ icill to determine which of them hath chiefeÅ¿t part in you, Å¿o it is eaÅ¿ie for me to reÅ¿olve how fit this diÅ¿courÅ¿e is for you, which levelleth at all three. I doubt
not but I might Å¿ay to you as Plotinus a famous PhiloÅ¿opher in Rome Å¿ayd to Origen, when he entred into his Schoole to heare him reade, who preÅ¿ently at Origens aÅ¿pect rubore Å¿uffuÅ¿us, bluÅ¿hing, ceaÅ¿ed to Å¿peake: Origen Porphyr. in vita Plot. requeÅ¿ted him to proceede, Plotinus replied, that it was time for a profeÅ¿Å¿our to hold his peace, when his auditors before-hand knew what he intended to teach. You need not learne of me thoÅ¿e things, which both by Å¿tudie and practiÅ¿e you have attayned vnto: yet it is no Å¿mall comfort for a man to Å¿ee, either that he knoweth, confirmed, or that he doeth, approved. If theÅ¿e Å¿illie labours Å¿hall content your Honour, I wiÅ¿h no other recompence: for that which liketh you in this kinde, I know will not diÅ¿like the beÅ¿t: and that which pleaÅ¿eth the beÅ¿t, by right reaÅ¿on, Å¿hould be a good inducement, to content all. If theÅ¿e blaÅ¿ted leaves be acceptable to your LordÅ¿hip, when the fruites are ripe, you Å¿hall receive a fatter crop: in the meane time ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us preÅ¿erve you in his grace, protect you from your enemies, and deliver you from inordinate PaÅ¿Å¿ions.

div.head: THE PREFACE vnto the Reader.
div.p:
I Have divers times weighed with my Å¿elfe, whencefrom it Å¿hould proceed that Italians, and Spaniardes, with other inhabitants â¢ eyond the Alpes, Å¿hould account â¢ lemings, EngliÅ¿hmen, Scots, and other Nations,Tramontani Å¿em â¢â¢â¢ . dwelling on this Å¿ide, Å¿imple, vncircumÅ¿pect, vnwarie, eaÅ¿ie to be deceyved, and circumvented by them. And the cauÅ¿e of my doubting was, for that I had perceived, by long experience in Schooles, both in Spaine, Italie, France, and Flaunders; that â¢ emings, Scots, and EngliÅ¿hmen were ever equall, and rather deeper Schollers, than eyther Italians or Spaniards, Å¿o many for Å¿o many: Whereunto we may adde the proofe of former ages, wherein all the worlde will confeÅ¿Å¿e, that our Nation hath yeelded as profound and learned Schoole-men as any Nation vnder the Sunne, in like quantity and pr â¢ portion. For, what Countrie in any age did ever repreÅ¿ent vnto the world, Å¿uch venerable w â¢ ttes, as England, by yeelding our venerable Bede, who, borne in a corner of the world, comprehended the whole world in his boundieÅ¿Å¿e apprehenÅ¿ion & iudgementâª what age ever Å¿ee before our Alexander de Hales, a Divine more â¢ rrefragable in all his doctrine and opinions, the chiefe maÅ¿ter of Schoole-men, before that England Å¿ent him into â¢ rance? In what Countrie ever appeared Å¿uch a mirrour of learning, of Å¿ubtilitie, of brevitie, of perspicuitie, (in deepeÅ¿t matters, and vnto worthy Å¿pirites) as when Scotus Å¿hewed himÅ¿elfe in the chayre at Oxford? whom, for his worth, Å¿ome other Countries with no leÅ¿Å¿e vntrueth, than ambition, have challenged for theirs, and would have bereaved England of one of the worthies of the world, What might I not Å¿ay of O cams, of Bacons, of Middletons, in forraine Nations more accounted of, than prized at home,
whoÅ¿e doctrine, the beÅ¿t highly esteeme, whoÅ¿e wittes the wiÅ¿est admire, and whoÅ¿e opinions innumerable Doctors doe follow? Wherefore we may well glory in this, that our Countrie hath affoorded moÅ¿t of the maÅ¿ters, & of the chiefeÅ¿t Wits, which at this time both ScotiÅ¿ts, Reals, and Nominals do follow, eyther in PhiloÅ¿ophie, or Divinitie. And yet for all this, our Nation is accounted Å¿imple and vnwiÅ¿e, among divers others.

Moreover, let vs cast our eyes vpon all Å¿ortes of Artes and Trades, from the very Å¿hooe vnto the hatte, from the Å¿hirte to the cloake, from the kitchin to the Court, and we Å¿hall Å¿ee our Nation as well furniÅ¿hed, as compleate, and artificiall as any other: and as all travellers can well affirme, farre Å¿uperior to the Spantards, and nothing inferior vnto the Italians. I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿Å¿e, that in Å¿ome one or other trade, the Italians Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿e vs, but they be Å¿uch, as eyther England regardeth not at all, or prizeth not very much: but, in Å¿uch as our Countrie esteemeth, wee may, eyther equall or preferre our Å¿elves before them. And yet for all this, a hie-minded companion doubted not, within theÅ¿e few yeeres, to call our Nation, vncivill, and barbarousâª and others, to repute vs as Å¿imple and vnwarie. After Å¿ome conÅ¿ideration and reflexion vpon our Å¿elves, with reference vnto other Nations, I found out three cauÅ¿es, why thoÅ¿e which inhabit theÅ¿e Northerne Climates, are accounted Å¿imple and vnwiÅ¿e.

The first is, a naturall inclination to Æ²ertue and honestie, much more palpable and eaÅ¿ie to be perceyved in theÅ¿e colder Countries, than in thoÅ¿e hotter Climates: this we may proove by common experience, for both Spamards and Italians, if they can have a I lemming, or an EngliÅ¿hman for their Å¿ervant, if he be alike qualified with thoÅ¿e Country-men, they will preferre him before their owne, for fidelitie, Å¿inceritie and diligence. The very bluÅ¿hing alÅ¿o of our people, Å¿heweth a better ground, wherevpon Vertue may build, than certaine brazen faces, who never change themÅ¿elves, although they committe, yea, and be deprehended in enormious crimes; for the Å¿hame of vice, is a good commencement of Vertue, becauÅ¿e it proceedeth from a iudgement diÅ¿liking of evill, which is an apt beginning of good. Wherefore AriÅ¿totle calleth Å¿hamefaÅ¿tneÅ¿Å¿e a vertue, notAriÅ¿t. 3. mora. Nico. cap. 8 â¢
for that it is a true vertue indeed, (for it moÅ¿t of all raigneth in
children, who are not capable Å¿ubiects of morall Vertues) but becauÅ¿e it is the Å¿eede of Vertue, or a Å¿purre to Æ²ertue, or a bridle from vice: or a way, preparation or diÅ¿poÅ¿ition vnto an honest vertuous life. And therefore Plato Å¿aid that iuÅ¿tice & Å¿hame faÅ¿tnes werePlato in protagor. the giftes of Iupiter. This naturall foundation of honestie, other Nations baptize with the Name of Simplicitie, which they vnderÅ¿tand, not in Å¿uch Å¿ort as it reÅ¿embleth a Vertue, and bordereth vpon Å¿inceritie and vpright dealing, but rather as a vice bending to Å¿tupiditie, & lacke of knowledge. The common Å¿ort of Spaniards and Italians, cenÅ¿uring our inclinations, with an erroneous iudgement, account that a paÅ¿Å¿ion of ignorance, which in very deed, is the firÅ¿t Å¿tep vnto prudence, eÅ¿teeming them fooliÅ¿hly vnwary, whom they ought to have reputed rather vertuouÅ¿ly wi â¢ e.

The Å¿econd cauÅ¿e is, Education, for prudence and policie are wonne by experience, experience by practiÅ¿e, practiÅ¿e by converÅ¿ation, converÅ¿ation by communication with people, the which in Citties is better attained vnto then in Villages, and in Citties of greater commerce and reÅ¿ort, than in Cities of leÅ¿Å¿er repayre. This wee trie by common conÅ¿ent of all men, who acknowledge the inhabitants of Seatownes to be more craftie than the rurall colonies, and therefore Ilanders are iudged moÅ¿t craftie of all, yet my meaning is alwayes, caeteris paribus, becauÅ¿e, as Å¿ome Ilanders have little trade, Å¿o Å¿ome Citties no great reÅ¿ort. The nature of mens wittes is Å¿uch, that one whetteth and polliÅ¿heth greatly another, for as their faces are various, Å¿o their inventions Å¿etches, Å¿leights and iudgements are diverÅ¿e.

Wherefore thoÅ¿e that have great commerce with men, either they themÅ¿elves; or elÅ¿e Å¿ee the various dealings and practiÅ¿es of others, cannot but in time greatly perfite their owne iudgements and vnderÅ¿tandings: this we may dayly perceyve in our owne Countrie, wherein our Northerne and Welchmen, when they come to London, are very Å¿imple, and vnwarie, but afterwards, by converÅ¿ing a while, and by the experience of other mens behaviours, they become wonderfull wiÅ¿e and iudicious. The Italians therefore and Spaniards, diÅ¿dayning greatly to dwell long in the Countrey, and betaking themÅ¿elves almoÅ¿t wholly vnto Cities, by a continuall converÅ¿ation, even from their youth, become very nimble in the managing all affaires,
and conÅ¿equently, very politique and craeftie. For great Citties (Å¿pecially Emporiall) affoord vnto them all Å¿orts of poÅ¿itique prudenc â¢ , eyther for vniverÅ¿all governement of the State, or particular regiment of the Cittie, or private oeconomie for a family, or common converÅ¿ation with men: all which Citties, as open Schooles, teach abundantly; villages and townes, eyther nothing, or very Å¿paringly. The moÅ¿t of our EngliÅ¿hmen contrariwiÅ¿e, eyther dwell in the Countrie, or in Citties not Å¿o populous, wherein they may enioy Å¿uch meanes, as enable other Nations vnto the attainement of w â¢ tâª po â¢ i â¢ y, and prudence, wherefore this defect of converÅ¿ation impeacheth greatly the warines of our Countriemen with other Nations: whereby Å¿undry of our rurall Gentlemen, are aÅ¿well acquainted with the civill dealing, converÅ¿ing, and practiÅ¿e of Citties, as many Kockneis, with the manuring of lands, and affayres of the countrey. Our EngliÅ¿h youth alÅ¿o, for most part, are brought vp, with too much feare and terrour: for eyther their Parents or Schoole-maÅ¿ters paÅ¿Å¿e the borders of mediocritie in this part: becauÅ¿e they eyther puniÅ¿h them too extreamely, or threaten them too Å¿everely: whereby th â¢ paÅ¿Å¿ions of puÅ¿illanimitie & feare Å¿pecially when any matter of moment is to be attempted, Å¿o distract their preÅ¿ent attention, that they cannot almost poÅ¿Å¿ibly vpon a Å¿udden conÅ¿ider the circumÅ¿tances, weigh the matter, and reÅ¿olve aright: for theÅ¿e reÅ¿training PaÅ¿Å¿ions witharaw a great part of their Å¿oules conÅ¿ideration. The Italians and Spaniards contrariwiÅ¿e, by bringing vp their children with more libertie, enlarge their hearts with boldneÅ¿Å¿e and audacitie, in Å¿uch Å¿ort, as vÅ¿ually you Å¿hall Å¿ee them at Å¿ixteene or Å¿eventeene yeeres of age, as bold and audacious as ours at thirtie: and contrariwiÅ¿e ours at Å¿ixeteene or Å¿eventeene, drooping with feare and timiditie, as if they were Å¿o many chickens drawne out of a Well.

The third cauÅ¿e is, a certaine naturall complexion and constitution of body, the which in very deed inclineth and bendeth them of hotter Countries more vnto craftineÅ¿Å¿e and warineÅ¿Å¿e, than them of colder Climates; This we may perceyve in Italy it Å¿elfe, where the L â¢ mbards are more Å¿imple than the Romanes, and theÅ¿e not Å¿o craftie as the Neapolitanes, not theÅ¿e comparable to the Sicilians. The like we finde in Spaine, where the Biskains are not Å¿o Å¿ubtle as the
Castilians, nor theÅ¿e Å¿o craftie as the AndaluÅ¿ians. Wherefore, as we proove in beaÅ¿ts, that Å¿ome, by their naturall inÅ¿tinct, are more wil â¢ e than others, as Foxes, Monckies, and Apes, Å¿o we finde in men, that Å¿ome Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿e others in aptnes to deceyve, and in craftineÅ¿Å¿e to circumvent. And in this we may confeÅ¿Å¿e that Spaniards and Italians goe before vs, for commonly they can better conceale their owne PaÅ¿Å¿ions, and diÅ¿cover others, than we. Our people, for most part, reveale and diÅ¿cloÅ¿e themÅ¿elves very familiarly and eaÅ¿ily; the Spaniard and Italian demurreth much, and Å¿elleth his Å¿ecrets and his friendÅ¿hip by drammes, you Å¿hall converÅ¿e very long with him, before you Å¿hall know what is in him: he will Å¿hew a countenance of friendÅ¿hip, although he intendeth revenge: he can trayne his purpoÅ¿es afarre off, to vndermine where hee pleaÅ¿eth: hee will praiÅ¿e where he Å¿piteth, and diÅ¿prayÅ¿e where he loveth for a further proiect: hee can obÅ¿erve his times better than we for his plots, and marke fitter occaÅ¿ions to effectuate his i â¢ tent: he can winne ground in a mans affection by Å¿ome Å¿mall converÅ¿ation, and after prevaile in what he liÅ¿t, when he hath got the advantage. In Å¿ine, he can diÅ¿Å¿emble better his owne paÅ¿Å¿ions, and vÅ¿e himÅ¿elfe therein more circumspectly, than we can doe. Wherefore I thought good to trie if a little direction would helpe â¢ ur Countriemen to counterpoiÅ¿e their native warineÅ¿Å¿e, and open the way, not to become craftie and deceitfull, which is vitious, but how to diÅ¿cover other mens paÅ¿Å¿ions, and how to behave our Å¿elves when Å¿uch affections extraordinarily poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e vs, the which is the chiefeÅ¿t poynt of prudence, and fittest meanâª to attayne vnto religious, civil, & gentlemanlike converÅ¿ation, which is vertuous. Whereunto especially this diÅ¿courÅ¿e of Affections aymeth, albeit for more compleate doctrine, I have handled almoÅ¿t all thoÅ¿e questions, which concerne the PaÅ¿Å¿ions in generall.

But for all this, I would not have any man to thinke that I am of opinion, that all Italians and Spaniards go beyond all EngliÅ¿hmen in Å¿ubtiltie and warineÅ¿Å¿e, for I have found divers of our Nation, whom I beleeve, neyther Italian, nor Spanyard c â¢ uld over-reach, in what negotiation Å¿oever: but onely I meane that for the moÅ¿t part, thoÅ¿e Nations Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿e ours in a certaine politique craftineÅ¿Å¿e, the which Nature firÅ¿t bred in them, Education per â¢ ited, Vertue amendeth,
and Art diÅ¿covereth. The which I have endevoured firÅ¿t of all (as I thinke) to draw into forme and method, according to the principles of Sciences, hoping that Å¿ome other will hereby take occaÅ¿ion, eyther to perfite mine, or to attempt a better; my deÅ¿ire is, the good of my Countrie; the effect, every mans prudent carriage; the laÅ¿t end, the glory of God; whereunto all our labours must tend, and all our actions be directect: and therefore, to him let theÅ¿e little Å¿parkes be conÅ¿ecrated, to kindle the â¢ ire in his moÅ¿t holy Temple.

div.p:

div.p: ALthough in the precedent Chapter wee touched, in part, the roote from whence did Å¿pring thoÅ¿e Å¿pinie braunches of briarie paÅ¿Å¿ions, that was the league and confederacie made with Å¿enÅ¿es; yet for more exact intelligence of their nature, or rather nativitie, I thought good to intreate of Å¿elfe-love the nurÅ¿e, mother, or rather Å¿tepdame of all inordinate affections.

Men and beaÅ¿tes with one appetite proÅ¿ecute the good they deÅ¿ire, and with an other they Å¿lie the evill they abhorre: as for example, with one appetite a man deÅ¿ires good wine, and with another deteÅ¿teth ill wine. div.head: How the PaÅ¿sions may be well directed and made profitable. CHAP. III.
div.p:
IT hath beene declared (I thinke) Å¿ufficiently, howe moÅ¿t men inordinately followe the vnbrideled appetite of their Å¿enÅ¿ual paÅ¿Å¿ions; yet no doubt but they may, by vertue be guided, and many good men Å¿o moderate and mortifie them, that they rather Å¿erve them for inÅ¿truments of vertue, than foments of vice, and as an occaÅ¿ion of victory, than a cauÅ¿e of foyle: For ChriÅ¿t our Saviour, in whom neyther Å¿inne, nor inordinate affection could fall, no doubt, was Å¿ubiect to theÅ¿e paÅ¿Å¿ions, Tristis est anima Matth. 26. Hereupon the PhiloÅ¿ophers and Fathers perceyving what commodities theÅ¿e paÅ¿Å¿ions afforded to a vertuous Å¿oule, with divers Å¿imilitudes declared their Å¿ervice: Some Å¿ay, they wereCic. 3. TuÅ¿c. Å¿parkes of fire apt to kindle vertue; others, that theyBaÅ¿il. hom. cont. ir â¢ Å¿c. BaÅ¿il. de virgi

By this DiÅ¿courÅ¿e may be gathered, that PaÅ¿Å¿ions, are not onely, not wholy to be extinguiÅ¿hed (as the Stoicks Å¿eemed to affirme) but Å¿ometimes to be moved, and Å¿tirred vp for the Å¿ervice of vertue, as learnedly Plutarch teacheth:Plutarchâª in libro de virt â¢ . a â¢â¢ r. for mercie and compaÅ¿Å¿ion will move vs often to pitty, as it did Iob, Quia ab infantia mea mecum crevit miÅ¿eratio, CompaÅ¿Å¿ion grewe with mee from my infancy, and it came with me out of my mothers wombe: therefore hee declareth what Å¿uccour hee gave to the poore, Iob 31. 18. div.head: An explication of the diviÅ¿ion of our Å¿enÅ¿itive appetite into ConcupiÅ¿cibile and IraÅ¿cibile, that is, Coveting and Invading. CHAP. V.
div.p: BEfore we do declare the number of paÅ¿Å¿ions that iÅ¿Å¿ue out of our Å¿oules, it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to premitte a common diviÅ¿ion of our Å¿enÅ¿uall appetite, found out by experience, allowed of by PhiloÅ¿ophers, andArist. lib. 1. Thom. 1 â¢ . q. 23. a. 1. & Å¿colastici ibidem. approved by Divines; that is, in concupiÅ¿cibile, which in EngliÅ¿h may be termed, Coveting, DeÅ¿iring, WiÅ¿hing; and, iraÅ¿cibile, that is, Anger, Invading, or Impugning, (for Å¿o I thinke it may better be called.) TheÅ¿e coveting and invading appetites, are not two faculties or powers of the Å¿oule, but one onely power and facultie, which hath two inclinations; as we have but one power or facultie of Å¿eeing, but two eyes, one power of hearing with two eares; Å¿o wee have one Å¿enÅ¿uall appetite, with two inclinations; the one to covet, the other to invade.

In the manner of explicating theÅ¿e two inclinations, both Divines and PhiloÅ¿ophers diÅ¿Å¿ent: yet two explications

there are, as more common, Å¿o more probable, and more conforme to reaÅ¿on. The firÅ¿t may bee declared after this manner: Wee Å¿ee by experience, that beaÅ¿tes Å¿ometimes have great facilitie to proÅ¿ecute, or obtayne thoÅ¿e obiects they covet; as for example, a horÅ¿e, the graÅ¿Å¿e which groweth in the paÅ¿ture where he feedeth, Å¿ometimes they have great difficulty; as for the Lyon to eate a Beare: Å¿ometimes they have great facility to eÅ¿chew that evill they hate; as a Woolfe or a Foxe to eÅ¿cape with his prey from a little Curre: other times we prove they have extreame difficultie to avoyde it; as a Bull to fly from a Lyon. Nowe the authors of this explication conclude, that the coveting appetite, inclineth onely to the obtayning of thoÅ¿e obiects which may eaÅ¿ily be come by, and to the eÅ¿chewing of thoÅ¿e that may eaÅ¿ily be eÅ¿caped: the invading appetite onely inclineth to the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ing of thoÅ¿e obiects which may hardly be gotten, and hardly eÅ¿caped.

This explication (in my opinion) as it is more common, Å¿o it is more vnture: for who doubteth but many both love and deÅ¿ire (which according to all Doctours are operations of the coveting appetite) divers things harde to be compaÅ¿Å¿ed; as, the two vnchaÅ¿te Iudges, the chaÅ¿te SuÅ¿anna: and in beaÅ¿ts we Å¿ee they often affect, love, and deÅ¿ire, that they hardly can purchaÅ¿e. It were folly, to thinke the foxe affected, loved, or deÅ¿ired not a gooÅ¿e, becauÅ¿e Å¿he were Å¿urely penned vp, hardly to be come by: or the wolfe deÅ¿ired not the Å¿heepe when Å¿he is defended with the Å¿hepheards dogges.

Many things more might be Å¿aide concerning this matter; as how the difference, of hardly, or eaÅ¿ily obtaining a thing can not cauÅ¿e Å¿uch diverÅ¿ities of inclinations; for Å¿o wee might Å¿ay our Å¿eeing might be divided; for Å¿ome things we Å¿ee with facilitie, others with difficulty; Å¿ome Å¿ounds wee heare eaÅ¿ily, others hardely. The other explication, and as eaÅ¿ie to be perceived as the precedent, is this. Wherfore, to the Bull hee hath imparted hornes, to the Boare

To this explication it Å¿eemeth that the names of IraÅ¿cibilis and ConcupiÅ¿cibilis more aptly agree, than to the other, becauÅ¿e heere onely IraÅ¿cibilis invadeth and impugneth, and not affecteth or deÅ¿ireth, as in the other. And thus much concerning this diviÅ¿ion. How many PaÅ¿Å¿ions there are coveting, and how many invading, in the next Chapter Å¿halbe declared.

The woolfe perceiving himÅ¿elfe weaker than he imagined, & his enemies Å¿tronger than he conceyved, falleth Å¿odainely into the paÅ¿Å¿ion of Feare, (as braggers doe, who vaunt much at the beginning,Feare. but quaile commonly in the midle of the fray) yet not abandoned of all hope of the victory; therefore he Å¿tirreth vp himÅ¿elfe, and proceedeth forward; but in

div.head: That there are PasÅ¿ions in the reaÅ¿onable Å¿oule. CHAP. VIII.
div.p:
NOw that we have determined how the PaÅ¿Å¿ions muÅ¿t dwell in an other Å¿oyle than the face; the order of methode requireth wee Å¿hould wade deeper into the Å¿oule, to view, if in the reaÅ¿onable part, we might finde out their habitation. be douted vpon, but that there are Å¿ome affections in the higheÅ¿t and chiefeÅ¿t part of the Å¿oule, not vnlike to the PaÅ¿Å¿ions of the Minde: for to God the Scriptures aÅ¿cribe love, hate, ire, zeale, who cannot be Å¿ubiect to any Å¿enÅ¿itive operations: And therefore, as in him they are perfections, and we are commaunded, and may imitate him in them, there is no reaÅ¿on why they Å¿hould be denyed vnto vs, in Å¿uch Å¿ort as they be perfite, and that is principally in the Will.

div.head: That the heart isc the peuliar place where that PaÅ¿sions allodge. CHAP. IX.
div.p:
NO PhiloÅ¿opher can deny, but that our PaÅ¿Å¿ions are certayne accidents and qualities, whoÅ¿e immediate Å¿ubiect, houÅ¿e, and lodging is the very facultie and power of the Å¿oule, becauÅ¿e all vitall operations (of which Å¿ort PaÅ¿Å¿ions are) challenge, by right, that the mother which hatched them, Å¿hould alÅ¿o Å¿uÅ¿tayne them, and harbour them in her owne houÅ¿e. But a queÅ¿tion may be demaunded, and not eaÅ¿ily reÅ¿olved, whether the faculty of our Å¿enÅ¿itive appetite hath allotted vnto it Å¿ome peculiar part of the body, where Å¿hee exerciÅ¿eth
her proper functions and operations: for, as wee Å¿ee by experience, the facultie of Å¿eeing, the power of hearing, the Å¿enÅ¿e of Å¿melling, taÅ¿ting, and touching, have aÅ¿Å¿igned vnto them divers corporall inÅ¿truments, habitations or Å¿eates, wherein they Å¿ee, heare, Å¿mell, taÅ¿te and touch; as eyes, eares, noÅ¿e, tongue, fleÅ¿h and Å¿inewes: nowe the queÅ¿tion propounded is thus to bee vnderÅ¿tood, whether may there be determined any Parte of the bodie, wherein peculiarly the paÅ¿Å¿ions of the minde are effected. To which queÅ¿tion I anÅ¿were, that the very Å¿eate of all PaÅ¿Å¿ions, is the hearte, both of men and beaÅ¿tes: divers reaÅ¿ons move me to this opinion. FirÅ¿t, the very common experience, men trie daily and hourely in themÅ¿elves, for who loveth extreamely, and feeleth not that paÅ¿Å¿ion to diÅ¿Å¿olve his hearte? who reioyceth, and proveth not his heart dilated? who is moyled with heavineÅ¿Å¿e, or plunged with payne, and perceiveth not his heart to bee coarcted? whom inflameth ire, and hath not heart-burning? By theÅ¿e experiences, wee proove in our hearts the working of PaÅ¿Å¿ions, and by the noyÅ¿e of their tumult, wee vnderÅ¿tande the woorke of their preÅ¿ence. The Å¿econd reaÅ¿on is, becauÅ¿e as our Å¿enÅ¿itive apprehenÅ¿ion hath her Å¿eate in the brayne (for we all proove, that in vnderÅ¿tanding, we eÅ¿pecially bend the force of our Å¿oule to the former part thereof) Å¿o the affections and paÅ¿Å¿ions, in proportionate manner, muÅ¿t have Å¿ome corporall organ and inÅ¿trument, and what more convenient than the heart? for, as the brayne fitteth beÅ¿t, for the Å¿oftneÅ¿Å¿e and moyÅ¿ture, to receyve the formes and prints of obiects for vnderÅ¿tanding; even Å¿o the heart endued with moÅ¿t fiery Å¿pirites, fitteth beÅ¿t for affecting. LaÅ¿tly, for what other reaÅ¿on, in feare and anger

I Å¿aw once in Genoa, a Bandite condemned to death, and going to Execution, to tremble Å¿o extraordinarily, that he needed two to Å¿upport him all the way, and for all that he Å¿hivered extreamely. Howbeit, I thinke this moÅ¿t true, and eÅ¿pecially in thoÅ¿e paÅ¿Å¿ions, which are about obiectes abÅ¿ent, as love, hatred, hope, flight, ire, and Å¿uch like; yet I cannot but confeÅ¿Å¿e, that when the obiectes are preÅ¿ent, and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed by Å¿enÅ¿e, then the paÅ¿Å¿ions inhabite, not onely the heart, but alÅ¿o are Å¿tirred vp in every part of the body, whereas any Å¿enÅ¿itive operation is exerciÅ¿ed; for if wee taÅ¿te delicate meates, Å¿mell muske, or heare muÅ¿icke, we perceyve, notonely that the heart is affected, but that alÅ¿o the paÅ¿Å¿ion of ioy delighteth thoÅ¿e partes of our Å¿ences: the like wee prove in payne and griefe, for which cauÅ¿e commonly wee Å¿ay, our teeth ake, our fingers, toes, or legges payne vs: Payne therefore, and PleaÅ¿ure, beeing PaÅ¿Å¿ions of the Minde, and evermore felt in that part of the bodie, where SenÅ¿e exerciÅ¿eth her operations: therefore, as touching is diÅ¿perÅ¿ed thorow the whole bodie, even Å¿o the PaÅ¿Å¿ions of pleaÅ¿ure and payne; for in everie parte, if it bee cheriÅ¿hed, it reioyceth, if be hurte, it payneth.

Yet Å¿uppoÅ¿ing the PaÅ¿Å¿ions principally reÅ¿ide in the hearte, as wee perceyve by the concourÅ¿e of humours thereunto, wee may demaund two curious queÅ¿tions. The former is, for what ende hath Nature given this alteration

To the which queÅ¿tion it may bee anÅ¿wered; FirÅ¿t,Why humors flocke to the heart in paÅ¿Å¿ions. that the humours concurre to helpe, diÅ¿poÅ¿e, and enable the heart to worke Å¿uch operations: for as we prove by experience, if a man Å¿leepe with open eyes, although his Å¿ight be marvellous excellent, yet he Å¿eeth nothing, becauÅ¿e in Å¿leepe, the purer Å¿pirites are recalled into the inner partes of the body, leaving the eyes deÅ¿titute of Å¿pirits, and abandoned of force, which preÅ¿ently in waking returne againe: euen Å¿o I conceive, the heart, prepared by nature to digeÅ¿t the blood Å¿ent from the liver, yet for divers reÅ¿pectes, not to have the temperature which all PaÅ¿Å¿ions require; for love will have heate, and Å¿adneÅ¿Å¿e colde, feare conÅ¿tringeth, and pleaÅ¿ure dilateth; the heart therefore which was to bee Å¿ubiect to Å¿uch diverÅ¿ities of PaÅ¿Å¿ions, by Nature was deprived of all Å¿uch contrary diÅ¿poÅ¿itions, as the PhiloÅ¿ophers Å¿ay, that Materia prima caret omni forma, quia omnes formas recipere debet. The other queÅ¿tion concerneth the efficient cauÅ¿e of theÅ¿e humours, what cauÅ¿eth their motions to the heart; they themÅ¿elves, as it were, flie vnto the heart? or the parte where they Å¿oiourned, Å¿endeth or expelleth them from her, and Å¿o for common refuge they runne to the heart? or finally, the heart draweth them vnto it? To this demaund I anÅ¿were, that (in mine opinion) the partes from whence theÅ¿e humours come, vÅ¿e their expulÅ¿ive vertue, Å¿ending the Å¿pirites choler, or blood, to Å¿erve the heart in Å¿uch neceÅ¿Å¿ity, as the hand lifteth vp it Å¿elfe to defend the head: howbeit, I doubt not, but the heart alÅ¿o affected a little with the paÅ¿Å¿ion, draweth more humors, & Å¿o encreaÅ¿eth. div.head: What Å¿ort of perÅ¿ons be most paÅ¿sionate. CHAP. X.
div.p:
OVt of the precedent Chapter we may gather, how that the heart is the Å¿eate of our paÅ¿Å¿ions, that Å¿pirites and humours concurre with them: here we may deduce a concluÅ¿ion moÅ¿t certayne and profitable, that according to the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the heart, humours, and body, divers Å¿ortes of perÅ¿ons be Å¿ubiect to divers Å¿ortes of paÅ¿Å¿ions, and the Å¿ame paÅ¿Å¿ion affecteth divers perÅ¿ons in divers manners: for, as we Å¿ee fire applyed to drie wood, to yron, to flaxe, and gunpowder, worketh divers wayes; for in wood it kindleth with Å¿ome difficulty, and with Å¿ome difficulty is quenched; but in flaxe Å¿oone it kindleth, and quencheth; in yron with great difficulty is it kindled, and with as great extinguiÅ¿hed; but in gunpowder it is kindled in a moment, and never can bee quenched till the powder be conÅ¿umed. But if the PaÅ¿Å¿ion of pleaÅ¿ure bee too vehement, queÅ¿tionleÅ¿Å¿e it cauÅ¿eth great infirmitie: for the heart being continually invironed with great abundance of Å¿pibecommeth too hote and inflamed, and conÅ¿equently engendereth much cholericke and burned blood: BeÅ¿ides, it dilateth and reÅ¿olveth the Å¿ubÅ¿tance of the heart too much, in Å¿uch Å¿ort, as the vertue and force thereof is greatly weakened. div.p: LIttle it would avayle the PhyÅ¿itian to Å¿peculate the cauÅ¿es and effects of infirmities, if he could not find foorth Å¿ome remedies: Å¿o Å¿mall profite the knowledge of our PaÅ¿Å¿ions would affoorde vs, if wee could not attaine vnto Å¿ome good meanes to direct them. div.p: AS the PhyÅ¿itian of the bodie ordaineth not onely medicines for his patients maladies, but alÅ¿o preÅ¿cribeth his diet, reÅ¿t, or exerciÅ¿e, Å¿leepe, or waking, what he ought to doe in the acceÅ¿sion of his agu â¢ , what in declination: euen Å¿o about the paÅ¿sions of the mind, which are certaine diÅ¿eaÅ¿es of the Å¿oule, like care and diligence muÅ¿t be vÅ¿ed. The Å¿econd point of prudence in paÅ¿sions, is, to conceale, as much as thou canÅ¿t, thy inclinations, o â¢ that paÅ¿Å¿ion thou knoweÅ¿t thy Å¿elfe moÅ¿t prone to follow; and this for two cauÅ¿es: firÅ¿t, for credite: Å¿econdarily, for many inconueniences that may thereby enÅ¿ue. div.p:
I Å¿ay not this, becauÅ¿e I would haue a man to doe one thing, and Å¿peake another, but that if he cannot but Å¿ometime of fragilitie Å¿lide, it may bee a good way to recall him againe, and not to fall Å¿o often, if he Å¿peake in diÅ¿praiÅ¿e of his owne fault; for men will be aÅ¿hamed to commit often, that they themÅ¿elues diÅ¿praiÅ¿e eagerly: and beÅ¿ides,

The third point may be, Not to vex and trouble thy Å¿elfe too much wheÌ a paÅ¿sion Å¿eizeth vpoÌ thee, but diuerting thy mind from it, and reÅ¿training thy conÅ¿ent as well as thou canÅ¿t from yeelding vnto it; and in Å¿hort time thou Å¿halt Å¿ee it vanniÅ¿h away: as wee prooue in daily temptations of ire, Å¿adneÅ¿Å¿e, loue, luÅ¿t, and Å¿uch like, which fall and conÅ¿ume away euen by themÅ¿elues: either becauÅ¿e the humour which was mooued, returneth to his former Å¿eat, or the impreÅ¿sion made in the imagination deminiÅ¿heth, or the attention of the Å¿oule deÅ¿tracted with other matters, faileth, or Å¿ome other paÅ¿sion expelleth it, or the deuill ceaÅ¿eth to tempt; either (I Å¿ay) all theÅ¿e, or moÅ¿t of them mittigat, conÅ¿ume, and wholy Å¿ubuert that paÅ¿sion which before Å¿o troubled vs, and Å¿eemed inÅ¿uperable.

The fourth poynt which ought principally to bee conÅ¿idered, and well waighed of thoÅ¿e whoÅ¿e paÅ¿sions are moÅ¿t vehement and inordinate, is this, that they which perceiue in themÅ¿elues Å¿uch diÅ¿ordered affections, ought firÅ¿t to know the root of them to bee Å¿elfe-loue, and the greater they find the boughs of their paÅ¿sions, the greater and deeper root let them bee aÅ¿Å¿ured lieth hidden vnder the bottome of their Å¿oule: for which cauÅ¿e Å¿uch men muÅ¿t perÅ¿uade themÅ¿elues to haue great difficultie to vertue, and extreame facilitie to vice: that as they loue pleaÅ¿ures of the body exceedingly, Å¿o they hate all that may hinder or oppoÅ¿e it Å¿elfe thereunto mightily. div.head: Pollicie in PaÅ¿sion. CHAP. IIII.
div.p: SInce men by nature are addicted to conuerÅ¿ation, and one dependeth vpon another, therefore it importeth much, to know how to Å¿econd or croÅ¿Å¿e other mens affections, how we may pleaÅ¿e or diÅ¿pleaÅ¿e them, make them our friends or foes. But becauÅ¿e this Å¿ubiect is infinite, I will only Å¿et downe certaine generall rules, whereby Å¿ome Å¿mall light may be had, how to liue and deale with men, to the intent, that loue, peace, and charitie be conÅ¿erued: for good ChriÅ¿tians ought not onely to procure an vnion with God, but alÅ¿o an amitie with men: and the world being greene in mallice, and withered in goodneÅ¿Å¿e, men more guided by paÅ¿sions, than ruled by reaÅ¿on, therefore the wiÅ¿er ought to prouide a Å¿alue proportionated to the Å¿ore, and meanes to preuent mallice; leaÅ¿t the children of darkeneÅ¿Å¿e in prudence Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿e the children of light, Å¿eeing our MaiÅ¿ter taught vs, how the cic of a doue adorneth beÅ¿t the Å¿erpents head.

The firÅ¿t rule may be this. All men (commonly) are pleaÅ¿ed with them, whom they Å¿ee affected with thoÅ¿e paÅ¿sions whereunto they are Å¿ubiect and inclined. This rule, both experience teacheth, and reaÅ¿on prooueth.

Alexander asked a pyrat that was taken and brought before him, How he durÅ¿t be Å¿o bold to infeÅ¿t the Å¿eas, and Å¿poyle the commerceries? he anÅ¿wered, That he played the pyrat but with one Å¿hip, and his MaieÅ¿tie with a huge nauie: the which Å¿aying Å¿o pleaÅ¿ed Alexander, that he pardoned his life, and graunted him libertie: Å¿o much could the Å¿imilitude of action tranÅ¿port the kings affection. The reaÅ¿on alÅ¿o of this rule may eaÅ¿ily be deliuered: becauÅ¿e all likelineÅ¿Å¿e cauÅ¿eth loue, and as euery one iudgeth, he doth the beÅ¿t, or at leaÅ¿t, approoueth well; euen Å¿o, he cannot diÅ¿prooue, but allow the Å¿ame in others. Hereupon followeth, that if thou wilt pleaÅ¿e thy maÅ¿ter or friend, thou muÅ¿t apparrell thy Å¿elfe with his affections, and loue where he loueth, and hate where he hateth: and vniuerÅ¿ally, to Å¿ooth other mens humours, plaineth the way to friendÅ¿hip and amitie: and as this meane foÅ¿tereth flatterie, if it be abuÅ¿ed, Å¿o it nouriÅ¿heth charitie, if it be well vÅ¿ed.

Out of this rule we may deduce the Å¿econd, which ought no leÅ¿Å¿e to be obÅ¿erued in conuerÅ¿ation than the former, That men commonly hate thoÅ¿e whome they know to be of contrarie paÅ¿sions: whereupon proceedeth that common Prouerbe, He that hateth whome I loue, how can he loue me? for as fire with fire doe neuer iarre, Å¿o fire and water can neuer agree. But in the next Booke, which Å¿hall be of Loue, I pretend to diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿e better this rule, becauÅ¿e, as Å¿imilitude cauÅ¿eth
loue, Å¿o diÅ¿similitude breedeth hatred. Therefore I omit to declare how Å¿ometimes likelineÅ¿Å¿e of paÅ¿sions engendreth contention, as we Å¿ay, Figulus figulum odit, one potter hateth another; and, Inter Å¿uperbos Å¿emper Å¿unt iurgia; among prowd men there are euer brawlings: for if Å¿imilitude of paÅ¿sions preiudicateth profit, then likelineÅ¿Å¿e of affections cauÅ¿eth diÅ¿Å¿ention.

The third rule. Be not too credulous to men in their owne cauÅ¿es: for as Å¿elfe-loue for the moÅ¿t part conceiues what appertaineth to our Å¿elues, with a greater Å¿hew of good and honeÅ¿tie, than indeed the thing carrieth with it; Å¿o, men mooued therewith, declare the matter as they conceiue it: for words Å¿pring from conceits, theÅ¿e are the tree, thoÅ¿e the flowers and leaues, which doe follow by iuÅ¿t proportion. Wherefore Alexander didPlutarch in Alexand â¢ o. wiÅ¿ely (as Plutarch recounteth) at the beginning of his raigne, by Å¿hutting one of his eares with his hand, when he heard any accuÅ¿er in criminall cauÅ¿es, thereby reÅ¿eruing (as he Å¿aid) audience for the defendant. ContrariwiÅ¿e, others mens matters, which hinder our profit or croÅ¿Å¿e our deÅ¿ignes, for the moÅ¿t part wee extenuat and abaÅ¿e. As in Italie once befell to a number of wiÅ¿e men, who heard an Oration, wherein they were all welnigh perÅ¿uaded: but the next day came vp another Oratour, and told a contrarie tale, and changed their minds, perÅ¿uading them all to the other part; for which cauÅ¿e we may adioyne the fourth rule.

The fourth rule. When you are induced to any thing by act, that is, by a tale well told in Rhetoricall manner, flexibilitie of voyce, geÅ¿tures, action, or other oratoricall perÅ¿uaÅ¿ions; good I hold it a while, for a man to Å¿uÅ¿pend
his iudgement, and not to permit his will follow too farre his motion, more artificiall than naturall, grounded vpon affection rather than reaÅ¿on: For that Å¿aying of IÅ¿ocrates ought well to be weighed, who being demaunded, what was Rhetorike; anÅ¿wered, to make great things little, and little, great: wherefore, after AeÅ¿chines wasEraÅ¿m. libr. 8. Ap â¢ ph. baniÅ¿hed from Athens, comming to Rhodes he made an Oration to the people in declaration of his cauÅ¿e of exile; they wondered at the Athenians, who had baniÅ¿hed him Å¿o vndeÅ¿eruedly: O quoth hee, you did not heare what DemoÅ¿thenes anÅ¿wered to my reaÅ¿ons; aÅ¿cribing wholy the cauÅ¿e of his exile, to the force and eloquence of DemoÅ¿thenes oration. By this example we Å¿ee proued, that commonly wiÅ¿e Rhetoricians affirme, that Rhetorike in an ill cauÅ¿e, is a two edged Å¿word in the hand of a furious man. Yet I would not by this condemne the facultie of eloquence, which I confeÅ¿Å¿e, if it be well vÅ¿ed, to be moÅ¿t profitable for the Church and common-weale: but becauÅ¿e at this preÅ¿ent it is Å¿ophiÅ¿ticated, by many, who couer Å¿tincking matters with fragrant flowers, and with a few Å¿ugred words temper the gall of their pernicious obiects; therefore euery wiÅ¿e man ought rather to examine the Orators reaÅ¿ons, than to follow his intent with a Å¿educed affection.

The fift rule. When men are poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed of a vehement paÅ¿sion, deale not with them by reprehenÅ¿ion or indignation, eÅ¿pecially in vehement manner, except it be Å¿ome perÅ¿on that is Å¿uperior, or in authoritie, but rather by a mild and Å¿oft Å¿ort of perÅ¿uaÅ¿ion. The Å¿ixt rule. No man ought to be employed to any office, act, or exerciÅ¿e, contrarie to his naturall paÅ¿sions and inclination. This rule concerneth all Å¿orts of Å¿uperiours
in the imployments of their Å¿ubiects, all parents for the education of their children, Å¿choolemaiÅ¿ters for the training vp of their Å¿chollers. The ground of this rule dependeth of long experience, and reaÅ¿on. ReaÅ¿on alÅ¿o prooueth the Å¿ame moÅ¿t manifeÅ¿tly: for three things are required of neceÅ¿sitie, to attaine to the perfection of any Å¿cience, cunning, or office; Nature, Art, & practiÅ¿e: Nature affordeth capacitie of wit, Å¿trength of bodie, and inclination of mind; the which inclination, if it be lacking, the Å¿ubiect Å¿triueth againÅ¿t the Å¿treame, and although by force and conÅ¿traint, nolens, volens, he follow Å¿uch a trade againÅ¿t his mind, he may peraduenture doe Å¿ome thing with great difficultie, the which labor if he had beÅ¿towed in that thing whereunto he was inclined, he would haue become a moÅ¿t excellent man.

This rule may not be vnderÅ¿tood Å¿o abÅ¿olutely, but that it admitteth Å¿ome limitation; for Å¿ome contrarie inclination or paÅ¿sion proceedeth not from defect of nature, or abilitie of mind, but from an ill and vitious Å¿elfewill,

The Å¿euenth rule Å¿erueth for great perÅ¿ons, who commonly neuer reÅ¿iÅ¿t their paÅ¿sions: therefore if a man vnderÅ¿tand once their inordinat affections, he may be very well aÅ¿Å¿ured to haue gained much ground in preuailing with them. Many more rules might be here deliuered, as that prowd men be pleaÅ¿ed with praiÅ¿es, honor, and account; diÅ¿contented with compariÅ¿ons, with commending their equals, in not yeelding them honour, in diÅ¿paraging their

div.head: THE FOVRTH BOOKE, Wherein is explaned, how PaÅ¿sions may be diÅ¿couered.

div.p:
AS by experience men may diÅ¿couer the inclinations of dogs and horÅ¿es, and other beaÅ¿tes, euen Å¿o by certaine Å¿ignes wiÅ¿e men may gather the inclinations whereunto other men are Å¿ubiect. I omit heere what paÅ¿sions euery countrie inclineth vnto: like wiÅ¿e, to what Å¿orte melancholy, Å¿anguine, flegmaticke and cholericke perÅ¿ons are addicted: for this was inÅ¿inuated Å¿ufficiently aboue: neither will I handle what Å¿ortes of men, paÅ¿Å¿ions moÅ¿t ouer-rule; for in the Å¿ame place this was Å¿ufficiently entreated, onely I will brieflie deliuer Å¿ome meanes, whereby in particular conuerÅ¿ation, euery one may diÅ¿couer his fellowes naturall inclinations, not by philoÅ¿ophicall demonÅ¿trations, but onely by naturall coniectures and probabilities, becauÅ¿e that wiÅ¿e men

For that we cannot enter into a mans heart, and view the paÅ¿sions or inclinations which there reÅ¿ide and lie hidden; therefore, as PhiloÅ¿ophers by effectes find out cauÅ¿es, by proprieties eÅ¿Å¿ences, by riuers fountaines, by boughs and floures the kore and rootes; euen Å¿o we muÅ¿t trace out paÅ¿sions and inclinations by Å¿ome effects and externall operations. And theÅ¿e be no more than two, words & deeds, Å¿peech and action: of which two, knowledge may be gathered of thoÅ¿e affections we carry in our minds: therfore firÅ¿t I will entreate of words, and then of deeds. Words repreÅ¿ent moÅ¿t exactly the very image of the mind and Å¿oule: wherefore Democritus called Å¿peech ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , theLacitius. image of life; for in wordes, as in a glaÅ¿Å¿e may be Å¿eene, a mans life and inclination. Wherefore Diogenes Idem lib. 6. wondred that men would not buy earthen pottes before they proued by the Å¿ound whether they were whole or broken, yet they would be contented to buy men by Å¿ight before they prooued their Å¿peech: Whereupon grew that old prouerbe, frequented of Socrates and approued of auntient PhiloÅ¿ophers, Loquere vt te videam,
Å¿peake that I may know thee: for paÅ¿sions Å¿o Å¿well within the Å¿oule, that they muÅ¿t needs haue Å¿ome vent, as Elihu Å¿aid of himÅ¿elf; Loe, my belly is like to new wine lackingIob. 32. a vent, the which breaketh new veÅ¿Å¿els. Sometimes I haue enquired of Å¿undry perÅ¿ons, what they thought of certaine mens inclinations; & I found that almoÅ¿t whatÅ¿oeuer they had noted in others, commonly to proceed from one Å¿ort of Å¿peech or other. Plainely you may perceiue, if mens words openly tend to their owne commendations, if they bragge or boaÅ¿t of their valor in wars, learning, qualities giuen by nature, or purchaÅ¿ed by labour, that they are of a proud diÅ¿poÅ¿ition: if they diÅ¿courÅ¿e laÅ¿ciuiouÅ¿ly or Å¿hameleÅ¿ly, queÅ¿tionleÅ¿Å¿e what the tongue Å¿peaketh, the heart affecteth: if men talke of meat and drinke, of â¢â¢â¢ ling and feaÅ¿ting, wiÅ¿hing for this meat, lamenting of that meat, Å¿uch perÅ¿ons, for moÅ¿t part, addict themÅ¿elues to gluttonie: if they rage with furious words, braull or wrangle, Å¿uch carie the conÅ¿cience of cholericke. div.head: Much talke.
div.p:

Hereupon came thoÅ¿e voices, Totum Å¿piritum Å¿uum profert Å¿tultus, The foole puttethPro. 29. 11. foorth all his Å¿pirit: but Sapiens differt, & reÅ¿eruat in poÅ¿terum, A wiÅ¿e man deferreth and reÅ¿erueth it for afterwardes. Wherefore fooles cary their hearts in their mouthes, wiÅ¿e men their mouthes in their hearts: for fooles Å¿peake, and then deliberat; but wiÅ¿emen firÅ¿t deliberat with reaÅ¿on, and then Å¿peake with circumÅ¿pection. Therefore Theocritus Å¿ayd, that Anaximines had a flood of wordsStob. Å¿erm. 34. and a drop of reaÅ¿on: For if you deÅ¿cant vpon Å¿ome long tale or diÅ¿courÅ¿e of theirs, you Å¿hall find them as void of matter, as prodigall in words. The cauÅ¿e hereof

div.head: Taciturnitie.
div.p: SOme contrariwiÅ¿e bee of too little Å¿peech, the which taciturnitie, although it repugneth to modeÅ¿tie, which Å¿tandeth betwixt theÅ¿e two extreames, yet commonly wiÅ¿e men account this extreame more Å¿ecure; for many words almoÅ¿t euer offend, but Å¿ilence very rarely: and therefore the PhiloÅ¿ophers Å¿ay, that he which will learne to Å¿peake, ought firÅ¿t to learne to hold his peace. This Å¿ilence may proceed Å¿ometimes of Å¿ottiÅ¿hneÅ¿Å¿e, becauÅ¿e a man knowes not how to reaÅ¿on, and Å¿o you Å¿ee clownes, or dull perÅ¿ons, not able to Å¿peake in a wiÅ¿e company. div.head: SlowneÅ¿Å¿e in Å¿peech.
div.p: SOme Å¿orts of men Å¿peake very Å¿lowly, and Å¿o leiÅ¿urely, that a cart of hay might paÅ¿Å¿e almoÅ¿t betwixt one word and another; the which manner of Å¿peech, is very lothÅ¿ome and tedious to their auditors, and eÅ¿pecially to Å¿ome quicke Å¿pirits intollerable. This lingering may proceed from Å¿ome impediment of the inÅ¿truments of Å¿peaking, a Å¿lowneÅ¿Å¿e of conceiuing, or a certaine vaine conceit that men haue of their owne wiÅ¿edome, the which they would diÅ¿till into other men, drop by drop, as water falleth from the Limbecke; for they thinke, if they doe vtter their words faÅ¿ter, they Å¿hould Å¿pill Å¿ome of their prudence. And indeed, among dull perÅ¿ons of Å¿low capacitie, I thinke it not farre amiÅ¿Å¿e; except they linger Å¿o long, that before their ending, they forget their beginning: but amongÅ¿t perÅ¿ons of good vnderÅ¿tanding, it argueth, either Å¿lowneÅ¿Å¿e of wit, or contempt of their vnderÅ¿tanding, and it cannot be but maruellous moleÅ¿tfull vnto them, like as if a man were extreamely thirÅ¿tie, and one Å¿hould giue him drinke by drops, which maner of deliuerie cannot but grieue him, although the drinke be neuer Å¿o excellent: euen Å¿o, men of quicke capacitie haue a Å¿harpe appetite, and would be preÅ¿ently Å¿atisfied, wherefore long lingering in Å¿peech hindereth greatly their naturall inclination and deÅ¿ire. Yet for all this I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿Å¿e, that in Å¿ome maieÅ¿ticall and very graue perÅ¿ons, whoÅ¿e prudence and wiÅ¿edome men much admire, few words pithie and leiÅ¿urely Å¿poken, argue both wiÅ¿edome, grauitie, and magnanimity, as afterwards in the paÅ¿sion of boldneÅ¿Å¿e Å¿hall be declared.

div.head: RaÅ¿hneÅ¿Å¿e in Å¿peech.
div.p:
AS Å¿ome men Å¿lide into Å¿louthfulneÅ¿Å¿e, and lingering too much in their words, Å¿o others fall into a greater extreamitie of raÅ¿hnes and precipitation. TheÅ¿eIob. 32. may well bee compared to new wine, that by venting burÅ¿teth the bottle? theÅ¿e bee fooliÅ¿h mouths whichProuer. 15. euer bluÅ¿ter foorth follies: theÅ¿e beare words in their mouths, as dogs arrowes Å¿hot in their thighs, the whichEccleÅ¿i. 19. Å¿o trouble, toÅ¿Å¿e and turmoile them, that they neuer can be quiet till they be drawne forth: euen Å¿o raÅ¿h men in Å¿peech, haue an arrow in their tongues, they neuer reÅ¿t till they haue vttered their minds. I haue Å¿eene Å¿ome of theÅ¿e men of very fine wits, but not Å¿etled iudgements, they excell in apprehenÅ¿ion, but faile in diÅ¿cretion; if they could Å¿tay themÅ¿elues, and moderat a little their naturall furie and haÅ¿tineÅ¿Å¿e, theÅ¿e would become very rare men: but for the moÅ¿t part, thoÅ¿e I dealt withall of this conÅ¿titution, I haue found to follow their owne inclination, and Å¿o with many good things they vtter many follies, yea many pernicious conceits, and often daungerous; becauÅ¿e, as they apprehend in euery matter, many things, and paÅ¿Å¿e beyond the common reach of ordinarie wits, Å¿o they without diÅ¿cretion, blab out good or bad, right or wrong, daungerous or not daungerous, and vtter what they conceiue, without iudgement, diÅ¿courÅ¿e, or reaÅ¿on: wherfore Å¿uch men may well bee called wittie, but not wiÅ¿e.
TheÅ¿e alÅ¿o eaÅ¿ily contemne others, they are very hote in what they apprehend, and Å¿elfe-loue adioyneth an account of their credit, and Å¿o rendereth (them obÅ¿tinat in their owne opinions. div.head: Affectation in Å¿peech.
div.p:
SOme haue a peculiar manner of parley, they Å¿peake in print, hunt after metaphors, coyne phraÅ¿es, and labour extreamely that their wordes may Å¿mell of Å¿ubtilitie, elegancie, and neat deliuerie, in Å¿uch affected Å¿ort, that for the moÅ¿t part, they leaue nothing behind them, but a Å¿ent of fooliÅ¿h affectation and verball pride. TheÅ¿e may well be compared to certaine birds which Å¿ing well, yet carie no fleÅ¿h vpon their backes, but are as leane as carion: they are not vnlike Å¿trumpets, who veile diÅ¿eaÅ¿ed carcaÅ¿Å¿es vnder rich attire. AmongÅ¿t a thouÅ¿and you Å¿hall Å¿carÅ¿e finde one ripe in iudgement, or Å¿ound in conceit: theÅ¿e men doe Å¿pend their time and Å¿tudies, to find out new phraÅ¿es, and that which they conceiued with great labour they vtter with extreame difficultie, they Å¿tammer often, and commit many diÅ¿cords, if they continue long in diÅ¿courÅ¿e; for the moÅ¿t part, their Epilogue conÅ¿orteth not with their Exordium. If they pen any thing to bee preÅ¿ented vnto the view of the world, you Å¿hal euer haue one new coined word or other which neuer Å¿aw light before it iÅ¿Å¿ued out of the mint of their
imagination, and it will beÅ¿eeme them as well as a peacoks fether a fooles cap. I heard once one of theÅ¿e worthy paroliÅ¿ts who had got by the end the word intricat; he comming among as wiÅ¿e men as him Å¿elfe, tould them, that Å¿uch a gentleman and he did beare moÅ¿t intricat loue one to another: he would haue Å¿aid intier. Another had got the word expoÅ¿tulat, and he imagined it was to require, and Å¿o he requeÅ¿ted a friend of his, to expoÅ¿tulat a certaine fauour at his lords hands in his behalfe. This affectation in Å¿peech proceedeth from a moÅ¿t vaine and notorious pride; the which no man (almoÅ¿t) will deny that conuerÅ¿eth with Å¿uch Å¿orts of perÅ¿ons: for if you demand any of their acquaintaunce, what opinion they hold of Å¿uch men; no other aunÅ¿were they can yeeld you, than that their words Å¿mell of preÅ¿umption and arrogance. I cannot moreouer excuÅ¿e moÅ¿t of theÅ¿e perÅ¿ons from certaine effeminat affections, becauÅ¿e Å¿uch Å¿peeches eÅ¿pecially were inuented to tickle women and gallants eares, that by alluring wordes they might win the credit of wittie, and Å¿o beguile the weaker mindes. TheÅ¿e inameld Å¿peakers, for the moÅ¿t part, condemne others as barbarous and ignorant, becauÅ¿e they frame not their Å¿peeches according to their humors: yea they will paÅ¿Å¿e further, and deÅ¿piÅ¿e all Authors who affect not in writing, that they frequent in prating. And I my Å¿elfe haue heard Å¿ome of them, as preÅ¿umtuouÅ¿ly as ignorantly, cenÅ¿ure moÅ¿t profound Doctours, yea and call them dunces and dolts, becauÅ¿e they either could not, or would not deliuer their conceits after the others cuÅ¿tomarie follies.

div.head: Scoffing Å¿peeches.
div.p: CErtaine men entertaine their company with Å¿coffing, nipping, gibing, and quipping: they thinke to haue wonne a great victorie, if in diÅ¿couering Å¿ome others defect, they can make the company laugh merrily: they wil Å¿eeme to make much of you, but the embracements of Å¿corpions follow Å¿tinging tailes. This Å¿coffing proceedeth from Å¿ome, of meere Å¿implicitie and fooliÅ¿hneÅ¿Å¿e, as common ieÅ¿ters, and therefore wiÅ¿e men weigh not Å¿uch follies: others ieÅ¿t for recreation without harme, with no other intention, but onely to be merry: but thoÅ¿e which eÅ¿pecially ought to be marked, and their company eÅ¿chewed, Å¿o quip and nip, that they principally pretend to diÅ¿credit, or Å¿hame thoÅ¿e perÅ¿ons at whom they ieÅ¿t: and this Å¿coffing manner is moÅ¿t malicious, and it proceedeth from pride and enuy, becauÅ¿e, either they would contemne others, or elÅ¿e make men not haue Å¿o good a conceit as they had before. And thus much concerning the maner of Å¿peech: As for the matter and obiect of talke, much might bee Å¿aid, but I will abridge the matter as briefly as I can.

div.head: DiÅ¿couerie of paÅ¿sions in the matter of talke.
div.p:
IF (as I Å¿ayd in the beginning of this chapter) men talke openly of Å¿uch Å¿ubiects as manifeÅ¿tly Å¿hew the exceÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿ome paÅ¿sion; no man can call in queÅ¿tion, but that Å¿uch men are addicted to Å¿uch paÅ¿sions: yet for that

div.head: DiÅ¿putation aboue the Å¿peakers capacitie.
div.p: SOme men will diÅ¿pute, or rather wrangle about matters exceeding their capacitie, as a Cobler of Chiualrie, a Tailor of Diuinitie, a Farmer of PhyÅ¿icke, a Merchant of Martiall affaires: and in fine, a number of men will meddle with thoÅ¿e matters, which either Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿e their capacitie, or at the leaÅ¿t, they vnderÅ¿tand not, for lacke of exerciÅ¿e, Å¿tudie, or practiÅ¿e. Sometimes I haue heard theÅ¿e batchellors hold talke Å¿o wilfully and obÅ¿tinatly, in matters of PhiloÅ¿ophie and Diuinitie, with Å¿uch groÅ¿Å¿e errours and abÅ¿urdities, that any wiÅ¿e man would either haue deÅ¿piÅ¿ed them for malapert and contentious, or elÅ¿e haue regiÅ¿tred them in the predicament of fooles.

And without all queÅ¿tion, this manner of Å¿peech, or wrangling, or let vs call it diÅ¿putation, cannot but proceed from great ignorance and arrogancie: for no wiÅ¿e man will contend in Å¿uch matters as he knoweth not. Whereupon came that Å¿aying of AriÅ¿totle; Euery man ought to be credited in his Art: and that other common prouerbe; Let not the cobler paÅ¿Å¿e his pantofle. For confirmation hereof, I will bring no better argument than euery mans common experience. There is no man (I thinke) but commonly he applieth himÅ¿elfe to one thing or other, this trade or that, Å¿ome Å¿tudie or art: as for example, a Printer, or a GoldÅ¿mith; if another man ignorant of his art, Å¿hould come and diÅ¿pute with him,
and condemne him, becauÅ¿e he vÅ¿eth Å¿uch and Å¿uch inÅ¿truments, this or that manner of working; he would laugh, and account him ignorant, as one that Å¿peaketh rather by chance than cunning, and hold him for more bold than wiÅ¿e: Å¿o queÅ¿tionleÅ¿Å¿e let theÅ¿e men aÅ¿Å¿ure themÅ¿elues, that if they diÅ¿pute of that they know not, they muÅ¿t be accounted preÅ¿umptuous, although they would not. Neither for this I diÅ¿allow Å¿ome good wits, to propound their difficulties which occurre in matters wherein they are not practiÅ¿ed; as for Lawyers in Diuinitie, PhyÅ¿itians in Law, and Diuines in PhyÅ¿icke, eÅ¿pecially to Å¿uch men as commonly are accounted learned in thoÅ¿e faculties; yet not to contend much, becauÅ¿e the further they paÅ¿Å¿e forward, the harder it will be for them to wind out againe. This rule admitteth Å¿ome exception; for I haue knowne Diuines very good PhyÅ¿itians, and Lawyers not altogether ignorant of Diuinitie, yea and PhyÅ¿itians practiÅ¿ed in them both; in Å¿uch caÅ¿es oftentimes thoÅ¿e of one profeÅ¿sion may excell thoÅ¿e of another: but this I hold for very rare, becauÅ¿e, he that employeth his wit to many Å¿ciences, commonly cannot be excellent in any. Wherefore men that be vnlearned, but diÅ¿creet, either will not moue any queÅ¿tions in Å¿uch matters as paÅ¿Å¿e beyond the Å¿phere of their capacities, or elÅ¿e in Å¿uch Å¿ort, as they rather intend to learne than to contend. But what Å¿hall a man doe when he falleth in companie with theÅ¿e wranglers, who neither are able to propound a difficultie; nor capable of a good and Å¿olid anÅ¿were? QueÅ¿tionleÅ¿Å¿e, it is a moÅ¿t moleÅ¿tfull life to liue in conuerÅ¿ation with Å¿uch idiots: yet the beÅ¿t courÅ¿e I can find with them is by Å¿ome palpable abÅ¿urditie to reduce
them to an open ignorance, as once befell a friend of mine, that talked with a vaine puritane (who vaunted he vnderÅ¿tood all the word of God:) well then quoth the other, I wil proue by Gods word you may not eat a blacke pudding; for we haue commaunded by the holy GhoÅ¿t and the ApoÅ¿tles in the 15. of the Actes, that we Å¿hould abÅ¿taine from eating of blood and Å¿trangled meates, now Å¿ir this precept is here Å¿et downe and commaunded to be kept, where haue you in all the Å¿cripture a warrant to tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿e it? The Å¿illie fellow was brought to Å¿uch an extremitie, as I thinke this argument was the beÅ¿t leÅ¿Å¿on that euer hee learned in his life, to curbe his owne preÅ¿umptuous ignorance.

div.head: Spirit of Contradiction.
div.p:
SOme men in Å¿peech are poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed with the Å¿pirit of Contradiction, and oppoÅ¿ition; for they will Å¿hew themÅ¿elues in company, able to controll, and gaineÅ¿ay other mens opinions: becauÅ¿e then they Å¿uppoÅ¿e the victorie gotten, when they crow ouer their companions. Such conuerÅ¿ation cannot but diÅ¿pleaÅ¿e the companie, thoÅ¿e perÅ¿ons being a burthen to their fellowes: for as euery man liketh his owne opinion, and deÅ¿ireth it Å¿hould be approoued, Å¿o all men miÅ¿like thoÅ¿e that contradict them, and hold for falÅ¿e that they deliuered for true. This contradictious Å¿peech lieth rooted in vaineglory, which Å¿preadeth her braunches in other mens minds, by deÅ¿piÅ¿ing that they approoue: and I thinke no better remedie can be vÅ¿ed, to amend Å¿uch a Å¿ort of people, than that a gentleman vÅ¿ed in Spaine to a gentlewoman
that did malapertly chide with him, Go your wayes (Å¿aid he) whether you haue right or wrong, I know you muÅ¿t haue the laÅ¿t word: and Å¿o I hold him wiÅ¿e, who can Å¿mooth vp his talke, and leaue Å¿uch quarreling and contentious Å¿pirits with the laÅ¿t word. Howbeit Å¿ometimes they are tamed with as froward fellowes as they are themÅ¿elues, who will as faÅ¿t contradict them as they contradicted others. I would alÅ¿o aduiÅ¿e this Å¿ort of contradictors to eÅ¿chew this defect, in regard of their owne credit, leÅ¿t accuÅ¿toming themÅ¿elues Å¿o oft to contradictions, they fall not into defence of many abÅ¿urdities, and Å¿o, for lacke of reaÅ¿on, and too much pertinacie, they leeÅ¿e their reputation. True it is, that among ciuile gentlemen and eleuated Å¿pirits, it will often chance that there will ariÅ¿e in conuerÅ¿ation, a certaine diuerÅ¿itie of opinion, and one muÅ¿t conÅ¿equently oppoÅ¿e his iudgement againÅ¿t another: Wherefore in Å¿uch a caÅ¿e, the oppoÅ¿er ought Å¿o to propound his reaÅ¿on, that he rather Å¿eemeth to deÅ¿ire to know the truth, than to triumph or inÅ¿ult ouer the other. The which he may the better performe, if hee vtter no word of contempt, if he be not very violent in vehemencie of voice or action, if he make good the others reaÅ¿on as farre as it will extend and bring the matter in concluÅ¿ion to a certaine reconciliation, or maner of Å¿peech, or Å¿ome Å¿uch qualification.

div.head: Speciall matters.
div.p:
TO diÅ¿couer a mans paÅ¿sions, much helpeth the maner of his Å¿peech, but I thinke, more the matter: for affection to any thing, if it bee vehement, muÅ¿t
breake forth. Men that be vnwiÅ¿e, commonly Å¿peake of friuolous & baÅ¿e matters; vitious men of one or other Å¿ort of vice; graue and wiÅ¿e men of Å¿erious & profound matters; and if they deÅ¿cend to Å¿ome lower Å¿ubiect, either they paÅ¿Å¿e it ouer very Å¿leightly, or therein touch Å¿ome point Å¿o wittily, that ex vnguibus, you may know him a lion. Some men talke much of themÅ¿elues, and as it were glancing at their owne commendation, and by little and little inÅ¿inuating their owne praiÅ¿es: or if they be commended, preÅ¿ently you Å¿hall Å¿ee them puft vp, and Å¿welling with a vaine pleaÅ¿ure and delight they haue conceiued of themÅ¿elues. But you will perhaps demaund of me by the way, What if a man Å¿hould commend me, or any thing appertaining vnto me, how ought I carry my Å¿elfe? If I accept the praiÅ¿e, I Å¿hall be accounted prowd; if I denie it, not to be Å¿o, I Å¿hall Å¿eeme to reprehend the praiÅ¿er, and condemn him for a liar or a flatterer. In Å¿uch a caÅ¿e, becauÅ¿e it occurreth daily, therefore good it were, to foreÅ¿ee and prouide an anÅ¿were preÅ¿ently. As AlfonÅ¿us king of Arragon anÅ¿wered an Orator, who had recited a long panigericall Oration of his praiÅ¿es; the king Å¿aidPanorm. lib. 1. de reb. geÅ¿t. AlfonÅ¿. to him: If that thou haÅ¿t Å¿aid conÅ¿enteth with truth, I thanke God for it; if not, I pray God graunt me grace that I may do it. Or elÅ¿e a wiÅ¿e man may Å¿ay, This praiÅ¿e I deÅ¿erue not, but your affection bettereth my actions: or, You by good nature and loue rather marke the little good I doe, than many defects therein committed: or, The Å¿pectacles of loue forceth you to cenÅ¿ure all my imperfections in good part. By this meanes you Å¿hall auoid a certaine vaine complacence in your owne doings, which offendeth much thoÅ¿e who are giuen to cenÅ¿ure
your actions, neither Å¿hall you rudely denie that, your friend of courteÅ¿ie affirmeth to be true.

div.head: Concealing and reuealing of Å¿ecrets.
div.p:
AS Å¿ome are Å¿o Å¿ecret, that they neuer will open any thing, almoÅ¿t, touching their own affaires; Å¿o others contrarily are Å¿o Å¿imple and blabbiÅ¿h, that they diÅ¿couer many of their conceits and matters, eÅ¿pecially concerning themÅ¿elues, to any man, almoÅ¿t at the firÅ¿t meeting. The former, commonly, are craftie, becauÅ¿e friendÅ¿hip requireth Å¿ome communication in Å¿ecrets, principally, if he be an eÅ¿peciall friend: yet this offence may well be tollerated in this miÅ¿chieuous world, and declining age, wherein profit is prized, and friendÅ¿hip deÅ¿piÅ¿ed; or at leaÅ¿t, men loue men more for their owne intereÅ¿t, than for vertue. Therefore, if thou be wiÅ¿e, truÅ¿t no man with that thou wouldeÅ¿t not haue publickely knowne, except he be a tried friend by long experience, yea, although he be thy friend: but vitious (if amongÅ¿t vitious perÅ¿ons there may be true friendÅ¿hip) aÅ¿Å¿ure thy Å¿elfe, that by opening to him thy mind, thou haÅ¿t halfe reuealed publickly thine owne Å¿ecret: for Å¿uch perÅ¿ons vÅ¿ually (if they bee young men, women, or of a very ill behauiour) be vnwiÅ¿e, blabbiÅ¿h, and moÅ¿t indiÅ¿creet in their Å¿peeches: beÅ¿ides, their loue being grounded in proper intereÅ¿t of pleaÅ¿ure and gaine, when theÅ¿e by chaunce or diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ure Å¿hall faile, then perÅ¿uade thy Å¿elfe, that all they know Å¿hall be reuealed, becauÅ¿e Å¿uch imprudent perÅ¿ons Å¿uppoÅ¿e that friendÅ¿hip once being diÅ¿Å¿olued, they are not bound any more, either to keepe Å¿ecret, or conÅ¿erue thy credit, and
Å¿o with one breath they blow all away. Wherfore I take it for a generall rule, that a man Å¿hold reÅ¿erue his Å¿ecrets of importance, either to himÅ¿elfe; or not to manifeÅ¿t theÌ, but only to honeÅ¿t & vertuous friends, leaÅ¿t it befall vnto him as happened to three Å¿tudents in a colledge where I liued Å¿ome yeers. It chanced a perÅ¿on of Å¿ome authoritie there, wrot to the Å¿uperior of the Colledge, a letter in diÅ¿coÌmendation of thoÅ¿e three Å¿tudents, all being meÌ in age, & good Scholers: this letter was Å¿howne by the Å¿uperior, to one of theÅ¿e three; yet becauÅ¿e it concerned not Å¿o much himÅ¿elfe, as the other two, he marked not well the contents thereof: the Å¿uperior gaue him Å¿trait order, that he Å¿hould in no caÅ¿e reueale it to the other two; he promiÅ¿ed, but performed it not, for preÅ¿ently he Å¿ignified to them both as much as he remembred: the one of them being touched Å¿omething to the quicke, preÅ¿ently deuiÅ¿ed a way how to come by the letter; and in fine, Å¿ecretly got a Å¿ight of it by a certaine deceit: he Å¿ignified to both the others the contents thereof, yet being Å¿harply prickt therwith, he fell into a chaÅ¿e with the perÅ¿on that had written the letter, and Å¿pared not to Å¿ignifie as much to the Å¿uperiour, who wondered how he came by the contents therof. After a little while, he which wrote the letter, came to the Colledge, and hearing how the perÅ¿on which chafed in that extreame manner, had gotten intelligence of the letter, (becauÅ¿e he was one of Å¿ome authoritie) he called him which firÅ¿t had reuealed the matter; who Å¿wore, that he neuer had vttered any Å¿uch words, but indeed that the other had by a Å¿tratageme gotten knowledge of the letter: then the perÅ¿on which wrote the letter called him that Å¿o wililie had found it foorth, and (although he had
Å¿worne, neuer to diÅ¿couer that the other had reuealed vnto him) preÅ¿ently he Å¿ignified all the matter vnto him, and he then againÅ¿t his promiÅ¿e, reuealed the Å¿umme vnto the perÅ¿on in authoritie, of the other; and thus all three broake their promiÅ¿es and their oathes, by reuealing of Å¿ecrets. Who that knew theÅ¿e men, would Å¿carcely haue beleeued, that any Å¿uch errours could by them haue bene committed; but by this experience (becauÅ¿e I was priuie to all their dealings) I got occaÅ¿ion, to Å¿uÅ¿pect falÅ¿hood in fellowÅ¿hip, to trie ere I truÅ¿ted; and finally, thought none more Å¿ecret than a man to himÅ¿elfe: for many hearts muÅ¿t haue many breathings; and few can conceale from their friends any Å¿ecret, when their friends reueale Å¿ome Å¿ecrets vnto them: and for that almoÅ¿t there liueth none Å¿o barren of friendÅ¿hip, but hee hath â¢â¢ me whom he truÅ¿teth, therefore hardly from him he can keepe Å¿ecret his owne heart, and what his friends reuealed vnto him.

div.head: Fained Å¿ecrets.
div.p:
YOu haue another Å¿ort of men, whome you may call, couÅ¿ining friends: for in Å¿hew they pretend friendÅ¿hip, but in effect, couÅ¿onage or flattery. They will come to you very Å¿eriouÅ¿ly, and deliuer a Å¿mooth tale in Å¿ecret, and coniure you, that in no caÅ¿e you Å¿hould reueale it: you promiÅ¿e and performe it, but your friend will not keepe that Å¿ecret, for he preÅ¿ently, when your backe is turned, will doe as much to another, the Å¿econd, and third; and Å¿o in fine, you Å¿hall haue that publique which was conceiued for Å¿ecret. This couÅ¿onage proceedeth from craftineÅ¿Å¿e, and diÅ¿Å¿embling friendÅ¿hip,
becauÅ¿e true friendÅ¿hip admitteth not many to communication in Å¿ecrets. It may alÅ¿o Å¿pring from a lauiÅ¿hing and too open a mind, for that indeed Å¿uch a perÅ¿on cannot conceale any thing in his heart from Å¿uch as doe Å¿eeme (in Å¿ome Å¿ort) to be addicted to his friendÅ¿hip. I haue knowne diuers great perÅ¿ons Å¿ubiect to this paÅ¿sion, but afterwards greatly croÅ¿Å¿ed thereby, for thoÅ¿e which once perceiued their humours, would neuer keepe cloÅ¿e any of their Å¿ecrets, and Å¿o by their pollicie they gained a reward like vnto liars, who though they Å¿ay truth are not beleeued; euen Å¿o, Å¿uch coyners of Å¿ecrets haue not their Å¿ecrets concealed, although they Å¿peake Å¿ecrets indeed: and one Å¿peaking of Å¿uch a perÅ¿on Å¿aid, he reuealed Å¿ecrets to the whole citie: as who Å¿hould Å¿ay, he Å¿old his Å¿ecrets publiquely and the wiÅ¿er Å¿ort would laugh in their Å¿leeues to heare him Å¿peake of Å¿ecrecie.

div.head: Sowers of diÅ¿Å¿ention.
div.p:
OTher men more maliciouÅ¿ly pretend friendÅ¿hip, and vÅ¿e Å¿trange dealing, either to make friends, or to breed diÅ¿Å¿ention: Å¿ome I haue found of Å¿uch an humour, that if they Å¿ee two conuerÅ¿e familiarly together and one to affect much another, they, vnder colour of amitie, will goe Å¿ecretly and reueale to the one of them, what they know, or heare, or that the other perÅ¿on his friend, Å¿ecretly Å¿poke or wrought to his diÅ¿credit; yea, diuers things they will relate, by their owne malice inuented, as by his friend diÅ¿couered: yet this they will not deliuer, but vnder an oath, that he Å¿hould not detect them to the other, whereby he of Å¿implicitie often reuealeth
all he knew of his friend, becauÅ¿e he beleeued his friend in very deed had betrayed him; whereas, for the moÅ¿t part, all was but a bait, forged to catch the Å¿eely Å¿imple Å¿oule. PreÅ¿ently after, they conuent the other, whom in Å¿ecret they tell all they had fiÅ¿hed out of his friend, in his diÅ¿praiÅ¿e, and Å¿o learne what they can of the other, charging him withall, in no caÅ¿e to manifeÅ¿t that he heard to the other. This Å¿tratageme I know many politique Å¿uperiors to haue frequented, and Å¿ome perÅ¿ons of great pollicie, but of moÅ¿t Å¿mall conÅ¿cience. BecauÅ¿e this wicked inuention proceedeth from a moÅ¿t malicious vncharitable, and enuious mind, which hateth the peace and concord of friends; it argueth alÅ¿o, a craftie politique wit, apt to Å¿ift out other mens actions: for he caÅ¿teth the poore man into an inextricable labyrinth: for forcing him to Å¿weare, he cannot examine whether his friend Å¿poke Å¿o ill of him, or no; leÅ¿t by the notice thereof he Å¿hould incur the crime of periurie: neither can he tollerat in his mind, that his friend Å¿hould Å¿o notoriouÅ¿ly abuÅ¿e him: wherefore he reÅ¿olueth himÅ¿elfe, either wholy to breake friendÅ¿hip, or at leaÅ¿t, not to vÅ¿e his friend Å¿o familiarly as before.

But how Å¿hall a man behaue himÅ¿elfe in Å¿uch a caÅ¿e? At the beginning wheÌ he telleth thee thy friends defects, excuÅ¿e them, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing the relatour to be ill informed, or that he miÅ¿tooke thy friend; for true friendÅ¿hip requireth, that a friend Å¿hould in all caÅ¿es (when euidently the concrary is not conuinced) defend the good name and eÅ¿timation of his friend; and thereby the Å¿ower of diÅ¿Å¿ention, Å¿halbe fruÅ¿trated of his intention.

Much more I could deliuer about this Å¿ubiect, but to
wiÅ¿e men it Å¿ufficeth to Å¿hew the way, & they will follow further than I can direct them: Å¿imple men, for as much as I can Å¿ee, muÅ¿t firÅ¿t trie & then truÅ¿t; for their rule lieth in experience and practiÅ¿e, more than in reading and Å¿peculation: becauÅ¿e their owne harmes, or their neighbours muÅ¿t Å¿choole them, for few are capable for practicall rules in vniuerÅ¿all, or at leaÅ¿t, they can not apply them to particular Å¿ubiects.

div.head: The diÅ¿couery of paÅ¿sions by externall actions. CHAP. II.
div.p:
THe internall conceits and affections of our minds, are not only expreÅ¿Å¿ed with words, but alÅ¿o declared with actions: as it appeareth in Comedies, where dumbe Å¿hewes often expreÅ¿Å¿e the whole matter, and by geÅ¿tures in dancing Å¿ome can giue to vnderÅ¿tand moÅ¿t mechanicall arts andCalius Rhodiginus lib. 5. c. 3. trades. The Rhetoritians likewiÅ¿e doe not content themÅ¿elues with the Å¿imple pronuntiation of their Orations, but alÅ¿o preÅ¿cribe many rules of action, the which they hold Å¿o much the better, how much more liuely it repreÅ¿enteth the conceits and affections of the mind, becauÅ¿e that both thorow the eares and the eyes of their auditors, they intend to imprint them in their Å¿oules the deeper: for indeed, words and actions Å¿pring from the Å¿ame root, that is, vnderÅ¿tanding and affections: and as leaues,
floures, and fruit declare the vertues of trees, Å¿o wordes and actions the qualities of minds. And as if the fruit or flowers be corrupted or vitious, we know the root muÅ¿t be infected: Å¿o if mens words or actions be diÅ¿conÅ¿orted, doubtleÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿oule cannot be well diÅ¿poÅ¿ed; for, as one Å¿aid well, A troubled Fountaine yeedeth vnpure water, & an infected Å¿oule, vitious actions, Plutarch in Moralib.

In many externall actions may be diÅ¿couered internal paÅ¿sions, as in playing, feaÅ¿ting, going, drinking, praiÅ¿ing, apparelling, conuerÅ¿ing, and writing. Somewhat I will note of each one in particular, remitting the reÅ¿t to the Readers diligent conÅ¿ideration: for to intreat of all, would exceed the Å¿phere of my proiect; & by diÅ¿courÅ¿ing of theÅ¿e few, wiÅ¿e men may paÅ¿Å¿e forward with the reÅ¿t.

div.head: I. DiÅ¿couery of PaÅ¿sions in play.
div.p: PLay pregnantly prooueth paÅ¿sions: for pride, choller, and couetouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, commonly wait vpon great gamÅ¿ters. Some, when they leeÅ¿e, are Å¿o inflamed with ire and choller, that you would take them rather for bedlams than reaÅ¿onable creatures; they Å¿weare, curÅ¿e, and crie; euery word Å¿poken againÅ¿t them, Å¿ufficeth to picke a quarrell, or deÅ¿erueth (in their iudgements) a buffet. This inordinat behauiour argueth, firÅ¿t blindneÅ¿Å¿e and folly; for if you aske them with whom they are offended, they themÅ¿elues cannot Å¿hew you: not with themÅ¿elues, for that were madneÅ¿Å¿e; with the dice? and that were as great follie; with fortune? but that is nothing: therefore wee muÅ¿t conclude, that they (in Å¿uch fits) are fooles, and brawle with the very aire.

BeÅ¿ides, theÅ¿e chafing players, play not for recreation, but for gaine; they vÅ¿e company, more for couetouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e than for honeÅ¿ty; becauÅ¿e, they would not fret Å¿o much at their looÅ¿ing, if they affected not too much the winning: and in very deed they abuÅ¿e the nature of play, the which was giuen as a medicine to recreat mens afflicted minds: but theÅ¿e, prepoÅ¿terouÅ¿ly rather afflict the mind, & make it a poiÅ¿on: for they are Å¿o anxious in themÅ¿elues, and many feare Å¿o much to leeÅ¿e, that as Å¿oone as a little Å¿umme is drawne from them, you could hardely diÅ¿cerne whether the heart were more vexed with griefe, or the tongue defiled with oathes. I would truely that in euery common-weale princes Å¿hould puniÅ¿h all perÅ¿ons, that play greater games than their abilitie doth affoord; for I take Å¿uch Å¿orts of exerciÅ¿es to be moÅ¿t pernicious, for many reaÅ¿ons, to the Å¿tate; and I thinke the puniÅ¿hment meeteÅ¿t for them, Å¿hould be, that it were lawfull to beg them for Wardes, and giue them tutors, becauÅ¿e they lacke diÅ¿cretion to vÅ¿e their money. Rarely you find great players, that carry not proud minds, who if they win, they vaunt of gaine, if they leeÅ¿e, they doe brag of loÅ¿Å¿e: as a Spaniard in a brauado, thought he deÅ¿erued great commendation, becauÅ¿e hee was able one night to leeÅ¿e ten thouÅ¿and crownes at dice.

Others, in play Å¿hew likewiÅ¿e their paÅ¿sions, albeit they exceed not much the lawfull quantity requiÅ¿it to recreation, yet they carry a Å¿ecret pride, & vehement deÅ¿ire to win, becauÅ¿e they would not be inferior to others, euen Å¿o much as in play: wherefore, if any caÅ¿t come croÅ¿Å¿e vnto them, they will chafe as much for a penny, as another man for a pound. TheÅ¿e men queÅ¿tionleÅ¿Å¿e haue
Å¿ome little Å¿hrubs of pride and vanitie: for although the moÅ¿t pleaÅ¿ure in play conÅ¿iÅ¿teth in the victorie; yet to affect it too much, to wrangle, to chafe, to fret therefore, argueth an vnmortified affection, the which wiÅ¿e men ought to ouercome, becauÅ¿e Å¿uch paÅ¿sions are in very deed childiÅ¿h, and vndecent for graue perÅ¿ons.

Some men wholly conÅ¿ecrat themÅ¿elues to play, either you Å¿hall haue them at dice, cards, bowles, or Å¿ome Å¿uch game. TheÅ¿e, as vnprofitable members, deÅ¿erue to be cut from the bodie of euery good commonweale; for what wiÅ¿e man would tollerat a Å¿eruant in his houÅ¿e, which did nothing but eat, drinke, and play? They weigh little their Å¿oules, for if they did, doubtleÅ¿Å¿e they would Å¿pend better their time, becauÅ¿e it Å¿eemeth that they were rather created to play than to labour, addicting themÅ¿elues more to the pleaÅ¿ures of the bodie, than to the Å¿eruice of the Å¿oule, and moÅ¿t like bruit beaÅ¿ts follow the inordinat appetite of Å¿ence, more than the right rule of reaÅ¿on. TheÅ¿e actions proceed from a Å¿oule altogether depriued of vertue, and repleniÅ¿hed with vice, which better may be named brutiÅ¿h than reaÅ¿onable.

By this it appeareth, that thoÅ¿e that are addicted much to play, are Å¿enÅ¿uall, chafers in play are couetous, great gameÅ¿ters are fooliÅ¿h: the firÅ¿t getteth baÅ¿e pleaÅ¿ure, the Å¿econd gaineth great vexation, the laÅ¿t winneth pouertie: all Å¿eeme to loue themÅ¿elues; but doubtleÅ¿Å¿e, all hate their Å¿oules: I Å¿ay, they Å¿eeme to loue their bodies, but indeed they are moÅ¿t cruell enemies, for they are butchers which feed their calues for Å¿laughter; they are fiÅ¿hers, who caÅ¿t a golden hooke with a little alluring bait, to catch the fiÅ¿hes for the frying pan; they cheriÅ¿h their bodies with a
moment of pleaÅ¿ure, after to be puniÅ¿hed with an eternitie of paine. To play too earneÅ¿tly doth argue pride, couetouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, choller, or follie: to play too careleÅ¿ly, troubleth good coÌpany, & carieth Å¿ome Å¿parke of contempt: not to play at all, proceedeth either from extreame holineÅ¿Å¿e, grauitie, hypocriÅ¿ie, or inÅ¿enÅ¿ibilitie. Therefore in game vÅ¿e the golden meane, play not too much, nor too Å¿eriouÅ¿ly, nor to great game; take it as medicines, vÅ¿e Å¿ome attention, play for a trifle.

div.head: II. DiÅ¿couery of PaÅ¿sions in feaÅ¿ting.
div.p: GReat feaÅ¿ters and gullars cannot but be Å¿ubiect to many vices: FirÅ¿t, leacherie Å¿pringeth from gluttonie, becauÅ¿e, as their Å¿eats are neere by Å¿cituation, Å¿o they are Å¿ubordinat in operation; gluttonie is the forechamber of luÅ¿t, and luÅ¿t the inner roume of gluttonie; therefore all diÅ¿orders and tumults raiÅ¿ed in the former, preÅ¿ently are perceiued in the latter. The Å¿uperfluities of gluttony are noriÅ¿hments to leacherie, and great repaÅ¿ts Å¿wim vnder the froath of luÅ¿t: wherefore, not without reaÅ¿on Å¿aid Å¿ome, Sine Cerere & Baccho friget Venus: LuÅ¿t faileth where good cheere wanteth: and (almoÅ¿t) it is impoÅ¿sible that he Å¿hould be continent in mind, that accuÅ¿tometh to gormandize his belly. But I know Å¿ome will demaund, In what conÅ¿iÅ¿teth this gluttonie? whereunto I anÅ¿were, That gluttons thinke, talke, and earneÅ¿tly procure to haue great cheere, daintie diÅ¿hes; they eate more than nature requireth; at the table they will haue the beÅ¿t; and in fine, the eaÅ¿ieÅ¿t rule to perceiue them, is to note their care and anxity to fare daintily, to feaÅ¿t often, and therein to delight much.

Hereupon followeth a rule to bee marked, That Å¿uch men, in the heat of their gulling feaÅ¿ts ouerÅ¿hoot themÅ¿elues extreamely, and the exceÅ¿Å¿e of feeding venteth foorth in Å¿uperfluous Å¿peaking: for the wit being a little diÅ¿tempered with fumes, the tongue breaketh forth into indiÅ¿creet words, and often they vtter Å¿o much in that fooliÅ¿h vaine, that afterwardes coÅ¿teth them both griefe and paine: whereas a diÅ¿creet man, obÅ¿eruing them in Å¿uch humours, might get great aduantage, and reape no Å¿mall commoditie.

Many more crooked braunches Å¿pring from this Å¿temme of gluttony and feaÅ¿ting: for hardly at Å¿uch times they can conceale Å¿ecrets: vpon a full paunch commonly waiteth Å¿louthfulneÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿leepe, and eaÅ¿e, and except his Å¿tocke be good, it will Å¿oone be Å¿pent: beÅ¿ides, great fare breedeth many diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, for as abundance of doung ingendreth abundance of vermine; Å¿o, abundance of meat, abundance of filthie thoughts, and pernicious maladies:

div.head: III. DiÅ¿couery of PaÅ¿sions in drinking.
div.p: SVperfluitie of meat, cauÅ¿eth dulneÅ¿Å¿e of mind; but Å¿uperfluitie of drinke, bereaueth men of wit: for as I haue Å¿eene in Å¿ome hoÅ¿pitals of mad men, Å¿undry differences of mandneÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿o I haue found not vnlike humours of drunkenneÅ¿Å¿e; for Å¿ome are merry mad, Å¿ome melancholy mad, Å¿ome furious, others fainting: Å¿o in drunkenneÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿ome you Å¿hall haue merry drunke, others dead drunke, others raging, others caÅ¿ting.
