I heare in high Germany, that parents will Å¿ee men drunke before they marry their daughters vnto them, becauÅ¿e they wil know to what kind of drunkenneÅ¿Å¿e they are Å¿ubiect; and according to the good or ill qualities (if a drunkard can haue good qualities) they iudge him conuenient or not for their marriages. There is (almoÅ¿t) no paÅ¿sion in theÅ¿e men that you Å¿hall not diÅ¿couer in their drunkenneÅ¿Å¿e, becauÅ¿e
that reaÅ¿on being buried in them, they rule themÅ¿elues wholly by inordinat appetites and Å¿enÅ¿itiue apprehenÅ¿ion, which cannot conceale at Å¿uch time, the verie dregges of their paÅ¿sions. And therefore to conclude, drunkards haue little feare of God, they hurt their bodies, they dull their wits, they clog the Å¿oule with vices, they Å¿pend their Å¿ubÅ¿tance, they Å¿poyle the commonweale, one deuouring more than would Å¿uffice for three or foure: and finally, they are neuer to be truÅ¿ted with any Å¿ecret matter; for I hold him for a Å¿imple man, that cannot Å¿ound a drunkards Å¿oule, euen to the bottome.

div.head: IIII. DiÅ¿couery of PaÅ¿sions in geÅ¿ture.
div.p: THis Å¿ubiect is very ample, and would require almoÅ¿t a whole booke: but I will onely touch Å¿uperficially Å¿ome chiefe points. The geÅ¿tures of the body may bee reduced vnto theÅ¿e heads; motions of the eyes, pronuntiation, managing of the hands and bodie, manner of going.

div.head: In Voice.
div.p:
THere came a man to DemoÅ¿thenes, deÅ¿iring his helpe to defend his cauÅ¿e, and told him how one had beaten him: DemoÅ¿thenes anÅ¿wered him again, Å¿aying, I doe not beleeue this to bee true thou telleÅ¿tPlutar â¢ . in De â¢ oÅ¿t. me, for Å¿urely the other did neuer beat thee. The plaintife then thruÅ¿ting out his voice aloud, Å¿aid; What, hath he not beaten me? Yes indeed, quoth DemoÅ¿thenes, I beleeue it now, for I heare the voice of a man that was beaten indeed: whereby we may Å¿ee how he coniectured, by the lowdneÅ¿Å¿e of his voice, the iuÅ¿t indignation of his mind: For indeed, men in ire and wrath, Å¿hew, by their pronuntiation, the flame which lodgeth in their breaÅ¿ts. Wherefore Cato gaue counÅ¿ell, That
Å¿ouldiers in the warre Å¿hould terrifie their enemies with vehement voices and cries. A Å¿mall trembling voice proceedeth from feare, and Å¿uch an one commonly hauePlutarc. in Ro. div.head: Managing of the hands and bodie.
div.p: IN diÅ¿courÅ¿ing, to vÅ¿e no geÅ¿tures, argueth Å¿lowneÅ¿Å¿e; too much geÅ¿ticulation commeth of lightneÅ¿Å¿e: mediocritie proceedeth from wiÅ¿edome and grauitie; and if it be not too quicke, it noteth magnanimitie. Some men you haue alwaies fidling about their garments, either prying for moaths, binding of garters, pulling vp their Å¿tockings, that Å¿carcely when they goe to bed they are apparelled: this proceedeth from a childiÅ¿h mind, and void of conceits: and if you deale with men in companie, it alÅ¿o Å¿heweth a little contempt of thoÅ¿e with whom you conuerÅ¿e, becauÅ¿e it Å¿eemeth you little attend what they Å¿ay.

Others Å¿carce thinke they doe pray, except they wrie and wreÅ¿t their neckes; which, either commeth of hypocriÅ¿ie, Å¿uperÅ¿tition, or fooliÅ¿hneÅ¿Å¿e. Some gaze vpon themÅ¿elues, how proper bodies they beare, how neat and proportioned legs Å¿uÅ¿taine them, and in fine, almoÅ¿t
are inamored of themÅ¿elues; Å¿o they are pleaÅ¿ed with their owne perÅ¿ons: but this geÅ¿ture diÅ¿pleaÅ¿eth commonly, and proceedeth from pride and vaine complacence in going.

To walke maieÅ¿tically (that is, by extending thy legs foorth, and drawing thy body backe, with a Å¿low and Å¿tately motion) in all mens iudgment vÅ¿ually iÅ¿Å¿ueth from a proud mind, and therefore deÅ¿erueth diÅ¿praiÅ¿e, except in a Prince, a Generall of an army, or a Souldier in in the Å¿ight of his enemies; becauÅ¿e this manner of paÅ¿ing Å¿heweth an oÅ¿tentation of the mind, and that a man would Å¿et foorth himÅ¿elfe aboue others: which Å¿ort of vaunting, few can tollerat, becauÅ¿e they can hardly Å¿uffer, that men Å¿hould Å¿o farre inhance themÅ¿elues aboue others.

To trip, to iet, or any Å¿uch light paÅ¿e, commeth of lightneÅ¿Å¿e and pride, becauÅ¿e Å¿uch perÅ¿ons Å¿eeme to take delight, that others Å¿hould behold their Å¿ingular Å¿ort of going. FaÅ¿t going becommeth not graue men; for as philoÅ¿ophers hold, a Å¿low paÅ¿e Å¿heweth a magnanimous mind: and if neceÅ¿sitie requireth not, a light paÅ¿e argueth a light mind, becauÅ¿e thereby wee know how the Å¿pirits are not Å¿ufficiently tempered & brideled; whereupon followeth lightneÅ¿Å¿e of bodie and inconÅ¿tancie of mind.

div.head: V. DiÅ¿couerie of paÅ¿Å¿ion in PrayÅ¿ing.
div.p:
I (AlmoÅ¿t) neuer knew man diÅ¿contented to heare his owne praiÅ¿e, and few there be who can tollerat to be diÅ¿praiÅ¿ed: wiÅ¿e men doubt with AntiÅ¿thenes the PhiloÅ¿opher, that when wicked men praiÅ¿e them, they

It were wiÅ¿edome, not to praiÅ¿e any man exceedingly, but eÅ¿pecially before a multitude, for that good men change their eÅ¿tates. Wherefore it were wiÅ¿edome to vÅ¿e Å¿uperlatiues very rarely, and Å¿ay, Å¿uch a man is vertuous, but not moÅ¿t vertuous. So therefore praiÅ¿e good men, that thou reÅ¿erue a caueat for their errours. BeÅ¿ides, commonly proud men cannot abide their equalls Å¿hould much be commended, for the praiÅ¿e of the one obÅ¿cureth the glory of the other; & as I haue obÅ¿erued by experience, they either openly, or Å¿ecretly will Å¿eeke to diÅ¿grace him and diÅ¿couer Å¿ome defects, the which impeacheth more his credit than your coÌmendation aduanceth his reputation, becauÅ¿e that men be more prone to conceiue ill than good of others: therefore one Å¿aid wiÅ¿ely, Calumniare Å¿emper aliquid haeret, Å¿peake euill, for euer Å¿ome thing remaineth: that is, either a full perÅ¿uaÅ¿ion, or a Å¿iniÅ¿ter Å¿uÅ¿pition. Some men, when they haue done any thing worthy of praiÅ¿e, they either like hennes goe cackling in regard of their new layd egge, that is, blazing their owne works; or indeuour by Å¿ecret inÅ¿inuation, or groÅ¿Å¿e induÅ¿trie, that others Å¿hould commend them: as the Italian Poet did, who hauing made an Epigram which much pleaÅ¿ed his fancy, Å¿hewed it to Å¿ome of his friends, prayÅ¿ing it about the Skies: they preÅ¿ently demaunded, who was the Author? then he for very Å¿hame of pride, would not tell them that it was his,
but with a fliering countenaunce well gaue them to vnderÅ¿tand, that the verÅ¿es and the laughter were cooÅ¿in germaines, and both iÅ¿Å¿ued from the Å¿ame proud hart. In thoÅ¿e Nations I haue dealt with all this Å¿ecret paÅ¿Å¿ion: an itching humour of affecting praiÅ¿e, eÅ¿pecially raigneth among the Spaniards; for if a man will not publiquely praiÅ¿e their doings, they hold him to make little account of them, to be vnciuile, or perhaps their enemy. â¢â¢ this we may gather a very good rule to diÅ¿couer paÅ¿sion â¢
â¢ or if that you Å¿ee one much to pleaÅ¿e himÅ¿elfe with others praiÅ¿es, and (as it were) to feed vpon the wind of mens words; doubt not but Å¿elfe-loue and vanitie poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e the beÅ¿t tenement of his heart: And this you may know, if the perÅ¿on praiÅ¿ed, either openly confeÅ¿Å¿e it, vnderhand inÅ¿inuat it, or as it were with a Å¿miling countenance Å¿ilently approue it: for as gold is tried by fire, Å¿o a man by the mouth of a prayÅ¿er.

div.head: VI. DiÅ¿couerie of PaÅ¿Å¿ions in Apparrell.
div.p:
EXtraordinary apparrell of the bodie, declareth well the apparrell of the mind: for Å¿ome you haue Å¿o inconÅ¿tant in their at tire, that the varietie of their garments pregnantly proueth the Å¿ickleneÅ¿Å¿e of their heads: for they are not much vnlike to Stage-players, who adorne themÅ¿elues gloriouÅ¿ly like Gentlemen, then like clownes, after, as women, then like fooles, becauÅ¿e the faÅ¿hion of their garments maketh them reÅ¿emble theÅ¿e perÅ¿ons. And truely the Frenchmen and EngliÅ¿hmen, of all Nations, are (not without Å¿ome good cauÅ¿e) noted
and condemned of this lightneÅ¿Å¿e, the one for inuenting, the other for imitating; in other things we thinke them our inferiors, & herein we make them our maiÅ¿ters: and Å¿ome I haue heard very contemptuouÅ¿ly Å¿ay, That Å¿carcely a new forme of breeches appeared in the French kings kitchin, but they were preÅ¿ently tranÅ¿lated ouer into the Court of England. This newfangleneÅ¿Å¿e proceedeth from an inconÅ¿tant mind, a proud heart, and an effeminate affection. AuguÅ¿tus CaeÅ¿ar had alwayes in hatred, rich and gorgeous garments, becauÅ¿e he Å¿ayd they wereSueton. banners blaÅ¿ing our pride, and neaÅ¿ts to breed leachery. Wherefore Saint Gregory plainly prooueth that gloriousGregon in hom. attire proceedeth from pride, becauÅ¿e that men or women will not vÅ¿e their gallant garments, but in Å¿uch places where they may be Å¿eene: and he that could Å¿ound the hearts of many vaine perÅ¿ons, Å¿hould find the root of this gay apparrell an vnchaÅ¿t heart, and an arrogant mind. As Å¿ome offend in too much niceneÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿o others in too much carleÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e and Å¿louenry, not regarding in what manner and faÅ¿hion they Å¿hew themÅ¿elues abroad: which, in Å¿ome, may come of a certaine contempt they haue of themÅ¿elues, of pride, and the world; but this maner of mortification (howbeit I will not condemne all thoÅ¿e that vÅ¿e it, of hypocriÅ¿ie) yet I hold, that for the moÅ¿t part, it carrieth a Å¿mell thereof: I know a man
that Å¿ome hold very godly and religious, yet when hee was to appeare before a prince, he would alwayes haue the bareÅ¿t cloke hee could get, to the intent the king might account him godly, mortified, and a deÅ¿piÅ¿er of the world: and perhaps AntiÅ¿thenes went not farre awry when he Å¿aw Socrates in a torne coat, Å¿hewing a hole thereof to the people; Loe, quoth he, thorow this I Å¿ee Socrates vanitie: for mortification Å¿tandeth well with modeÅ¿tie and decent attire. Much might be Å¿aid here concerning the newfangle madneÅ¿Å¿e, or laÅ¿ciuious pride, or vaine Å¿uperfluities, of womens pointing, painting, adorning, and fantaÅ¿ticall diÅ¿guiÅ¿ing: but I muÅ¿t Å¿ay this vice in them to be remedileÅ¿Å¿e, becauÅ¿e it hath bene in euery age, euer cried againÅ¿t, and neuer amended: and for my part, I am halfe perÅ¿uaded this Å¿inne carrieth with it a finall impenitence, which women neuer intend to change as long as they liue, but to carry it to the graue: for euery one will excuÅ¿e her Å¿elfe, becauÅ¿e Å¿hee onely followeth the faÅ¿hion and cuÅ¿tome: if others would change, Å¿hee would bee contented to immitate; but if you aske another, Å¿he will Å¿ay as much, but none will begin, and Å¿o their pride muÅ¿t be endleÅ¿Å¿e, and therefore incorrigible in this world, to be puniÅ¿hed in another.

div.head: VII. DiÅ¿couerie of paÅ¿sion in ConuerÅ¿ation.
div.p: COmmonly by conuerÅ¿ation you may diÅ¿couer mens affections, for he that frequenteth good companie, for moÅ¿t part is honeÅ¿t; and he that vÅ¿eth ill company, can hardly be vertuous: who euer Å¿aw a man very conuerÅ¿ant with drunkards, to be Å¿ober? who knew an indiuiduall companion of harlots, chaÅ¿t? I am not ignorant that a phyÅ¿itian may conuerÅ¿e with Å¿ick men without infection, and cure them: but many phyÅ¿itians will Å¿carce aduenture to deale with plaguie patients, leÅ¿t in curing others, they kill themÅ¿elues. Vices are plagues, and vicious perÅ¿ons infected: therfore it were good to deale with them a farre off, and not in Å¿uch places where their vices are Å¿trongeÅ¿t, as with gl â¢â¢ ters in banquets, drunkards in tauernes, riotous perÅ¿ons in Å¿uÅ¿pected houÅ¿es, leÅ¿t thou diÅ¿credit thy Å¿elfe, and be infected with the others vice: as a gentleman I knew, who walking by Thames, and Å¿eeing his boy in watring his gelding to paÅ¿Å¿e too farre, Å¿o that he was in danger of drowning, preÅ¿ently leapt in, thinking by Å¿wimming to deliuer them both, the boy caught hold of his maÅ¿ters foot, and puld him ouer head and eares, and Å¿o they were drowned all three for companie.

Who talks much before his betters, cannot but be condemned of arrogancie, contempt, and lacke of prudence. To conuerÅ¿e much with inferiours, as it breedeth contempt Å¿o it argueth a baÅ¿e mind, as though his conceits were no better than Å¿uch perÅ¿ons deÅ¿erued to be acquainted
withall. Except inferiors be indued with Å¿ome excellentContinuus aÅ¿pectus minus verendos magnes homines ipÅ¿a Å¿atietate facit. Liu. lib. 35. Et maieÅ¿tati maior ex longinquo reuerentia Taci. 1. An. qualities: wherefore noblemen or princes may conferre with inferiors or Å¿ubiects, if they be learned, militarie men, or wiÅ¿e polititians: wherefore, to keepe, or win grauitie, great prudence it were, neuer to talke with thoÅ¿e that be farre beneath vs in eÅ¿tate, and condition, but of Å¿erious matters: for Å¿uch men, by Å¿porting, wil account better of themÅ¿elues, and in time, deÅ¿piÅ¿e their Å¿uperiors; for familiaritie aÅ¿pireth to equalitie.

To enter into companie, although of equals, without Å¿ome ciuile courteÅ¿ie, or affable Å¿peech, commeth of ruÅ¿ticitie: to depart without taking of leaue, or Å¿alutation, argueth inciuilitie and contempt.

Too much familiaritie, with Å¿coffing, and gibing, proceeds from lightneÅ¿Å¿e, and rarely continueth without diÅ¿Å¿ention; becauÅ¿e that men are not at all times apt to receiue ieÅ¿ts: wherefore friendly ieÅ¿ts euer carry with them a certaine reÅ¿pect: this fault I find more common among Frenchmen, and EngliÅ¿h, than any other Nation. Some, in conuerÅ¿ation can diÅ¿courÅ¿e well for Å¿ome two or three dayes, but after that time their oyle is Å¿pent, they thruÅ¿t out all they haue of a Å¿uddaine, & after become very barren. div.head: VIII. DiÅ¿couerie of PaÅ¿sions in Writing.
div.p: WHo of purpoÅ¿e writeth obÅ¿curely, peruetteth the naturall communication of men; becauÅ¿e we write to declare our minds, and he that affecteth obÅ¿curity, Å¿eemeth, not to be willing that men Å¿hould conceiue his meaning. The holy Scriptures I alwayes except, which for many cauÅ¿es admit Å¿ome obÅ¿curitie. But for men, in their writing to follow Å¿uch a phraÅ¿e as hardly you can vnderÅ¿tand what they Å¿ay, cannot but proceed either from confuÅ¿ed vnderÅ¿tanding, becauÅ¿e a cleere conceit breedeth perÅ¿picuous deliuerie, or affectation of learning, which Å¿pringeth from pride; for I haue knowne moÅ¿t excellent men endeuour to Å¿peake and write the greateÅ¿t myÅ¿teries of our faith, in Å¿uch plaine maner, that very deepe diuinitie Å¿eemed very eaÅ¿ie. And I truely am of opinion, that he is the greateÅ¿t Diuine, and moÅ¿t profitable to the common-weale, which can make his learning to be beÅ¿t conceiued.

To vÅ¿e many Metaphors, Poetical phraÅ¿es in proÅ¿e, or incke-pot tearmes, Å¿melleth of affectation, and argueth a proud childiÅ¿h wit. To be peremptorie and Å¿ingular in opinions, to cenÅ¿ure ill, or condemne raÅ¿hly, without rendring Å¿ome Å¿ound and Å¿trong reaÅ¿on, for the moÅ¿t part proceedeth from Å¿ingular Å¿elfe loue, and a defectuous iudgement.

Some will condemne others for writing, becauÅ¿e they thinke there bee Bookes written more than Å¿ufficient: This cenÅ¿ure commeth, either from a Å¿luggiÅ¿h mind, or enuious, to Å¿ee others good endeuours commended; or
elÅ¿e from groÅ¿Å¿e ignorance, becauÅ¿e they neither know the nature of mens wits, nor the limits of humane vnderderÅ¿tanding: for if we Å¿ee the art of Å¿ayling with the CompaÅ¿Å¿e, the exerciÅ¿e of Artillerie, the manner of Printing, of late yeeres inuented, augmented, and perfitted; Why may not diuers Sciences already inuented, be increaÅ¿ed with new conceits, amplified with better DemonÅ¿trations, explaned in a more perÅ¿picuous manner, deliuered in a more ordinat method?

Contrary to theÅ¿e be certaine itching Å¿pirits, who put euery toy in print, they prize their owne workes exceedingly, and cenÅ¿ure others iniuriouÅ¿ly: theÅ¿e may well be compared to certaine wild vines, which bring forth many grapes, but neuer mature them: Å¿ome doe it for Å¿ame, and Å¿ome for gaine, and both without diÅ¿cretion, and againÅ¿t their owne credit. Therefore great wiÅ¿edome it were, to write Å¿omething diÅ¿creetly, that mens labours may, not onely profit themÅ¿elues, but alÅ¿o be deriued to others: for what doe we account good in it Å¿elfe, if it bee not communicatiue of goodneÅ¿Å¿e, to others? div.head: Order of PaÅ¿sions in generation or production.
div.p:
2 DIuines and PhiloÅ¿ophers commonly affirme, that all other paÅ¿sions acknowledge loue to be their fountaine, root, and mother; the reaÅ¿on I take to be for that al paÅ¿sions, either proÅ¿ecut Å¿ome good, or flie Å¿ome euill: thoÅ¿e which flie euill, as hatred, feare, Å¿adneÅ¿Å¿e, preÅ¿uppoÅ¿e the loue of Å¿ome good, the which that euill depriueth, as for example; who hateth death, but he which loueth life? who feareth aduerÅ¿ity, but he that loueth proÅ¿peritie? who is penÅ¿iue in his Å¿ickeneÅ¿Å¿e, but hee that loueth health? Loue then goeth before all thoÅ¿e paÅ¿sions which eÅ¿chew euil. AmongÅ¿t them which proÅ¿ecute good, loue likewiÅ¿e proceedeth, for the paÅ¿Å¿ions of our minds are not vnlike the motions of our bodies: For as things naturally mooued, haue an appetite or naturall inclination to the place whereunto they are mooued, mooue, and reÅ¿t therein; as the water which runneth Å¿o faÅ¿t downe the mountaines, hath an inÅ¿tinct of Nature to be vnited with the Sea, for which cauÅ¿e we Å¿ee brookes and flouds runne with Å¿uch a maine force to attaine thereunto, when they come to the Sea; preÅ¿ently they ioyne in friendÅ¿hip, and liue in concord, ioyning together as louing friends: euen Å¿o, we Å¿ee in beaÅ¿tes, the horÅ¿e loueth water when hee is thirÅ¿tie, and therefore by deÅ¿ire hee Å¿eeketh out Å¿ome riuer or fountaine; when he hath found it, he drinketh, pleaÅ¿eth himÅ¿elf therewith, and Å¿o reÅ¿teth contented. paÅ¿sion of griefe and ire inuade him: and Å¿o per accidens, in many other caÅ¿es, the foreÅ¿aid order may be broken.

div.head: Order of PaÅ¿sions in Intention.
div.p: 3 IF we diÅ¿courÅ¿e of thoÅ¿e PaÅ¿sions which reÅ¿ide in the Å¿enÅ¿itiue appetite, it euer firÅ¿t intendeth pleaÅ¿ure and delight, becauÅ¿e therewith Nature is moÅ¿t contented: from which intention followeth loue, hatred, ire, and Å¿uch like: this paÅ¿sion beaÅ¿ts moÅ¿t deÅ¿ire, yea children and Å¿enÅ¿uall perÅ¿ons wholy Å¿eeke after, and direct almoÅ¿t their whole actions thereunto, for pleaÅ¿ure is the poleÅ¿tare of all inordinat paÅ¿sions: and if a man examine himÅ¿elfe thorowly, he Å¿hal find that riches, glorie, health, learning, and what elÅ¿e moÅ¿t men deÅ¿ire, aime commonly at pleaÅ¿ure and delight of the body, becauÅ¿e theÅ¿e pleaÅ¿ures are eaÅ¿ily perceiued, and in them the Å¿oule Å¿eemeth to purchaÅ¿e a quiet reÅ¿t. div.head: Order of PaÅ¿sions in Dignitie.
div.p: 4 IF we compare our paÅ¿sions in dignitie or perfection, then thoÅ¿e wherewith we proÅ¿ecute good, are more excellent than thoÅ¿e wherewith wee eÅ¿teeme ill: and among theÅ¿e, loue holdeth the principall place, and as a queene in dignitie preceadeth the reÅ¿t: becauÅ¿e that loue vniteth the louer in affection with the obiect beloued: loue is the root of other affections, loue finally maketh vs friends with God and man.

div.p: THe water which wee find in euery Citie, by three wayes paÅ¿Å¿eth into it; either by fountaines or Å¿prings, by riuers or conduits, or by raine, Å¿now, or haleÅ¿tones: that is, Å¿ome water ariÅ¿eth, Å¿ome paÅ¿Å¿eth, Å¿ome deÅ¿cendeth: Å¿o in like manner our imaginations or internall Å¿ences, and conÅ¿equently our PaÅ¿sions, by three wayes are mooued; by humours ariÅ¿ing in our bodies, by externall Å¿ences and Å¿ecret paÅ¿Å¿age of Å¿enÅ¿uall obiects, by the deÅ¿cent or commaundement of reaÅ¿on. div.head: How Å¿ences mooue PaÅ¿sions, and Å¿pecially our Å¿ight Â§. 1.
div.p: GEnerally they loue and affect vanitie, for what is that they loue or can loue in the world, and worldly, but vanitie? that is, neither before it is had, contenteth, nor when it is poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed, fully pleaÅ¿eth, nor after it is departed, Å¿atiÅ¿fieth: For Å¿uch things are vaine, which vaniÅ¿h away, and are reÅ¿olued into nothing. The third maner more Å¿enÅ¿ible & palpable is this, that the very Å¿ound it Å¿elfe, which according to the beÅ¿t philoÅ¿ophie, is nothing elÅ¿e but a certaine artificiall Å¿haking, criÅ¿pling, or tickling of the ayre (like as we Å¿ee in the water criÅ¿pled, when it is calme, and a Å¿weet gale of wind ruffleth it a little; or when wee caÅ¿t a Å¿tone into a calme water, we may perceiue diuers warbling naturall circles) which paÅ¿Å¿eth thorow the eares, and by them vnto the heart, and there beateth and tickleth it in Å¿uch Å¿ort, as it is moued with Å¿emblable paÅ¿sions. For as the heart is moÅ¿t delicat and Å¿enÅ¿atiue, Å¿o it perceiueth the leaÅ¿t motions and impreÅ¿sions that may be: and it Å¿eemeth that muÅ¿icke in thoÅ¿e celles playeth with the vitall and animate Å¿pirits, the onely inÅ¿truments and Å¿purres of paÅ¿sions. The laÅ¿t and beÅ¿t manner I take to be, that as all other Å¿ences haue an admirable multiplicitie of obiects which delight them, Å¿o hath the eare: and as it is impoÅ¿sible to expound the varietie of delights, or diÅ¿guÅ¿tes, which we perceiue by them, and receiue in them (for who can diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h the delights wee take in eating fiÅ¿h, fleÅ¿h, fruit, Å¿o many thouÅ¿and Å¿auces, and commixtions of Å¿pices with fiÅ¿h, fleÅ¿h, and fruit?) Å¿o in muÅ¿icke, diuers conÅ¿orts Å¿tirre vp in the heart, diuers Å¿orts of ioyes, and diuers Å¿orts of Å¿adneÅ¿Å¿e or paine: the which as men are affected, may be diuerÅ¿ly applied: Let a good and a Godly man heare muÅ¿icke, and hee will lift vp his heart to heauen: let a bad man heare the Å¿ame, and hee will conuert it to luÅ¿t: Let a Å¿ouldiour heare a trumpet or a drum, and his bloud will boile and bend to battell; let a clowne heare the Å¿ame, and he will fall a dauncing; let the common people heare the like, and they wil fall a gazing, or laughing, and many neuer regard them, eÅ¿pecially if they bee accuÅ¿tomed to heare them. True it is, that one kind of muÅ¿icke may be more apt to one paÅ¿sion than another, as alÅ¿o one obiect of Å¿ight is more proportionat to Å¿tirre vp loue, hatred, or pleaÅ¿ure, or Å¿adneÅ¿Å¿e, than another. a Å¿ound iudgement, but what occurred vnto me in this queÅ¿tion I haue Å¿et downe, leauing the choiÅ¿e and approbation, or Å¿enÅ¿ure, to them that Å¿ee more in it than I doe.

ORators, whoÅ¿e proiect is perÅ¿uaÅ¿ion, haue two principal parts where with they endeuour to compaÅ¿Å¿e their purpoÅ¿e, OrnatÃ¨ dicere, & concinnÃ¨ agere, To Å¿peake eloquenly, and to act aptly: That conÅ¿iÅ¿teth Å¿pecially vpon proper words and Å¿ound reaÅ¿ons, this in a certaine moderation of the voice and qualifications of geÅ¿tures. And the philoÅ¿ophicall and morall reaÅ¿on hereof is moÅ¿t apert, becauÅ¿e with them it is a common receiued axiome, Nemo dat quod non habet: a man cannot communicateAuguÅ¿t. lib. 2. de lib. arb. cap. 17. that he wanteth, Quod in cauÅ¿is vniuocis eÅ¿t Å¿emper verum. NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e let them be aÅ¿Å¿ured one day to Å¿mart for it, in that they prepared and diÅ¿poÅ¿ed not themÅ¿elues to be fit inÅ¿truments for Å¿uch eminent functions. And for this cauÅ¿e the paÅ¿sion which is in our breÅ¿t muÅ¿t be the fountaine and origen of all externall actions; and as the internall affection is more vehement, Å¿o the externall perÅ¿uaÅ¿ion will be more potent: for the paÅ¿sion in the perÅ¿uader Å¿eemeth to mee, to reÅ¿emble the wind a trumpeter bloweth in at one end of the trumpet, and in what manner it proceedeth from him, Å¿o it iÅ¿Å¿ueth forth at the other end, and commeth to our eares; euen Å¿o the paÅ¿sion proceedeth from the heart, and is blowne about the bodie, face, eies, hands, voice, and Å¿o by geÅ¿tures paÅ¿Å¿eth into our eyes, and by Å¿ounds into our eares: and as it is qualified, Å¿o it worketh in vs. But I know Å¿ome would vnderÅ¿tand the cauÅ¿e, why a good reaÅ¿on in the preacher or oratour will not Å¿uffice to perÅ¿uade the people, vnleÅ¿Å¿e they themÅ¿elues be affected with the like paÅ¿sion? Wherefore DemoÅ¿thenes, as of all Oratours the prince for action, Å¿o he defined, that the principall part ofCicero in Brut. an Oration was action; the Å¿econd, the Å¿ame; the third, no

For action is either a certaine viÅ¿ible eloquence, or an eloquence of the bodie, or a comely grace in deliuering conceits, or an externall image of an internall mind, or a Å¿haddow of affections, or three Å¿prings which flow from one fountaine, called vox, vultus, vita, voice, countenance, life, that is, the affection poureth forth it Å¿elfe by all meanes poÅ¿sible, to diÅ¿couer vnto the preÅ¿ent beholders and auditors, how the actor is affected, and what affection Å¿uch a caÅ¿e and cauÅ¿e requireth in them: by mouth he telleth his mind; in countenance he Å¿peaketh with a Å¿ilent voice to the eyes; with all the vniuerÅ¿all life and bodie he Å¿eemeth to Å¿ay, Thus we moue, becauÅ¿e by the paÅ¿sion thus we are mooued, and as it hath wrought in vs Å¿o it ought to worke in you. Action then vniuerÅ¿ally is a naturall or artificiall moderation, qualification, modification, or compoÅ¿ition of the voice, countenance, and geÅ¿ture of bodie proceeding from Å¿ome paÅ¿sion, and apt to Å¿tirre vp the like: for it Å¿eemeth, that the Å¿oule playeth vpon theÅ¿e three parts, as a muÅ¿ition vpon three Å¿trings, and according to his Å¿triking Å¿o they Å¿ound.

A number of precepts Oratours preÅ¿cribe about theÅ¿e three parts, and labour extreamly by art to perfit and accompliÅ¿h the rude indigeÅ¿ted motions of nature: to
them therefore I will leaue the minching of this matter in particularities, and onely Å¿et downe certaine generalities.

FirÅ¿t, although art Å¿upplie the defects of nature, yet if a man haue not a good naturall habilitie, it is impoÅ¿sible by art to come to any perfection for this manner of motion. The reaÅ¿on hereof is manifeÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e as in muÅ¿ick, he that wanteth a tunable voice by nature, although he otherwiÅ¿e excell in the art of muÅ¿icke, yet it were leÅ¿Å¿e paine to heare him Å¿ay than Å¿ing. Secondly, he that will act well, muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿sitie Å¿tir vp firÅ¿t that affect in himÅ¿elfe, he intendeth to imprint in the hearts of his hearers; and the more vehement the paÅ¿sion is, the more excellent action is like to enÅ¿ue. Secondly in feare and Å¿adneÅ¿Å¿e, that they render not the actions vile and abiect: for then the paÅ¿sion will rather be occaÅ¿ion or cauÅ¿e to Å¿mother and kill them, than to reuiue and animate them.

Thirdly, euery part of action ought to expreÅ¿Å¿e the mind as grauely, as prudently, as Å¿olidly as may be: The reaÅ¿on is, becauÅ¿e he that publickely intendeth to perÅ¿uade, muÅ¿t be eÅ¿teemed a wiÅ¿e, and a good man; wiÅ¿edome muÅ¿t make the auditors beleeue he erreth not vpon ignorance, honeÅ¿tie muÅ¿t induce them to thinke hee will not lie: therefore all his actions ought to be prudent and graue: for if they be any way light or raÅ¿h, then preÅ¿ently he will be Å¿uÅ¿pected, either not to haue premeditated maturely his matter, or not to regard what he Å¿aith, or not to be Å¿o Å¿etled in vertue and knowledge as Å¿uch an important matter requireth: for leuitie and raÅ¿hneÅ¿Å¿e, at leaÅ¿t argue imprudence, inconÅ¿ideration, immortification, and precipitation, which all are capitall enemies to deepe conÅ¿ulation, Å¿pecially in matters which concerne perÅ¿uaÅ¿ion to vertue, or diÅ¿Å¿uaÅ¿ion from vice, exhortation to goodneÅ¿Å¿e, or dehortation from ilneÅ¿Å¿e. As feare participateth of hatred and Å¿adneÅ¿Å¿e, in deteÅ¿ting an imminent euill, and Å¿orrowing leaÅ¿t it befall, and therefore requireth like voyce, countenance and action; Å¿o, becauÅ¿e little it would auaile to explaine the perill and daunger thereof, except we encouraged and Å¿tirred vp our hearers to attempt meanes, to proÅ¿ecute labours, to enterpriÅ¿e difficulties, to encounter and reÅ¿iÅ¿t the euill: therefore according to Saint Pauls inÅ¿truction, we muÅ¿t arguere, obÅ¿ecrare, increpare, accuÅ¿e, requeÅ¿t, reprehend. Then tend thy turne, when neighbors houÅ¿en burne. div.head: The 8. Motive to Loue, which is Honestie.
div.p: I Take not HoneÅ¿tie in this place, as an obiect of temperance, oppoÅ¿ite to diÅ¿honeÅ¿tie or impuritie: but as a generall obiect to all Vertue, called by Divines and moral PhiloÅ¿ophers, Honestum contra-diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed to vtile & delectabile, to profitable and delightfull: for in the former Å¿enÅ¿e a man may be honeÅ¿t, and yet an vniuÅ¿t perÅ¿on, an VÅ¿urer, a Murtherer &c. For divers men mayVide Arist â¢ . 9. moral. Nic â¢ . cap. 4. & Pl â¢â¢â¢ in Hipparcho. be chaÅ¿te of body, who are otherwiÅ¿e addicted to Å¿undry vices in Soule. But here I take HoneÅ¿tie, as comprehending all actions, or good inclinations, or vertuous habilities, tending and bending the Soule to follow ReaÅ¿on, and enabling a man to live like a man: and Å¿o HoneÅ¿tie includeth all Vertues, and excludeth all vices.

Wee proove by daylie experience, that if a man bee beautifull and perÅ¿onable, he is amiable: if valour bee therewith conioyned, hee is more eÅ¿teemed: if Prudence be added, hee is more accounted: if Vertue bee annexed, he is highly reputed: if Religion adorne all theÅ¿e precedent partes, he is admired: if eminent Sanctitie glorifie them, he is adored. For although every excellencie carrieth with it a Å¿weete grace and motive to amabilitie, yet Å¿uch is the luÅ¿tre and glorie of Vertue and HoneÅ¿tie, that it alone cauÅ¿eth a more Å¿olide friendÅ¿hip, love, and amitie: a perÅ¿onable body is often linked with a peÅ¿tilent Å¿oule: a ãâã Captaine in the field, for moÅ¿t part is infected with â¢â¢ effeminate affection at home: thoÅ¿e things we love as profitable, we love not abÅ¿olutely, but rather in them our Å¿elues, for whoÅ¿e vÅ¿e they Å¿erve, and therefore when commoditie faileth,
love quaileth. But thoÅ¿e men we affect for their honeÅ¿tie, thoÅ¿e wee love indeed, and that affection is permanent: becauÅ¿e it Å¿tandeth vpon a Å¿ound foundation, to wit, Vertue and HoneÅ¿tie, the principall obiects of ReaÅ¿on, and reaÅ¿onable affections. And Å¿o we proove daily our Å¿elves, that wee finde many men, who neyther have beautie of body, nor martiall mindes, nor ornaments of learning, nor riches, nor degrees, and yet onely for that we know them Å¿incere, vpright, and honeÅ¿t, all honeÅ¿t men love them, and maugre malice of the wicked, though Å¿pitefully they backe-bite them, yet in their heartes they cannot but commend them. And truely there is almoÅ¿t nothing in this life, which abÅ¿olutely ought to be loved, but that which eyther is, or relliÅ¿heth of HoneÅ¿tie, for all other loves are either indifferent, mercenarie, or vicious; if Vertue; or vertuous men for their Vertue ought to be loved and eÅ¿teemed. O my GOD! the Life of Vertue, what Love is due to thee? who art the QuinteÅ¿Å¿ence and Å¿upreme Perfection, not of heroicall vertue, but of innate and conÅ¿ummate goodneÅ¿Å¿e, dignitie, and maieÅ¿tie: which are as farre aboue the pitch of all excellent Vertues, heroicall, Å¿upernaturall, or theologicall, and infinitely more, then the chiefeÅ¿t Vertues Å¿urmount the baddeÅ¿t vices. The erroneous ignorant PhiloÅ¿ophers, who Å¿tumbled Å¿ometimes vpon true Vertues, though in moÅ¿t they miÅ¿Å¿ed the marke, could Å¿ay, that if a vertuous Soule could be beheld with corporall

div.head: The 9. Motive to Love, is Love it Å¿elfe.
div.p:

â¢â¢ a Plato in LyÅ¿ide. of them that truely love them, it would be as violent to withhold them from reloving againe, as a LioneÅ¿Å¿e from her whelpes lying in her Å¿ight, a Å¿tone in the ayre from his center, a bullet within a diÅ¿charged Cannon. Who would not love an honeÅ¿t vertuous Lover, who honoreth, prizeth, and Å¿erveth whom he loveth? for honor, eÅ¿timation and Å¿ervitude, if they bee cordiall, cannot bee accounted but rare treaÅ¿ures. Hee that loveth vertuouÅ¿ly, eÅ¿teemeth the beloved worthy of honour, becauÅ¿e hee reputeth him vertuous, and therefore in affection yieldeth him condigne
honour due to Vertue: he Å¿erveth him in regard of his great goodneÅ¿Å¿e, which in his conceit meriteth all Å¿ervitude and obÅ¿equious complements. Who would not love a vertuous Lover, who conÅ¿ecrateth himÅ¿elfe, and all hee hath vnto the perÅ¿on beloved? for that one friend is thought able to doe, which his friendes can performe and effect: and therefore a man hath Å¿o manyArist. 3. moral. Nicom. c. 3. bodies, Å¿oules, heartes, eies, eares, tongues, handes, feete, as he hath friendes; and Å¿o by this meanes is made potent and mightie. Ah my loving God! I demurre too long in theÅ¿e Å¿peculative diÅ¿courÅ¿es, and with-hold my Å¿oule too much from patheticall affections. DoeÅ¿t thou Love vs? who doubteth? for if thou hadÅ¿t never loved, we had never lived: and if thy Love continued not preÅ¿ervingDiligis omnia quae Å¿unt: & nihil odisti corum quae feciÅ¿ti. Sap. cap. 11. our being, we Å¿hould preÅ¿ently be reÅ¿olved into duÅ¿t and nothing. Well then thou dooÅ¿t prize vs and honor vs: elÅ¿e thou wouldeÅ¿t never have given the pretious blood of thy Sonne to have redeemed vs. This argueth eÅ¿timation, but not honour: for honour Å¿uppoÅ¿eth Å¿ubiection, inferioritie, and I know not what kinde of vaÅ¿Å¿alage and Å¿ervitude: it Å¿eemeth too preÅ¿umptuous, if not blaÅ¿phemous, to make thee either inferior or equall with men, whoÅ¿e MaieÅ¿tie the higheÅ¿t Seraphims admire, reverence, worÅ¿hip, and with trembling knees adore. Ah my God! of moÅ¿t maieÅ¿ticall and extaticall
Love, Å¿hall I preÅ¿ume to enter into the abyÅ¿Å¿e of thy eclypÅ¿es, exceÅ¿Å¿es, and charitable extaÅ¿ies? They be too deepe for mee, yea, and all the world beÅ¿ide to compriÅ¿e: yet I know who Å¿ayd that thou went out of thy Å¿elfe, and Å¿uffered extacie thorow the vehemencieDyoniÅ¿. Great, no doubt, is thy love (O God without paragon in love) to men in this life: for here thou doeÅ¿t not only affect them, powre out thy benefits vpon them, diÅ¿till thy graces into their hearts, and a thouÅ¿and wayes externally and internally worke their Å¿alvation, but alÅ¿o that which Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿eth all, it Å¿eemeth thy will and power are at the command, or rather ready to obey the deÅ¿ires of thy faithfull Å¿ervants, for what elÅ¿e meane thoÅ¿e protrite words of the PÅ¿alme, Voluntatem timentium Å¿e facit, He fulfilleth the will ofPÅ¿al. 144.
them that feare him? and what other Å¿enÅ¿e can be brought of that requeÅ¿t thou made to thy Å¿ervant MoÅ¿es, Dimitte me, vt iraÅ¿catur furor meus contra eos, & deleam Exod. 32. eos, Suffer me, that my fury be revenged of them, and that I may deÅ¿troy them: but that thy anger and revenge, thy diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ure and their intended deÅ¿truction laid in MoÅ¿es power to rule and guide according to his pleaÅ¿ure? div.head: The 10. Motive to Love, which is ReÅ¿emblance.
div.p:
THe ground of every mans love of himÅ¿elfe, is the Identitie of a man with himÅ¿elfe, for the lover and beloved are all one and the Å¿ame thing: becauÅ¿e love being nothing elÅ¿e but a complacence or contentation in the goodnes or perfection one hath with a deÅ¿ier of the accompliÅ¿hment thereof, conÅ¿equently as we ought both in grace and nature to preferre none before our Å¿elves in the affection of vertue and perfection, Å¿o we Å¿hould not love any above our Å¿elves. From the Identitie of our Å¿elves and the love thereof, neceÅ¿Å¿arily followeth a certaine love to all them who are vnited any way vnto vs, and the Å¿tricter this vnion is, the Å¿tricter affection it engendreth, and for that all things vnited have a kind of reÅ¿emblance, therefore PhiloÅ¿ophers and Divines ground friendÅ¿hip vpon Å¿imilitude: here hence we love our kinÅ¿emen, parents, and children, for the vnion and reÅ¿emblance in blood: Å¿tudents ground their friendÅ¿hip in the Å¿ame kind of Å¿tudies, Å¿ouldiers in martiall affaires, courtiers in civill courtly carriage, tradeÅ¿men in their artes, marriners in navigation: and finally all men of one profeÅ¿Å¿ion love them of the Å¿ame, and Omne animal EccleÅ¿. 13.
diligit Å¿ibi Å¿imile: and every beaÅ¿t affecteth the like, liveth with the like, conÅ¿orteth with the like. And the reaÅ¿on is, becauÅ¿e a man in this life by nature and grace, by the inÅ¿tinct of his innate iudgement and reaÅ¿onable affection, preÅ¿cribeth vnto himÅ¿elfe an end in this world, void of troubles and moleÅ¿tation, quiet, peaceable, full of reÅ¿t and contentation: whereat all his labours, thoughts, and meditations levell: moreover, he being a Å¿ociable creature had need of men to help him in councell, comfort him in griefes, Å¿uccour him in Å¿undrie diÅ¿aÅ¿ters of fortune, which dayly and caÅ¿ually occurre, and finally converÅ¿e peaceably and agreeably with him: all which, none can performe better, not Å¿o well as they whoÅ¿e natures and conditions are like vnto ours: for what diÅ¿Å¿ention can be among thoÅ¿e men, whoÅ¿e wills are one and the Å¿ame? what Å¿orrowes can greatly moleÅ¿t vs, where friends carrie their portions with vs, and thereby alleviate a great part of their waight? what counÅ¿ell can preuaile againÅ¿t many friends, who are wiÅ¿e, diÅ¿creet, faithfull, vertuous? what converÅ¿ation can be more gratefull, then that, where neither iniuries are offered, nor Å¿uÅ¿pected? in few, as vertue is the Å¿ureÅ¿t chaine wherewith men can be bound together, Å¿o reÅ¿emblance in vertue the Å¿ureÅ¿t foundation of friendÅ¿hip, and a vertuous companie the happieÅ¿t Å¿ocietie. O my God of moÅ¿t pure and perfit loue, thou Å¿pake the word and begot thine eternall word, thou breathed out thy love and produced the holy ghoÅ¿t, the life and Å¿oule of all true love, as well create as increate: thy love in Trinitie is one and the Å¿elfe-Å¿ame identified in all the three perÅ¿ons, and the Å¿elfe-Å¿ame thing with their Å¿ubÅ¿tance: and therefore moÅ¿t intier, inexplicable, and perfit is your

Thy creatures are all beloued of thee, becauÅ¿e thou like a father in them haÅ¿t imprinted and Å¿tamped a reÅ¿emblance of thy MaieÅ¿ty: and becauÅ¿e there is none Å¿o baÅ¿e and vnperfit but that all the goodneÅ¿Å¿e it hath, reÅ¿ideth in thee, much more perfitly then it Å¿elfe: therefore no child Å¿o repreÅ¿enteth his father, as every creature thy MaieÅ¿ty, according to that perfection it enioyeth, and thy boundleÅ¿Å¿e eÅ¿Å¿ence comprehendeth. What Å¿hall I heere Å¿ay of the image of thy eÅ¿Å¿ence and three perÅ¿ons in Trinitie engrauen in the center of every reaÅ¿onable Å¿oule? this were a matter too prolixe to diÅ¿courÅ¿e vpon: but well I may conclude, that if thou love all thy creatures for a darke cogniÅ¿ance they carry vpon their backs of thy glorious greatneÅ¿Å¿e, no doubt but thou wilt love & fauour man, who beareth in the face of his Å¿oule thy perfit portrait and image in a farre higher degree? much more might be added of the blood of ChriÅ¿t, wherewith all Å¿oules are Å¿prinkled, who have put him on in their baptiÅ¿me. Finally, thy future reÅ¿emblance which all thy faithfull Å¿ervants Å¿hall poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e in glory, of whom is verified that propheÅ¿ie of S. Iohn, Scimus quoniam cum apparuerit, 1. Ioh. 3. div.head: The 11. Motive to Love, which is agreeableneÅ¿Å¿e with Nature.
div.p: IF a man Å¿hould inquire why the Vine Å¿o loveth by nature the Elme, that it wrappeth more kindly about it, and bringeth forth more plentie and better grapes, then planted at the roote of any other tree: queÅ¿tionles no other reaÅ¿on could be giuen then a certaine Å¿ecret Å¿ympathie of Nature, a proportionate agreeablenes, and naturall conveniencie. What paine taketh the Hen to Å¿itte Å¿o long vpon her egges? what labour endure little Birdes to build their neÅ¿tes, to feede their yonglings, to teach them by daily examples to avoyde dangers, to procure foode, to conÅ¿erve, protect and defend themÅ¿elves? all theÅ¿e, and thouÅ¿ands Å¿uch like, proceed from a certaine Love, grounded vpon the agreeableneÅ¿Å¿e and concordance with Nature. So that Å¿mall pleaÅ¿ures the poore Birdes finde to leave their owne proviÅ¿ion Å¿ought with Å¿uch labour, to cramme their little ones; and no great delight the Hen can reape by Å¿o daintily and carefully covering her egges, but that the want of pleaÅ¿ure is Å¿upplied by the conformitie of Nature, which therein is apertly Å¿hewed.

When we Å¿ee beaÅ¿ts fight, we commonly wiÅ¿h in our harts the victorie Å¿hould happen rather to the one party then the other: If a reaÅ¿on of this deÅ¿ire were demaunded, it were impoÅ¿Å¿ible divers times to be rendred, except we reÅ¿olved it into a Å¿ecret Å¿ympathie of nature: likewiÅ¿e meeting with a companie of Å¿trangers which we never Å¿ee men or women, preÅ¿ently one Å¿hall perceive a certaine more affectuall fancie inclined to love one then an other, although divers times both proportion, comelineÅ¿Å¿e, or I know not what other perfection, be more Å¿pectable in the reiected, then in the accepted. The Å¿ame we might Å¿ay of divers meates drinks, ayers, Å¿mells, lodgings, apparell, &c. which agree and are conformable to Å¿ome mens nature, but marvellous hurtfull and offenÅ¿ive to others, the which therefore are loved of thoÅ¿e, and abhorred of theÅ¿e.

It is hard for me, if not impoÅ¿Å¿ible (O God the center of my Å¿oule) to explicate the admirable proportion, conveniencie, and agreeablenes betwixt thy mercies and our miÅ¿eries, thy riches and our poverty, thine habilities to perfit vs, and our indignities to be perfited, thy patience and longanimitie to Å¿upport iniuries, and our perverÅ¿enes to commit offences. Tell me O thou hart of man, why thou liveÅ¿t in this life, for moÅ¿t part diÅ¿guÅ¿ted, diÅ¿taÅ¿ted, vnquiet, ever loving, never perfitly liking, thirÅ¿ting ever for a happy quiet reÅ¿t, and never attaining any quietnes to thy full contentment or reÅ¿t? Ah my God! one who knew this miÅ¿erie, and had felt the finger of thy mercy, told the cauÅ¿e, for being as vnable to Å¿ettle himÅ¿elfe, as he had perceived the Å¿ame in others, at laÅ¿t was Å¿tirred vp to Å¿eeke to thee, the center, life, and Å¿atietie of the Å¿oule.

Tuenim excitas vt laudare te delectet. Quia fecisti nos Aug. lib. 1. confeÅ¿. cap. 1. ad te, & inquietum eÅ¿t cor nostrum donec requieÅ¿cat in te. Thou excites vs (O God) with delight to praiÅ¿e thee: BecauÅ¿e thou haÅ¿t made vs for thee, and our heart is vnquiet vntill it reÅ¿t in thee. div.head: His IngreÅ¿Å¿e. Â§ 1.
div.p: 1 IF his Parents were baÅ¿e, wicked, or infected with any notorious vice; if deformed in body, or marked by any monÅ¿truoÅ¿itie of Nature.

But Å¿ome will obiect, as I have heard divers, what fault have I if my Parents bee vicious and baÅ¿e? And what commendation is thine, if thy parents bee vertuous and noble? and yet, who is hee, that had not

That is no fault but a Å¿taine, this no vertue but an ornament: men know full well, that waters, which runne thorow Å¿tinking Å¿oyles, carrie an vnÅ¿avory Å¿mell: and that winds and vapours drawne from infected places, are plaguie meÅ¿Å¿engers to many Countries: in like manner, Parents naturall propenÅ¿ions to wickedneÅ¿Å¿e, imprint for moÅ¿t part in their children, a certaine reÅ¿emblance: wherefore as theÅ¿e externall reÅ¿pects be not invincible arguments to convince a vitious nature, or a corrupted Å¿oule: Å¿o when in the progreÅ¿Å¿e of life, we infallibly diÅ¿cover an exorbitant badde carriage and brutiÅ¿h demeanour, then we may well inferre, that the firÅ¿t Å¿taines and infections were ominous preÅ¿ages of future malice: as if Nature had foreÅ¿eene what an infamous gueÅ¿t was to lodge in that body, and therefore prepared a lodging correÅ¿pondent: Adam had a Caine, Abraham an IÅ¿mael, IÅ¿aac an EÅ¿au, Iacob a Dan, David an AbÅ¿olon, and many godly Parents, vngodly children, which argueth manifeÅ¿tly, that neither good nature in Parents, (for what bodies could bee more perfit then thoÅ¿e of Adam and Heua, wholy framed by Gods owne handes, and conÅ¿equently could have no defect?) nor vertuous example, nor provident inÅ¿tructions can Å¿uffice to withdraw a man from wickedneÅ¿Å¿e, if his wicked will intendeth to follow it.

What, have not many BaÅ¿tards prooved well? Å¿igens d. 56 not brought vp with like care and vigilance of their Parents as other legitimate: and commonly Å¿uch Å¿purious

div.head: His ProgreÅ¿Å¿e. Â§ 2.
div.p: THe perÅ¿ons whome wee intend to moove to hatredThat vice Å¿hould moÅ¿t be amplified which the auditors moÅ¿t deteÅ¿t. ought to be conÅ¿idered well before wee repreÅ¿ent vnto them the filthineÅ¿Å¿e of the mans vice for which we intend to make him odious vnto them: for Å¿uch is the corruption of Å¿ome companies, as great Å¿innes with them are little accounted: for example, he that would diÅ¿grace a Å¿ouldier in the Campe, by vehemently exaggerating the mans fornication, Å¿hould little prevayle: or a Merchant among Merchants for vÅ¿ury, in taking ten in the hundred: or drunkenneÅ¿Å¿e among the Dutch men: and Å¿uch like offences before, Å¿uch perÅ¿ons, who eyther will boaÅ¿t of them, or defend them, or at leaÅ¿t extenuate the deformity of them: wherefore in every company that vice Å¿pecially muÅ¿t bee noted, which among theÅ¿e men is moÅ¿t deteÅ¿ted, as treachery and cowardlineÅ¿Å¿e among Å¿ouldiers, bloud and cruelty among Citizens, all Å¿ortes of heynous offences among grave, Å¿ober, iudicious, and vertuous hearers.

As in every vertue there is a lowe degree, a meane,IntenÅ¿ion of vice. and an excellent: for there be beginners, goers forward and perfite, incipientes, proficientes, & perfecti. LikewiÅ¿e in every vertue there is a Å¿upreame excellency, rare, Å¿ingular, and admirable; in temperance virginity, in fortitude apert perilles of death, in prudence preÅ¿ent reÅ¿olutions, deepe councell in affaires of greateÅ¿t importance, as manage of States, and governement of Kingdomes. In iuÅ¿tice neyther to Å¿pare friend, father, mother, nor childe, who offend and tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿e the Lawes. In magnificence
to diÅ¿pend great treaÅ¿ures readily for the honour of God, and generall good of the realme. In mercy eaÅ¿ily to pardon iniuries againÅ¿t our owne perÅ¿ons. As, I Å¿ay, in every vertue there are found theÅ¿e degrees and eminent perfections, Å¿o in vices and offences there appeare varieties of exceÅ¿Å¿es in the Å¿ame Å¿inne; as in theft he that robbeth a rich man, and taketh fourty Å¿hillings from him, can not be compared to him that Å¿tealeth a kowe from a poore man, wherewyth hee Å¿uÅ¿tayned his wife and whole family, wherefore the enormity of the Å¿inne ought greatly to bee weyghed. Agayne, in vice Å¿ome Å¿o farre exceede, as they paÅ¿Å¿e the common courÅ¿e of vitious perÅ¿ons, and arrive at a certayne ferall or Å¿avageSavageneÅ¿Å¿e or feral â¢ tie. brutiÅ¿hneÅ¿Å¿e, delighting in nothing but wickedneÅ¿Å¿e, as beaÅ¿tly pleaÅ¿ures, violent extortions, cruel butcheries, and Å¿uch like barbarous beaÅ¿tlineÅ¿Å¿e, whereby they make Å¿hew to have loÅ¿t all reaÅ¿on and humanity, and onely follow the fury of every inordinate PaÅ¿Å¿ion.

Moreover it is to be conÅ¿idered, that as every vice hath her intenÅ¿ion or vehemency in malice and wickedneÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿o Å¿he hath an extenÅ¿ion and various kinde of deformities: for example, theft hath vÅ¿ury, cooÅ¿onage, pilferings, burglaries, robberies: murther hath woundings, lamings, man-Å¿laughters, wilfull-murthers: Å¿o in intemperance, gluttony, &c. In our preÅ¿ent caÅ¿e, theÅ¿e will mightily aggravate the perÅ¿ons wickedneÅ¿Å¿e, if we can proove him in Å¿undry vices to have committed various exceÅ¿Å¿es, and in every vice not to have wanted variety.

Yet all the enormities a vitious wretch committeth in the progreÅ¿Å¿e of his life may bee reduced to theÅ¿e iij. heads; Irreligion towards God, IniuÅ¿tice towards men,
beaÅ¿tlineÅ¿Å¿e in himÅ¿elfe.

FirÅ¿t, If towards God he hath beene irreligious, an AtheiÅ¿t, an heretike, one that vpon every little hope of preferment or gayne, would change and alter his Religion: to this purpoÅ¿e I cannot here omitte an excellent HiÅ¿tory, penned by EuÅ¿ebius and Zozomenus, of ConÅ¿tantius the father of Constantine the great; who at whatEuÅ¿eb. in lib. 1. vitae Constant. Sozomen. lib. 1. cap. 6. time the inferior MagiÅ¿trates in every Province, by the decrees of the Emperours, moÅ¿t Å¿everely perÅ¿ecuted ChriÅ¿tians, and with Å¿undry Å¿orts of exquiÅ¿ite torments bereaved them of their lives: Constantius to trye his Courtiers conÅ¿tancie in ChriÅ¿tian Religion, put it freely in their election, eyther to Å¿acrifice vnto the Idols, and remayne with him, and keepe their former places and honours; or if they would not, to leave his company and depart from him: preÅ¿ently they divided themÅ¿elves into two parts, Å¿ome offered to Å¿acrifice, others refuÅ¿ed: by this the Emperour perceived his Å¿ervants mindes, and thereupon diÅ¿covered the plot he had caÅ¿t: wherefore reprooving the former, commending the latter, expoÅ¿tulating with them their feare and timiditie, highly exalting theÅ¿e for their zeale and Å¿inceritie, and finally iudging them vnworthie of the Emperours Å¿ervice, as traytours to God, expelled them from his Pallace: for how, quoth he, will theÅ¿e be truÅ¿tie to their Prince, who are trecherous and perfidious to their God? the others he appointed to be his guard, to wayte vpon his body, and to be keepers of his Kingdome: averring that hee doubted not of their fidelity to him, who had beene Å¿o faithfull and conÅ¿tant in profeÅ¿Å¿ing and proteÅ¿ting their beleefe and religion.

Secondly, If he conÅ¿pired againÅ¿t the Prince or State,

If he be of a bloody nature, delighting in quarrels and brawls: or in fine hath perpetrated any notorious offence, whereby the Common-weale, or preÅ¿ent auditors are damnified, either in reputation, or any other way.

Thirdly, If he be convinced by good reaÅ¿ons, guilty in any one vice; that is to be amplified after the beÅ¿t manner: Å¿pecially, if there appeare in it any notable circumÅ¿tance, as oppreÅ¿Å¿ion of Widowes, Orphanes, Women, poore & needy men, honeÅ¿t, devout, or eccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall perÅ¿ons.

div.head: Hatred of a communitie. Â§ 4.
div.p: IN exciting Hatred of a Communitie, Kingdome, Province or any Society. FirÅ¿t wee may weigh their naturall diÅ¿poÅ¿itions and badde inclinations: and Å¿pecially thoÅ¿e, which moÅ¿t offend our preÅ¿ent Auditors.

div.head: Hatred of Abomination. Â§ 5.
div.p:
HAtred of Abomination, as was Å¿ayd above, conÅ¿iÅ¿teth in a deteÅ¿tation of evill, for the love we beare the PerÅ¿on: as Iacob Å¿o dolefully lamented IoÅ¿eph (whom he Å¿uppoÅ¿ed dead) for the tender love hee bare his perÅ¿on: And how bitter is the memorie of death to that man, which hath peace and great felicitie in his Å¿ubÅ¿tance, and that loveth extremely this tranÅ¿itory life? div.head: Meanes to move flight and feare. Â§ 6.
div.p:
WE Å¿aid, that flight or deteÅ¿tation was oppoÅ¿ite to deÅ¿ier: and that deÅ¿ier was the wiÅ¿hing of a thing abÅ¿tracted from hope or expectation thereof, as every beggar would be a King if he might chooÅ¿e, albeit he never had, nor is like to have any hope of the aÅ¿piring thereunto. Flight is a deteÅ¿tation of Å¿ome evill, though not imminent, nor exÅ¿pected, yet Å¿uch an evill as we abhorre it and deteÅ¿t it, and poÅ¿Å¿ibly may befall vs, as a king to fall to poverty, beggery, or Å¿ervitude he abhorreth; yet becauÅ¿e he living in Å¿uch proÅ¿perity conceiveth no danger nor perill, therefore he Å¿tandeth in no feare. TheÅ¿e two paÅ¿Å¿ions of deÅ¿ier and deteÅ¿tation, are Å¿tirred vp with the Å¿ame motives that love and hatred of abomination, for as all the reaÅ¿ons apportable to render the thing amiable, the Å¿ame make it deÅ¿iderable, Å¿o all the inducements which perÅ¿wade the obiect of hatred to be abominable, all the Å¿ame cauÅ¿e it Å¿eeme deteÅ¿table. As for example, I have a vertuous friend whom I love intierly, he converÅ¿eth with AtheiÅ¿ts, the more I love him, the more I hate AtheiÅ¿me, as evill to him, and therefore I abhorre it Å¿hould any way befall him. I am moved to abominate it as an extreme evill, for what can be more Å¿ottiÅ¿h, then to deny a God whom all creatures confeÅ¿Å¿e and Å¿ay ipÅ¿e fecit nos, & non ipÅ¿ae nos, he made vs, and not we our Å¿elves? what can be more beaÅ¿tly then not to acknowledge

No doubt but if AtheiÅ¿me once enter into the hearts of men, vertue will be deÅ¿piÅ¿ed, and vice eÅ¿teemed, might will rule right, and the rich oppreÅ¿Å¿e the poore, and epicuriÅ¿me wil take full poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, edamus bibamus cras moriemur, let vs gull our Å¿elves with eating & quaffing, for after this life no other remaineth, and therefore little it importeth vs to live like beaÅ¿ts, and dye like dogs: all theÅ¿e and many more Å¿uch like arguments demonÅ¿trate the abomination of AtheiÅ¿me, and alÅ¿o perÅ¿wade evidently the deteÅ¿tation of the Å¿ame, Å¿o that by applying the harmes or dammages of the evill, conÅ¿idered in generall, and abÅ¿olutely in it Å¿elfe, to my Å¿elfe, or my friend whom I love, we may eaÅ¿ily force flight and deteÅ¿tation.

Feare is a flight of a probable evill imminent: wherefore two things muÅ¿t be proved & amplified to enforce feare: firÅ¿t that the evill is great: Å¿econdly that it is very likely to happen: the exceÅ¿Å¿e of the evill may be gathered out of the precedent diÅ¿courÅ¿es, the likelyhood, probability, or certainty we draw from Å¿undry circumÅ¿tances, as from our adverÅ¿aries malice, & hatred againÅ¿t vs, their craft & deceit, their former maner of proceeding, wherunto we may annexe the impoÅ¿Å¿ibility or extreme difficulties to avoid it, as their might and our weakenes, their experience and our rawneÅ¿Å¿e: Å¿o that where there is obÅ¿tinate & implacable hatred againÅ¿t vs; knowledge and foreÅ¿ight how to overcome vs; power and meanes

The Romanes in paÅ¿Å¿ed ages who with moÅ¿t carefull eye did foreÅ¿ee & prevent the dangers of their Empire, thought not themÅ¿elves Å¿ecure in Italy, except the Carthaginians were vanquiÅ¿hed: but how much more neere are the TurkiÅ¿h Cities to Spaine, Germany, and Italy, then Carthage was to Rome? His malice isThe Turks hatred againÅ¿t ChriÅ¿tians. no leÅ¿Å¿e then his might: what pretendeth he in Constantinople? forÅ¿ooth to be Emperour over all Europe, and Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿or to Constantine the great, this he claymeth as right, this he meaneth to win by might, this he reÅ¿olveth to inioy at length. div.p: THe iniurers baÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e augmenteth the iniurie, as a buffer given a Prince by a Prince, were not Å¿o heynous an iniury, as if a baÅ¿e peaÅ¿ant had done itâª becauÅ¿e as the greatnes of the Princes perÅ¿on ought more to be reÅ¿pected of a baÅ¿e man then of an equall Prince, Å¿o by beating him his contempt is accounted the greater.

4. If the iniurer were before our moÅ¿t Å¿peciall friend, for that common grammaticall example that AmantiuÌ irae a moris redintegratio Å¿unt, that lovers ire Å¿ets love afier, and friends diÅ¿Å¿entions, renue, revive, & increaÅ¿e friendÅ¿hip. If he have received any benefits at our hands, and in lieu of reward, recognition, and gratitude repaye vs with iniuries & ingratitude: and for this circumÅ¿tance we reade that God in the old TeÅ¿tament expoÅ¿tulating the dayly iniuries the Å¿tiff-neckt Iewes offered him, he vÅ¿ually reprehended their ingratitude with commemorating the continuall benefits he had beÅ¿towed vpon them, as though Å¿uch favours deÅ¿erved better Å¿ervice.

div.head: The iniurie in it Å¿elfe. Â§ 9.

WE may be iniuried in the goods of our Å¿oules, our bodies, of fortune or of good name, exiÅ¿timation or reputation. In the goods of our bodies by killing, mayming, wounding, beating, or any way abuÅ¿ing of them. In goods of fortune by theft, coÅ¿inage, vÅ¿urie, not repaying due debts, hurting our cattell, fervants, children, friends, lands, tenements, or any kind of poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion. In goods of Å¿ame or reputation, by detracting, calumniating, convitiating, or any way diÅ¿honoring vs, as mocking, gibing, or after any Å¿currilous maner

Ordinarily the goods of the Å¿oule are prized above the goods of the body, and theÅ¿e more eÅ¿teemed then the favours of fortune, and they preferred before the blazon of honour: becauÅ¿e, as the origen of love, is firÅ¿t a mans Å¿elfe, and for it all other things beloved; Å¿o theÅ¿e goods, which are moÅ¿t neere himÅ¿elfe, and concerne his Å¿ubÅ¿tance, or neceÅ¿Å¿ary preÅ¿ervation thereof, are more affectually loved, then they which touch him leÅ¿Å¿e; as firÅ¿t his body, then goods of fortune, and laÅ¿t of all, Å¿ame. I Å¿ayd ordinarily, for if we compare a title of honor, as to be Earle, Baron, &c. theÅ¿e are to bee preferred before a great Å¿umme of money: yet I doubt not, but if election were given an Earle to bee a beggar, and an Earle all his life; or a Å¿imple Merchant, but exceeding rich: hee would rather chooÅ¿e this, and refuÅ¿e that, for there is no miÅ¿erie like Nobility preÅ¿Å¿ed with penury. Wherefore alwayes muÅ¿t be held with the chiefeÅ¿t of one degree of goods, with the chiefeÅ¿t of an other, and Å¿o the compariÅ¿on framed, as the chiefeÅ¿t goods of the Å¿oule, of grace, vertue, wiÅ¿edome, prudence, &c. are to be valued above the life of the body, integritie of members, wealth, fame, &c. I know againÅ¿t this diviÅ¿ion and reaÅ¿on, Å¿ome will obiect that common Text of Scripture; Melius Proverb. 22. 1. est nomen bonum, quam divitiae multae: Å¿uper argentum & aurum gratia bona. But to this Text I anÅ¿were, that in it are involved good friends, and their gratious good willes, which are favors of Fortune, and Å¿o to be preÅ¿erred before riches, which

Secondly, fame and a good name Å¿ometime is neceÅ¿Å¿arie to the perfection of vertue, and the good of the Å¿oule, as without them, the Preacher Å¿hould perÅ¿wade but Å¿orrily; the MagiÅ¿trate be obeyed but Å¿ervilely, the Prince honored but ceremoniouÅ¿ly; & in fine, take away a good Name, and all vertuous examples wil Å¿eeme counterfeit hypocriÅ¿ie. Thirdly, true it is, a good Name ought to bee prized above many riches, but I thinke there be few rich men in the world, that had not rather bee iniuried in their good Name, then fall to begging. Fourthly, a good Name or a good Fame wayteth vpon a good Life, and he that liveth badly, for moÅ¿t part carrieth as bad a name and a fame: to our purpoÅ¿e then, a man muÅ¿t have care of his good Name, becauÅ¿e hee Å¿hould live vertuouÅ¿ly, whereby Å¿uch a good Name is gotten: and indeed, Å¿uch a precious fruite hanging vpon Å¿o noble a Plant, Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿eth all worldly wealth; and this I take to be the true and literall Å¿enÅ¿e of this Text of Scripture, whence-from exhaleth that Å¿weete and fragrant Å¿mell of gracious pleaÅ¿ing, and contenting of all men: for a Å¿oule that is really vertuous, and Å¿o knowen and blazed abroad, cannot but Å¿tirre vp mens hearts to like and love well Å¿uch a PerÅ¿on.

div.p: FIrÅ¿t, the greatneÅ¿Å¿e of the PerÅ¿on iniuried, encreaÅ¿eth the iniurie, as a blow given to a Prince, even by a Prince, is accounted more offenÅ¿ive, then done to a private man by a Prince or a private perÅ¿on.

div.head: Meanes to moove Hope. Â§ 13.
div.p:
HOpe is a PaÅ¿Å¿ion, whereby we expect probably or certaynely any future good, or any evil to happen, conceaved as good. For example, the Souldyer expecteth and hopeth for riches, when he lyeth before a Cittie to beÅ¿iege it: the bleÅ¿Å¿ed Saintes in Heaven live in a moÅ¿t certayne Hope of the glorious ReÅ¿urrection of theyr bodyes: the Dyvell in temptyng Gods Servants, hopeth to prevayle. Hope therefore beeyng grounded vpon perÅ¿waÅ¿ion Å¿pecyally of obtayning; therefore all thoÅ¿e Motives which render the atchyevement more likely, all thoÅ¿e Å¿tyrre and moove the PaÅ¿Å¿ion of Hope: and the more forcibly, they which perÅ¿wade it moÅ¿t apparantly and preÅ¿ently. This obiect is endleÅ¿Å¿e, and hardly can be brought to any Methode, for as the thyngs hoped for, are without number; Å¿o the Meanes and Motyves to induce men thereunto be

FirÅ¿t, for that Hope expecteth the thing hoped for, of an other, or by a mans labour, endevour, or induÅ¿try: therefore wee muÅ¿t in Å¿tirring it, have alwayes an eye to the groundes and foundations, whereupon our Hope Å¿hall be built, for as theÅ¿e fadge, Å¿o Hope followeth: if theÅ¿e bee Å¿mall or frivolous, Hope is vayne and ridiculous: if they be Å¿trong and Å¿ound, Hope will proove more certayne and prudent: for wiÅ¿e men alwayes according to theÅ¿e groundes iudge of the event: for example, a man may well hope the TurkiÅ¿h Empyre cannot long continue, becauÅ¿e theyr manner of governement repugneth with Å¿tabilitie and continuation: for how is it poÅ¿Å¿ible, but that in every change of Emperour, there Å¿hould Å¿ucceede civill warres among them, Å¿eeing the new Emperour preÅ¿ently cauÅ¿eth all his brethren to bee Å¿layne, leÅ¿t afterwards they Å¿hould growe potent and trouble his Raigne. I omitte, that this bloody vnnaturall Tyranny (which demaundeth dayly vengeaunce at Gods handes) deÅ¿erveth DiviÅ¿ion, Rebellion and DeÅ¿truction, and onely inferre, that they being certayne to dye in all humane Policie, nay, in naturall equity, are enforced to make partes, and while theyr Father lyveth, provide Forces and Friends, and after hee is dead, to prevayle by Mayne and Might, that theyr Brothers Creation be not theyr deÅ¿truction.

Secondly, among grave men, few reaÅ¿ons and Å¿trong are more effectuall, then a number, but weaker: becauÅ¿e they bee able preÅ¿ently, by the Å¿trength of theyr wittes, to confute and overthrow them. But a

Thirdly, to gather theÅ¿e Motives into heads, I hold it beÅ¿t, in that hope which dependeth vpon the good will of another to performe, to diÅ¿courÅ¿e over the CircumÅ¿tances of actions. If we have potent InterceÅ¿Å¿ours for vs, and wiÅ¿e Agents to procure what we deÅ¿ire: then this CircumÅ¿tance of Quibus auxilijs will greatly further our purpoÅ¿e. Fourthly, it were not amiÅ¿Å¿e to Å¿et downe all the obiections which any way may fruÅ¿trate our Hope, and briefely, orderly, and as evidently as may be, refute them: for thereby all cavilles, and impediments Å¿hall be remooved.

Fiftly, that which I have Å¿ayd of Hope, by a contrary rule, may be applyed vnto DeÅ¿peration: for the difficulty of obtayning that we deÅ¿ire, being remonÅ¿trated

div.head: Meanes to move ioy and delight. Â§ 16.
div.p:
AS there is nothing in this life more potent then pleaÅ¿ure to move men to action, and the attempting of great exploits, Å¿o there is nothing more requiÅ¿ite to be knowne to any man that will be gratefull & acceptable vnto men, then how to move and excite them to pleaÅ¿ure. Secondly it is requiÅ¿ite a man conÅ¿ider the inclinations of thoÅ¿e perÅ¿ons he would move to delight, for quicquid recipitur per modum recipient is recipitur, according to the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the hearer are received the words of the Å¿peaker. the perÅ¿on exceedingly: and therefore the paraÅ¿ites of Princes Å¿tudy dayly & hourely how by deeds & words they may feed this humor: yea Å¿ome of theÌ proceeded Å¿o far in dignifying their Kings and Monarks, that they adored them as gods. div.head: The Å¿ixt Booke, entreating of the defects or imperfections of mens Å¿oules.
div.p:
THE Geographers deÅ¿cribing the Å¿cituation of any country, are not content to Å¿et downe the provinces, citties, and territories thereof, but alÅ¿o they depaint in theyr Cardes, and explicate in theyr Bookes, the Countries and Cities adioyning, that thereby men might know the borders and limits of both, and not miÅ¿take the one for the other: even Å¿o, becauÅ¿e our Å¿enÅ¿itive appetite hath the wit and will which border vpon it; therefore I thought good, to declare certayne of their imperfections, which knowledge will not help vs alitle, to diÅ¿cerne more exactly the nature of paÅ¿Å¿ions. div.head: 1. Naturall ignorance.
div.p:
ALl the Å¿onnes of men are conceived and borne in Å¿inne and ignorance: Aristotle compareth our wits, at the beginning, to a Å¿mooth table, wherein nothing is written, but apt to receive all formes and figures: and in this truely I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿Å¿e one poynt of my ignorance, that it Å¿eemeth to me, that God endoweth bruite beaÅ¿ts with more Å¿parkes of knowledge, then reaÅ¿onable men, and they may be Å¿ayde, even in their nativitie, to have imprinted a certayne knowledge and naturall inÅ¿tinct, to inquire and finde out things neceÅ¿Å¿ary, to be theyr owne PhyÅ¿itians, to flye that may hurt them, and follow that may profit them. Marke but a Lambe almoÅ¿t new yeaned, how it will finde foorth the mothers dugge, diÅ¿cerne and Å¿ingle her foorth in all the flocke, waite vppon her Å¿o dilligentlie,
within eight dayes it Å¿eeth light: but a childe may be many dayes borne, and yet cannot finde out his mothers dugge, except the NurÅ¿e move him vnto it: neyther can it cure it Å¿elfe, or demaund what it needeth, otherwayes then by weeping.

div.p: WHen a man beginneth to practize a little his facultie of VnderÅ¿tanding, then you Å¿hall Å¿ee how fitly he expelleth this chaos of infinite ignorance, lyke an vnskilfull PhyÅ¿itian, who, to cure one diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, cauÅ¿eth a worÅ¿e; Å¿o hee delivereth himÅ¿elfe of ignorance by a multitude of errours, quenching his thirÅ¿t with a potion of poyÅ¿on: this wee may Å¿ee more plainely, by the infinite errours that men are Å¿ubiect vnto by Nature: For let vs conÅ¿ider the famous PhiloÅ¿ophers of paÅ¿Å¿ed ages, who lacking faith, bragged of naturall knowledge: Which of them knew but to what end man was created of God? their diÅ¿Å¿enting Å¿ects and erroneous opinions. IF the ende was apparelled with Å¿uch darkeneÅ¿Å¿e, how how could they bee but ignorant of the meanes neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the atchievement of Å¿uch an ende? and wee dayly proove, what difficulty men feele, in effecting, yea, in reÅ¿olving themÅ¿elves, which action is good, which is badde; how many volumes have beene written of caÅ¿es of ConÅ¿cience, and yet, what good mans conÅ¿cience is not vexte Å¿ome times with Å¿eruples? who can define the qualitie of his actions, affected with Å¿uch varietie of circumÅ¿tances? who can reÅ¿olve himÅ¿elfe, howe far â¢ e the lawe of Nature engraven in our heartes extendeth? div.head: IIII. Difficultie in Vnderstanding.
div.p:
BVt what Å¿hall I Å¿ay of the woonderfull difficultie all men Å¿uffer to come by the knowledge of any Trueth? Veritas in profundo latet; Veritie lyeth in the bottome. div.p:

Therefore I am of opinion in this poynt with Socrates, that as Å¿ober men oughtPlutarch. in Moraribus. eÅ¿pecially to take heed of thoÅ¿e diÅ¿hes and cates which allure and provoke them to eating, although they be not hungry, and thoÅ¿e drinckes which intice them to drinke, howbeit they be not thirÅ¿tie: Å¿o thoÅ¿e Å¿hewes, Å¿peeches, and companies principally ought to be avoyded, which vrge them to deÅ¿ire things impertinent, and to iudge raÅ¿hly without diÅ¿cretion; becauÅ¿e, to examine, and to be inquiÅ¿itive of our owne faults can be never vnprofitable, but to Å¿pie into other mens actions, rarely or never can be profitable, except it be Å¿uperiours or perÅ¿ons in authoritie, Scrutemur, Å¿ayth Ieremie) vias nostras, Thren. 3. 40. but he Å¿ayth not, aliena â¢ : Yea, Saint Paul forbiddeth, Tu quis es qui iudicas alienum Å¿ â¢ rvum. Rom. 14. 4.

div.p:

div.p:

div.head: The Å¿eventh Impediment is, diÅ¿contentment of our owne EÅ¿tate.
div.p:
AN other Impediment I thinke moÅ¿t men feele at one time or other, which hindereth not a little the the progreÅ¿Å¿e of Vertue; and it is, that none can be contented with their owne eÅ¿tates: we perceive not onely a warre or battell in our mindes, but alÅ¿o a certayne diÅ¿contentment in our Å¿elves, whereupon broke foorth thoÅ¿e Å¿aying, Nemo Å¿orte Å¿ua contentus, laudet diverÅ¿a Å¿equentes: wee may be well compared to certayne Å¿icke men, who would ever be changing theyr beds, yet they never finde reÅ¿t, for that the cauÅ¿e of theyr griefe lyeth not in the beds, but in their bodies: the reaÅ¿on why men live Å¿o diÅ¿contented with their owne eÅ¿tates, proceedeth from many croÅ¿Å¿es, which every Å¿tate, condition, exerciÅ¿e, or office carrieth with it; beÅ¿ides, the often exerciÅ¿ing of one thing engendreth fatiety, and therefore alwayes Nature affecteth variety. AgainÅ¿t this tediouÅ¿nes and loathing life, many great helps I can obiect; for, thoÅ¿e which attend indeed to Å¿erve God, find a certaine Å¿ecret Manna, a Paradice of conÅ¿olations, which will eaÅ¿ily mittigate the croÅ¿Å¿es and diÅ¿contentments miniÅ¿tred by a nature ill inclined: for as God permitteth no evill to eÅ¿cape vnpuniÅ¿hed, Å¿o he letteth paÅ¿Å¿e no good vnrewarded; and although this reward Å¿hall be reaped in the harveÅ¿t of eternall life, yet with a quiet conÅ¿cience, the tranquility of mind, an internall peace and conÅ¿olation in heavenly affaires, he fully in this life recompenÅ¿eth all diÅ¿aÅ¿ters and calamities which occurre. Cucurri viani PÅ¿al. 118. 32. mandatorum tuorum (Å¿aid one) dum dilatasti cor meum: and as he that guideth by his providence the Å¿terne of mens Å¿oules, permitteth them not to bee moyled with tentations above the forces and habilities wherewith

And then if a man caÅ¿t his eyes vp to heaven and conÅ¿ider the eternity of pleaÅ¿ures, laid vp for a moment of payne; if he weigh that the Sun Å¿etteth the Å¿ame howre to him that paÅ¿Å¿ed the day in good works, in faÅ¿ting and praying, & to him which vitiouÅ¿ly Å¿pent it in feaÅ¿ting & playing, he Å¿hall perceive how vain fancies, and voluble croÅ¿Å¿es vaniÅ¿h away as little cloudes before the Northerne winds. div.head: The eight Impediment is, That pleaÅ¿ures are preÅ¿ent, which the fleÅ¿h and world yeeld: The ioyes of heaven abÅ¿ent and future.
div.p:
THough men and beaÅ¿tes in many things differ, yet in one we may moÅ¿t plainely diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h them, for beaÅ¿ts regard onely or principally what concerneth the preÅ¿ent time, but men forecaÅ¿t for future events; they know the means & the end, & therfore comparing theÅ¿e 2. together, they provide preÅ¿ent meanes for a future intent. But I know not how originall Å¿in hath enchaunted our heartes, that preÅ¿ent pleaÅ¿ure, all men for moÅ¿t part
preferre before all future ioy: for Å¿ince we Å¿ee not by faith preÅ¿ent, thoÅ¿e things we expect by hope, or abhor by feare, in the meane time the divell, fleÅ¿h, and world, delighting vs with a preÅ¿ent baite, we neglect that we Å¿hould expect, and accept that we finde next: not vnlike to children, who preferre an apple before their inheritance. And without all doubt, I take this to be a moÅ¿t vehement occaÅ¿ion of vice, and Å¿uch an one as hath caÅ¿t many poore Å¿oules to hell; for worldlings will be of the Å¿urer Å¿ide, they thinke it better to poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e one bird in their hands, then expect two in the fieldes, to be Å¿ure of a preÅ¿ent commoditie, then to be vncertaine of a future gayne: for as I remember, one asking of a godly man, (who lived in great auÅ¿terity, poverty, mortification, flying from preÅ¿ent pleaÅ¿ures, with as great zeale as commonly others Å¿eeke after them) what if there were no heaven nor Paradice wherewith thoÅ¿e paynes Å¿hould be recompenÅ¿ed? An other I know, gave a more direct anÅ¿were, for, he being demaunded the like queÅ¿tion, Å¿aid, that if he were never to receyve any reward for thoÅ¿e Å¿mall labours and duties hee did to the glory of God, that hee thought himÅ¿elfe Å¿ufficiently recompenÅ¿ed in this life, with the quietneÅ¿Å¿e of a good conÅ¿cience, with the honeÅ¿tie of a vertuous life, that he could do Å¿omething for the love of ChriÅ¿t, who had Å¿uffered Å¿o much to Å¿ave him: that by his works the MaieÅ¿ty of God was glorified,Iohn 15. 8. to whom all homage was due, all Å¿ervice inferior. And truely Å¿o it is, that if fooliÅ¿h and beÅ¿otted worldlinges could well diÅ¿cerne howe all theÅ¿e preÅ¿ent pleaÅ¿ures vaniÅ¿h like Å¿moake, becauÅ¿e they are not durable,

ContrariwiÅ¿e, thoÅ¿e Å¿pirituall comforts God beÅ¿toweth vpon good Å¿oules here, are Å¿o divine, Å¿o pure, Å¿o excellent, Å¿o content, and inhaunce the Soule, that they exceede all delights, that eyther Nature affoordeth, or Arte inventeth: and well they know this trueth that have prooved it; Å¿uch as mortifie Å¿enÅ¿uality, caÅ¿ting from them the dregs of Egypt, thoÅ¿e, I Å¿ay, Å¿hall not onely enioy the land flowing with milke and hony in Paradice, but a heavenly repaÅ¿t, the foode of Angelles even in the deÅ¿art of this world, which, Nemo novit, niÅ¿i qui accipit, and therefore they deÅ¿erve to be condemned of extreme folly, who preferre a preÅ¿ent toy before eternall ioy.

div.p:

BeÅ¿ides, if all creatures by the inÅ¿tinct of Nature, endevor Å¿o much to win theyr full and compleat perfection, why Å¿hould we degenerate Å¿o farre from our owne nature, as not to accompliÅ¿h that we lacke: marke but the Å¿eede caÅ¿t into the ground, how it laboureth to die, after to live; how it fixeth his rootes, pierceth the ground to enioy the Sunne and ayre, erecteth the Å¿tem, Å¿prings the huskes, iÅ¿Å¿ues the eare, yeelds with the wind, and never giveth over till the corne bee brought to a full maturity: we Å¿ee how new wines, beere, and all liquors worke, by boyling the rawer parts, expelling the dregs, reducing themÅ¿elves to a due temper, proportionated mixture and perfection: if theÅ¿e inÅ¿enÅ¿ible creatures, Å¿o induÅ¿triouÅ¿ly labor to come to theyr end, Å¿hal not we endevour to atchieve our end and felicity? Some more Impediments I could deliver, as the many occaÅ¿ions offred dayly to do ill, the great readineÅ¿Å¿e of matter and favourers thereof, the inÅ¿atiable deÅ¿ire poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿eth our heartes of inordinate pleaÅ¿ures, the admirable diligence in procuring temporall treaÅ¿ures, the extreame delight all men conceyve in theyr owne actions, the great account and eÅ¿timation they do make of them: how Å¿oone they deÅ¿piÅ¿e or abaÅ¿e the enterpriÅ¿es of others, how perverÅ¿e and obÅ¿tinate they live in their own opinions. I could (I Å¿ay) make long diÅ¿courÅ¿es vpon theÅ¿e particular obiects, but that they may all be reduced to Å¿elfe-love, inordinate PaÅ¿Å¿ions, the world and the divell, of which we have intreated largely before: onely I will here adioyne the reaÅ¿on and cauÅ¿e of all this TreatiÅ¿e, why, we having Å¿o many meanes, Å¿o forcible, Å¿o divine,Mat. 7. 15. & 20. 16. 1. Pet. 4. 18. Å¿o continuall, Å¿o Å¿upernaturall, to Å¿erve God, to follow Vertue, to fly Å¿inne; and Å¿carce halfe Å¿o many impediments leading vs to vice and vngodlineÅ¿Å¿e: yet for one that doth well, thouÅ¿ands doe ill, and for one that goes to Heaven, almoÅ¿t a million goes to hell: and that the difficulty may Å¿eeme more apparant, adde another conÅ¿ideration: queÅ¿tionleÅ¿Å¿e, all vniverÅ¿all effectes proceede from vniverÅ¿all cauÅ¿es, as we Å¿ee all men die; therefore we gather, that all have a Nature corruptible, all men are Å¿ubiect to PaÅ¿Å¿ions, preventing and diÅ¿Å¿enting from reaÅ¿on, therefore we inferre, that Nature is corrupted: even Å¿o, Å¿ince moÅ¿t men doe ill, and few good, and after this tenour in all Countries and Nations, therefore we muÅ¿t finde out Å¿ome generall cauÅ¿e.
