div.p: The third reaÅ¿on is, preÅ¿ent delectation; for that we hope is future; that pleaÅ¿ure worldlings perceive, is preÅ¿ent, Å¿enÅ¿ible delectation feedeth the corporall Å¿ubÅ¿tance of Å¿ences, and therefore we eaÅ¿ily perceive it, but vertue affecteth the Å¿oule, not after Å¿o palpable and groÅ¿Å¿e manner, & therefore they deÅ¿piÅ¿e it: wherefore mens Å¿oules, by inveterated cuÅ¿tomes vÅ¿ed to Å¿enÅ¿uall and beaÅ¿tly delights, either not beleeving, or miÅ¿truÅ¿ting, or rather doubting of Å¿pirituall ioyes, they neglect, and for the moÅ¿t part, care not for them, contenting themÅ¿elves with their preÅ¿ent eÅ¿tate, not looking any further: and Å¿o, as beaÅ¿ts they live, and as beaÅ¿ts they dye, according to that Å¿aying, Home cum in honore eÅ¿Å¿e â¢ , non intellexit, PÅ¿al. 48. 13. & 21. comparatus eÅ¿t iumentis inÅ¿ipientibus, & Å¿imilis factus eÅ¿t illis, and Å¿o become, Å¿icut equus & mulus, in quibus non eÅ¿t PÅ¿al. 31. 19. intellectus.

Finally, the lacke of preÅ¿ervation hindereth our Å¿pirituall profite, becauÅ¿e I conceive our Å¿oules without prayer, meditation, the Sacraments of ChriÅ¿ts church, exerciÅ¿e of vertue, and works of pietie, not vnlike a dead body, which for lack of a living Å¿oule dayly falleth away by putrifaction, leeÅ¿eth colour, temperature and all Å¿weetneÅ¿Å¿e, and becommeth ghaÅ¿tly, loathÅ¿ome and Å¿tinking; even Å¿o, the Å¿oule without thoÅ¿e balmes God hath prepared as preÅ¿ervatives, it will be infected with vices, and Å¿tincking with Å¿innes: therefore thoÅ¿e which neglect theÅ¿e benefits, are not vnlike Å¿icke men, which know where medicines lie, but will not Å¿eeke for them, or receive them.

TheÅ¿e foure cauÅ¿es I take to be the principall enimiesMath. 11. 3 â¢ . of our Å¿pirituall life: howbeit I doubt not that ChriÅ¿ts yoke is Å¿weete, and his burthen eaÅ¿ie, if men would conÅ¿ider the meanes, and accept thoÅ¿e helps God hath beÅ¿towed vpon them. But all meanes and helps which ordinarily we proove may be reiected by a wicked will,Prov. 1. 24. IÅ¿a. c. 5. & 62. 2. Matth. 23. 37. and a hard indurated heart may reÅ¿iÅ¿t the Å¿weete calling of God, Quia vocavi & renuistis, extendi manum meam & non erat qui aÅ¿piceret.

By theÅ¿e Scriptures and many more we may eaÅ¿ilyActs 7. 51. Mat. 11. 21. inferre, that neither lacke of meanes, nor lacke of grace hindereth vs from dooing well, but our owne perverÅ¿e and wicked will: let vs but runne over two or three examples, and we Å¿hall even touch with our fingers the certaintie of this veritie.

ConÅ¿ider but Adams fall, how many meanes he had to do well, and yet how baÅ¿ely he fell, he firÅ¿t, by Gods eÅ¿peciall grace, was indued with Å¿o many internall gifts of vertues and knowledge, that eaÅ¿ily he might have obÅ¿erved
that commandement: the inferiour parts were Å¿ubordinate by originall iuÅ¿tice to the Å¿uperior, Å¿o that paÅ¿Å¿ions could not aÅ¿Å¿ault him; he had all beaÅ¿ts, and the whole garden of Paradice, with all the hearbs and trees at his pleaÅ¿ure, therefore the precept was not Å¿o rigorous; for what difficultie were it for a man to abÅ¿taine from one tree, having the vÅ¿e of thouÅ¿ands? He knew moÅ¿t certainely, how by eating, into what a damnable eÅ¿tate he caÅ¿t himÅ¿elfe and all his poÅ¿teritie: wherefore the event might have taught him to prevent the cauÅ¿e: but above all, the perfit knowledge of the Å¿inne he committed againÅ¿t God, the extreme ingratitude, diÅ¿loyaltie and treacherie, might have bridled his mouth from that poyÅ¿oned Apple, which brought preÅ¿ent death of the Å¿oule, and after a time, a certaine death of the body. But all theÅ¿e helps countervailed not his negligence in conÅ¿ideration, and his ill will Å¿educed with ambition.

Let vs take an other familiar example, which dayly occurreth, more common than commendable: a woman married, which breaketh her fidelitie promiÅ¿ed to her husband, marke but what helps Å¿he hath to reÅ¿traine her from this Å¿inne: I omit the Sacraments of ChriÅ¿ts Church, the threatnings of death, Gods iudgement and hell, the enormious offence Å¿he committeth againÅ¿t God, the abuÅ¿e of his benefits, the breach of his law, the contempt of his grace, the remorce of conÅ¿cience, the wounding of her Å¿oule, and Å¿poyling of the Å¿ame; all theÅ¿e, and many more common helps graunted to all Å¿inners, I will Å¿peake nothing of, albeit I thinke them Å¿ufficient to with-hold any ingenious heart from prevarication, only let vs weigh thoÅ¿e particular meanes
Å¿he hath to abÅ¿taine and withdraw herÅ¿elfe from this offence, as the great iniurie Å¿he offereth her husband, the breach of love betweene them, the infamie wherevnto Å¿he for all her life Å¿hall be Å¿ubiect, the Å¿tayne of her kinred and friends, for her fault redoundeth to their diÅ¿credit, as her good to their reputation, the Å¿hamefaÅ¿tneÅ¿Å¿e wherewith God hath indued women, to retayne them from theÅ¿e Å¿hamefull actions, the baÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e and brevitie of that pleaÅ¿ure Å¿he pretends vnvailable to that coÅ¿t Å¿he beÅ¿toweth; yet for all this loÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿he will hazard it: Å¿he neither regardeth the good Å¿he leeÅ¿eth, nor the harmes Å¿he incurreth, nor the little trifle Å¿he winneth, tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿eth the law of nature, the law of God, the law of chriÅ¿tianitie, the law of friendÅ¿hip, onely for lacke of prudent and mature conÅ¿ideration married to a wicked Wili, and perverÅ¿e affection. That which I have Å¿ayde of this lewd Woman, the Å¿ame might be Å¿ayde of all Å¿inners, becauÅ¿e the meanes to do well are Å¿o many, and the dommages Å¿o great, that every Å¿inne conÅ¿ummate carrieth with it, that I could make a whole booke of them, and perhaps, in time, I will do it. In the meane Å¿eaÅ¿on (gentle Reader) whenÅ¿oever occurreth any occaÅ¿ion apt to induce thy Will to offende God, runne not too faÅ¿t after it, ponder a little, crave helpe from above, conÅ¿ider thy helpes, expende thy harmes, and preÅ¿ently thou Å¿halt Å¿ee that all tentations of this worlde will become like to the huge Statue that Nabuchodonozor beheld, with the head of golde, the breaÅ¿t of Å¿ilver, the belly of braÅ¿Å¿e, the legges of yron,Daniel c. 3. the feete of yron and earth; for all pleaÅ¿ures are golden in the entraunce, but Å¿till decreaÅ¿e to terreÅ¿triall and earthly Å¿ubÅ¿taunces, towardes the ende

div.head: A Succinct PhiloÅ¿ophicall declaration of the nature of Clymactericall yeeres, occaÅ¿ioned by the death of Queene Elizabeth.â¸ª
div.p:
AFter the death of Queene ELIZABETH, who died in the 70. yeere of her age, which was the Clymactericall period of her life, diuerÅ¿e pregnant wits, and curious PhiloÅ¿ophers were aÅ¿Å¿embled by chance togither, & among Å¿undry other learned DiÅ¿courÅ¿es, one demaunded of me, what were theÅ¿e Clymactericall yeeres, their nature, and effects: For (quoth hee) I haue heard many PhiloÅ¿ophors and PhiÅ¿itians talke of them, but as yet I neuer throughly could pierce or penitrate them. I aunÅ¿wered him, that the TreatiÅ¿e thereof required longer time, then that place and preÅ¿ent occaÅ¿ions afforded, but that afterwards at more ley Å¿ure hee Å¿hould vnderÅ¿tand them, if hee were deÅ¿irous to learne: The Gentleman importuned
me Å¿o much, as at laÅ¿t hee drew me to write this DiÅ¿courÅ¿e which followeth: & for that it Å¿eemeth not altogether impertinent to this explanation of PaÅ¿Å¿ions, I thinke it not vnfit to be inÅ¿erted in the laÅ¿t Booke of the PaÅ¿sions of the Minde; becauÅ¿e the Å¿ame temper of body, and propenÅ¿ion to death, which is the baÅ¿e of Clymactericall yeres; the very Å¿ame conferres much, either to mooue PaÅ¿sions, or hinder the opperations of the Å¿oule, as in the progreÅ¿Å¿e of this diÅ¿courÅ¿e Å¿hal plainly appeare.

Clymax in Greeke Å¿ignifieth a Staire or a Ladder, and metaphorically is applyed to the yeeres of a man or womans life; as if the whole courÅ¿e of our dayes were a certaine, Ladder, compounded of Å¿o many Å¿teppes.

True it is, that as the conÅ¿titutions of mens bodies are, for the moÅ¿t parte, of two Å¿ortes, the one is firme and Å¿trong, the other more weake and feeble: Å¿o the PhiÅ¿itians by long experience haue obÅ¿erued, that the fatall ends of them who be of a luÅ¿tie conÅ¿titution, finiÅ¿h for moÅ¿t part in Å¿ome Å¿core of yeeres, and Å¿o they number Å¿uch perÅ¿ons periods by twentie, 40. 60. 80. 100. 120. And toOther count them by tens. this purpoÅ¿e Å¿ayde MoÅ¿es, *whoÅ¿e eyes were neither darkned, nor any tooth looÅ¿ed. *Centum viginti Deut. 31. 2. annorum Å¿um hodie, non poÅ¿Å¿um vltra egredi, & ingridi: I am now an hundred and twenty yeeres old, I can no more goe out and come in, that is, no longer liue: and Å¿o it fell out, for that * Å¿ame yeereDeut. 34. 7.
he died. And GOD himÅ¿elfe Å¿aid of man * Erunt GeneÅ¿. 6. 4. dies illius centum & viginti anni. The dayes of man Å¿hall be an hundred and 20. yeeres.

The next Clymactericall yeere in them of Å¿olide and virile conÅ¿titution is an 100, and Å¿o the Scriptures report. Numerus dierum vitae hominum vt EccleÅ¿. 18. 8 multum centum anni. The number of the dayes of the life of men at moÅ¿t is an 100 yeeres. Another kinde of men whoÅ¿e complexion is weaker, haue a leÅ¿Å¿er kinde of meaÅ¿ure, as they haue Å¿horter life; and yet theÅ¿e alÅ¿o be of two Å¿orts, Å¿ome Å¿tronger, Å¿ome weaker: the firÅ¿t Clymactericall yeeres are nine, eighteene, tweentie Å¿eauen, thirty Å¿ix, forty fiue, fifty foure, Å¿ixty three, Å¿eauenty two, eighty one; the Å¿econds are, Å¿eauen, foureteene, twenty one, twenty eight, thirty fiue, forty twoo, forty nine, fifty Å¿ix, Å¿ixty three, Å¿eauenty. Of theÅ¿e two ages Å¿pake Dauid when hee Å¿ayde. Dies annorum PÅ¿alme 89. 10. nostrorum in ipÅ¿is Å¿eptuaginta anni. Si autem in potentatibus octoginta anni amplius corum labor & dolor. The dayes of our yeeres are Å¿eauentie yeeres, and if in Potentates they be eightie, the labour and griefe is greater.

The moÅ¿t daungerous of all theÅ¿e paÅ¿Å¿ages or Å¿teps, are the forty nine, compounded vpon Å¿euen times Å¿eauen: and Å¿ixty three Å¿tanding vppon nine times Å¿eauen, and next to theÅ¿e is Å¿eauenty, which containeth tenne times Å¿eauen; they number them alÅ¿o by nine, and Å¿o make eighty one, the
moÅ¿t perillous as comprehending nine times nine.

TheÅ¿e obÅ¿eruations then of PhiÅ¿itians preÅ¿uppoÅ¿ed as true, for men that are wiÅ¿e, vertuous, and experimented in their faculties ought to be belieued (for wiÅ¿dome and experience protect them from errour, and honeÅ¿tie from lying and deceite) it were good to examine and Å¿earch out the cauÅ¿e of theÅ¿e notable alterations and daungers of death in the Clymactericall yeeres, for thoÅ¿e humors which alter the bodie, and diÅ¿poÅ¿e it to Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, and death; the Å¿ame bend the Å¿oule to take inordinate affections and paÅ¿Å¿ions. I haue heard Å¿ome PhiÅ¿itians reÅ¿olue this doubt into the influence of heauens, to wit, that Å¿o manie courÅ¿es of the Sunne, Moone, and Planets from the time of a mans Natiuitie, worke Å¿uch effects; Å¿o that Å¿ome men, let them liue neuer Å¿o orderly, after Å¿o manie circular motions of the Sunne and Moone haue warbled ouer their heads, vppon neceÅ¿Å¿itie they muÅ¿t fall into one Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e or another, and Å¿o die.

Some others ground this varietie and daungerous diuerÅ¿itie, vppon the Å¿ingular prouidence of God, who hath created all thinges In numero, pondere & menÅ¿ura: and therefore hath preÅ¿cribed infallibly the periods of mens liues, according to that PÅ¿alm: Notum fac mihi domine finem meum: & numerum dierum meorum quis eÅ¿t: vt Å¿ciant
quid deÅ¿it mihi. Ecce menÅ¿urabiles poÅ¿uisti dies meos. PÅ¿alme, 38. Make knowne vnto me O Lord mine end, and the number of my dayes, that I may knowe what I want. Loe thou haÅ¿t put my dayes menÅ¿urable; that is, preÅ¿cribed certaine bounds and limmits of age not paÅ¿Å¿able: and therefore both PhiloÅ¿ophers and PhiÅ¿itians conclude, that a man with manie diÅ¿orders, Å¿urfeits, exerciÅ¿es, &c. may Å¿horten the natural courÅ¿e of his life, but that he cannot any way prolong it, & paÅ¿Å¿e the prefixed inÅ¿tant of his death: the Å¿imilitude we haue in a candle lighted, for let a man vÅ¿e all the diligence poÅ¿Å¿ible, the light and fire feeding vpon the candle, perforce will conÅ¿ume it at laÅ¿t; and God or any Angell behoulding the quantitie of the wike, tallow, time of the yeere (for in cold weather a candle conÅ¿umeth more then in hote, Per antiperistaÅ¿in) and other circumÅ¿tances may preciÅ¿ely foretell, that Å¿uch a candle cannot continue burning longer then Å¿uch a minute of Å¿uch an houre; in a Å¿horter time it may be conÅ¿umed with wind, witches, Å¿nuffe-fallings, or Å¿uch like things which waÅ¿te it away, but longer it cannot be prolonged: after the Å¿ame Å¿ort Å¿tandeth the courÅ¿es and the liÅ¿tes of our liues preÅ¿cribed by God and prefixed by nature: and Å¿o God hath appointed theÅ¿e Septuarie, and Nonarie yeeres as beÅ¿t Å¿eeming his wiÅ¿dome and prouidence.

TheÅ¿e manners of declaration I will not confute, for albeit I doe thinke them both in Å¿ome
things moÅ¿t true, yet they are too generall and remote to anÅ¿were and Å¿atisfie fully our demaund. The difficultie, no doubt, is exceeding hard, and rather I belieue it to be true for the authoritie of PhyÅ¿itians, then for any credite I can giue to theyr reaÅ¿ons; for indeede all that I haue heard diÅ¿courÅ¿e thereupon (and I haue heard Å¿ome verie fine wits) and what I haue read, dooth not content nor Å¿atisfie my minde. Therefore I will Å¿et downe my PhyloÅ¿ophicall conceite (for in this Å¿peculation PhyÅ¿ick dependeth vppon PhyloÅ¿ophie) and firÅ¿t Å¿uppoÅ¿e that cuÅ¿tomes, habites, changes, and great alterations in mens bodies come Å¿eldome vppon a Å¿uddaine, but by little and little grow and increaÅ¿e by tract of time; and as we Å¿ay.

div.p:
Galen to declare the nature and force of cuÅ¿tomeGalen. de ConÅ¿uet. c. 2. and what effects it worketh in vs, demaundeth this queÅ¿tion: how it commeth to paÅ¿Å¿e, that Å¿ome mens natures abhor exceedingly Å¿ome Å¿orts
of meate, and are not able to diÅ¿gueÅ¿t them; as for example, Å¿aith he, Å¿ome cannot abide beefe, others Å¿hell fiÅ¿hes; and we haue manie who cannot Å¿o much as endure the Å¿ight of cheeÅ¿e, others of aples: And yet theÅ¿e Å¿ame perÅ¿ons by little and little are brought to eate, diÅ¿gueÅ¿t, yea and greatly to like them? He anÅ¿wereth, that all beaÅ¿ts and men haue naturall propenÅ¿ions, to Å¿uch meates as are conÅ¿orting with the naturall proprieties of theyr bodies, and abhor Å¿uch things as are contrarie; and therefore the Lyon feedeth vppon fleÅ¿h, not vpon hay; and the Oxe vpon hay not vpon fleÅ¿h; yet it falleth out that by tract of time, thoÅ¿e meates which we deteÅ¿ted, after by vÅ¿e become familiar, for they alter the body, and by the Å¿ucke of theyr nouriÅ¿hment, change the affections and qualities of the Å¿tomack, in Å¿uch Å¿ort, as that meate, which before was moleÅ¿tfull, and in very deede hurtfull, becommeth Å¿auorie and healthfull: and this he proueth, not onely to be true in men and beaÅ¿ts, but alÅ¿o in feedes and trees, whoÅ¿e fruite in Å¿ome countries are poyÅ¿on, transferred into other Å¿oyles where they receiue another kind of noriÅ¿hment, they become, not only by tract of time; not hurtfull, but very healthfull; not poyÅ¿onfull, but pleaÅ¿ant.

Secondly, it is to be conÅ¿idered, that our bodies generally haue certaine courÅ¿es, paÅ¿Å¿ages, Å¿tations or periods, wherein they notably change their actions and operations: till 21. yeeres, or 25. at the moÅ¿t, we grow in height, for Å¿ome come to theyr
full growth Å¿ooner, Å¿ome later: from 25. to fortie two, or forty fiue, we grow in breadth or thicknes, from this, till the end of our dayes we decline: the cauÅ¿e of theÅ¿e three notorious alterations is our naturall heate or humidum radicale, (which in mine opinion is nothing els but the vitall temper, and qualification of euery Å¿olid part of our bodies) the which reÅ¿iding in a moiÅ¿t body, cauÅ¿eth it to grow, like the heate in a loafe of Dowe Å¿et in the Ouen: afterwards, what with internall heate, externall drying of the windes, and Å¿unne, and other continuall exerciÅ¿es, which daily exÅ¿iccate the body, & draw out the vndegueÅ¿ted moyÅ¿ture, the innated heate is not able to rouze vp the body any more in height, but Å¿preadeth it abroade, and Å¿o enlargeth, and ingroÅ¿Å¿eth it: after which continuall working, heate is weakened, and Å¿o by little and little Å¿till decayeth: and finally reÅ¿olueth in diÅ¿Å¿olution.

Thirdly, in this Å¿eptuarie number of our yeeres, although we cannot diÅ¿couer Å¿uch notorious differences, as in the three former paÅ¿Å¿ages, yet in theÅ¿e likewiÅ¿e, we may obÅ¿erue Å¿ome markable change. At the firÅ¿t Å¿eauenth yeere, men commonly note, that then the child beginneth, to haue Å¿ome little Å¿parkes of reaÅ¿on: and for this cauÅ¿e, the Cannon Law permitteth Å¿uch, directed by their parents or Tutors, contrahere Å¿ponÅ¿alia, to make a promiÅ¿e of future mariage. In the foureteene yeere, the youth is thought to haue the perfit vÅ¿e of reaÅ¿on, & then the Cannons account him capable of marriage.
At twenty one, a man is reputed able iudiciouÅ¿ly to diÅ¿poÅ¿e of his goods, and faculties, and therfore the Common-law riddeth him then of his vvardÅ¿hip, and the Cannons giue him leaue to take the order of Å¿ubdeacon: the firÅ¿t Å¿eauen yeeres are called infantia, the Å¿econd pueritia, the third adoleÅ¿centia, the fourth, that is, from twenty one to twenty eight, iuuentus, from thence to forty nine, hee is eÅ¿teemed to Å¿tand in Å¿tatu virili, the next till Å¿ixtie three is Å¿enectus, after, till Å¿eauenty & Å¿eauentie Å¿eauen, for moÅ¿t part enÅ¿ueth decrepita aetas. In all theÅ¿e periods, or Clymactericall yeeres, it is to be noted, that although the change in that yeere be perceiued moÅ¿t palpably, and Å¿enÅ¿ibly, yet in all the precedent, they were preparing, working, and Å¿omething diÅ¿poÅ¿ing there-vnto: as for example, wee muÅ¿t not thinke that the leaÅ¿t drop of rayne, which in effect breaketh the Å¿tone, dooth it of it Å¿elfe, for that were impoÅ¿Å¿ible, but it doth it in vertue, and by force and working of all the former: And perhaps for this cauÅ¿e they were called anni Å¿calares, for that euery yeere precedent, was a Å¿teppe to the laÅ¿t, wherein the Ladder or Å¿taires were ended.

Fourthly, there is a great diÅ¿pute among PhiÅ¿itians, what Å¿hould be the cauÅ¿e of the ParoxiÅ¿mes, or fittes in Agues, and once I my Å¿elfe being troubled with a tertian Ague, in Italie, in the Cittie of Como, there came two PhiÅ¿itians my deere friends, and a Doctor of Diuinitie all at one time to viÅ¿ite me, and euen then I Å¿tood in expectation of my
fit. After many complements & diÅ¿courÅ¿es about my Å¿icknes, at laÅ¿t I demaunded theÅ¿e two Doctors of PhiÅ¿icke, that they would reÅ¿olue mee in one doubt about my diÅ¿eaÅ¿e: they aunÅ¿wered, with a good will: Well, Å¿ayd I, you both conclude, and it Å¿tands with good reaÅ¿on, that this Å¿icknes of mine proceedeth from exceÅ¿Å¿e of choller: now I would know of you, when my fit is paÅ¿t, is the choller all diÅ¿gueÅ¿ted, conÅ¿umed, and voyded away or no? If it be conÅ¿umed, why dooth my Ague returne? if it be not conÅ¿umed, why dooth mine Ague depart? The PhiÅ¿itians here aunÅ¿wered one contra
â¢ ie to another: for the firÅ¿t Å¿ayd it was diÅ¿gueÅ¿ted: Why then returneth mine Ague? For this cauÅ¿e quoth he, the Ague proceedeth not onely of choller, but of choller putrified, corrupted, and poyÅ¿oned. Now Å¿ir, the choller poyÅ¿oned is conÅ¿umed, but other choller which remaineth, is not corrupted, but by the next paroxiÅ¿me it will be corrupted: Well, Å¿ayd I, what thing is that which corrupteth & poiÅ¿oneth that good choller, which before was not corrupted? It Å¿eemeth Å¿trange to me, how Å¿o much preciÅ¿ely Å¿hould be corrupted, and the other beeing Å¿o neere lying by it, or rather vnited with it, yea mingled in it, not to be infected: In truth I remember not what he aunÅ¿wered, but I am Å¿ure he Å¿atisfied none of vs all. The other Doctor of PhiÅ¿icke Å¿ayd, it was not conÅ¿umed, but nature feeling the force of that poyÅ¿on, vnited her Å¿elfe to fight againÅ¿t it, and Å¿o allayed moÅ¿t of the vehemencie, vigour, and malignitie thereof: and
hee gaue an example of a pot of water Å¿et on the fire, for quoth hee, if the coales be couered with aÅ¿hes, the hote water cooleth, blow the fire and it warmeth and boyleth, let aÅ¿hes returne, or the fire die, the water returneth to the firÅ¿t coldneÅ¿Å¿e: So quoth hee, the poyÅ¿on of the choller, by natures might is ouercome, when the Ague departeth, but after that thoÅ¿e Å¿pirits and forces, which nature had vnited, are diÅ¿perÅ¿ed, the fire is quenched, and choller againe corrupted. But quoth the other PhiÅ¿itian, Å¿o the Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e Å¿hould neuer depart, for if your choller be Å¿till in cooling and heating, and nature now fighting, now ceaÅ¿ing, when I pray you Å¿hall this combat be finally ended? Marry Å¿ir quoth his fellow Doctor, in this Å¿ort, nature mittigateth the forces of choller this fit, and allayeth them: now nature in the meane time, is Å¿trengthned with good foode, and the humour either purged, or quailed with phiÅ¿icke, and Å¿o by little and little it is quite diÅ¿gueÅ¿ted.

Not Å¿o Å¿aid the other, for then the Å¿econd fit Å¿hould alwayes be leÅ¿Å¿e then the firÅ¿t, and the third leÅ¿Å¿e then the Å¿econd, and Å¿o forward to the laÅ¿t: but this is falÅ¿e, for his third and fourth fits, were much more vehement, then either the firÅ¿t or Å¿econd. And beÅ¿ides, by this declaration, no man Å¿hould euer die vpon an Ague. For if in euery fit, the Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e ceaÅ¿Å¿ed not, vntill the humour were allayed, then certainly in Agues, (which are mortall)
the fitte Å¿houlde neuer paÅ¿Å¿e, which is moÅ¿t falÅ¿e.

With this the Doctor of Diuinitie, who was a very good PhiloÅ¿opher, and for that he had beene much troubled with maladies, he was like manie wrangling Gentlemen, a petty-fogging PhiÅ¿itian at his owne coÅ¿ts, as they be petty-fogging Lawyers thorow theyr owne Å¿utes.
